number of helpful: 30 of 46 people (65%) found this review helpful17 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												*Gets handed a Microphone*What...Path of Exile? Wh- NOW!?...Okay...Uhm...It's better than Diablo! 10/10....What more do you want from me at this short no- WE'LL DO IT LIVE! W-WE'LL DO IT LIVE DAMNIT!#I Want Malachais SpikeANYWAY, What's Path of Exile? It's Diablo, done right, pretty much. Yeah I know some of the fanboys are PROBABLY going to downvote me for this, but it's still true. The game is free, and is more dynamic and polished than Diablo ever was. That can be a bad as well as a good thing...With Diablo you don't get in-game stores cause you already paid for it a-...Wait you can buy stuff for it on battlenet?...Well...Uhm...okay!The game's pretty much you picking one of 7 different classes...From brute monster dudes to a creepy witch gal, and then you get pitted against four chapters of various horrifying and SUPER edgy monsters, while being forced to tackle the most INTIMIDATING SKILL TREE THAT YOU WILL EVER EVER SEE FOR AS LONG AS YOU LIVE!!![i.imgur.com]. Seriously, it's flipping mind blowing! There are dozens of different paths to take and things to do and stuff and what have you! It's outrageous! And to add insult to injury: There's no tutorial what so ever! After getting to a certain point in the first playthrough, you unlock a jack of all, ace of none character, named Scion, who's pretty much a blank slate character. Do what you want with type of deal.The graphics are a-okay and it actually gives you a wide range of spec requirements...the recommended is nice and high and lets even the toughest rigs get to make the game into a gorey HD experience, while the minimum are so low that even the worst old crappy laptops(Like my own) can play it with little to no complications!Once you've completed the game on normal difficulty....you...GET TO PLAY THROUGH IT AGAIN!...This time on cruel difficulty, and then merciless!!! Yes, you have to backtrack the same stuff you just did if you want to level past 35-40 -.- Cause thats when you reach the last bit of chapter 4 and the game starts from scratch 1 difficulty level higher.But it's okay cause you'll NEED to know how this stuff works anyway! Normal difficulty is more like a 'let me show you how its done' stage, and cruel difficulty is actually the INTENDED difficulty of the game! Or that's the feeling I got from it, anyway.So now lets do some pros and cons...Pros:It's better than Sakura ClickerYou have the most freedom skill wise than in any other game that I've ever seen.Large assortment of classes to choose from, including one ace of none jack of all character to unlock.Very large community, which is commonly adultThe game is INSANELY gorey and kind of horror based. Lots of impaled corpses and body parts and literal RIVERS of blood. If you're a gorefest lover, you'll ADORE this game!Naked golden statue women with really nice golden asses...BIG plus for that one.PvP is a thing!Crazy difficulty curve...Easy at first, IMPOSSIBLE to solo at the end.A real e-peen fertilizer! You feel you have a boner that could lift your desk when you're wrecking parts of the game that shouldnt be soloable, by yourself!You can raise the dead to fight for you, then make them explode when they die, then raise the dead who just died to your zombie minions...It's AMAZING!!!Cons:The currency system is a complete mess...It's based on 'orbs' and there are literally 15+ different orbs to keep track of, each more valuable than another and WHAT value they exactly are switches from day to day and from person to person, so you might buy something for 10 regal orbs but can only seem to sell it for 5 etc.How good you are is RNG based. When you get a good piece of gear, it might not fit your needs exactly(You might do lightning dmg mainly and the piece has cold dmg!). So you use an orb of chance or whatever it is to change the attributes of it to fit your needs....And you might end up making it WORSE, like putting strength on some mage gloves or something stupid like that! Being good in this game relies a LOT!!! on luck of the draw.Repetitive as all hell.You play through the game...next difficulty...Play through the game...NEXT difficulty...OH there's an event! Make a new character, play through the game, event ends, new character again, new league to get better get...Play through the game, next difficulty, league ends, character gets put in hardcore league....If character died, character's bumped to standard league. Make new character etc. It's the same exact stuff over and over again.Bit of a random storyline.It's kinda hard to follow the lore of the game, as it's all kind of just thrown at you as you go along :\ Unless you sit and waste 30 seconds - 3 minutes reading dialogue from NPCs, you will have NO IDEA whats going on, or why Merveil has to die, or why Malachai is a grade A ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, etc.Other than that, the game is, for its few, not super crippling flaws, a really good one, and I do indeed recommend it.

number of helpful: 17 of 23 people (74%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
-Quick Review-Path of exile is a free to play dungeon crawler which reverses skill points and abilities, you can always change your abilities, but you are limited in changing skill/trait/build points. Please note, I feel that dungeon crawlers are probably my weakest style to review, because they all start to feel the same to me after awhile, put in a few words, I enjoyed this one the most out of Diablo3, Torchlight 2. -Detailed breakdown review- Story:  Hail Exile, you are on Wraeclast, a bloody and dangerous land full of treasure, loot, monsters, Goatmen, and various other enemies. I just remember Goatmen, because I feel like they're following me around in dungeon crawlers. *looks out window*You won't be playing this game for its story, while the game does provide fully voiced dialogue with the various npc's, my best friend never gave me time to listen to the dialogue, so we just kept dungeon grinding and skipped the conversations. The basic gist of the story is: You're an exile, go get your revenge, got your revenge? Restart! You're an exile, go get your revenge, got your revenge? One more time! You're an Exile, go get your revenge, got your revenge? Yay! Now you need to map grind. Game Play: As with dungeon crawler games you control movement with clicking, you're in the above view watching your exile run all over your screen. additionally you can set various action butons, 1,2,3,4,5 are quick buttons to use flasks. you can bind left, middle or right click to different attacks, as well as several keys on your keyboard.You also face some npc's that are a different color or have a different health bar, indicating they're  cooler than other npc's; if you see these smug npc's be sure to slap them and tell 'em Atratzu sent you. But, on a more serious note, they have different abilities, and attack types, sometimes they can leap, sometimes curse, other times they shoot hyper beam at you. Achievements: there are really two types of achievements, the ones regular people can do, and the ones that will require a commitment to the game. This game is meant to appeal to hardcore gamers, there is also a hardcore mode.  Price:  The game's free, you have no excuse to not at least try it sometime. If you want to look like a badass, then you need to pay real money to get the aesthetics or bank space. But if you are just looking to play a dungeon crawler for a little while, go for it. Conclusion: Story: What story? Why are we killing this guy again? because that random guy said so? Okay! *murders face*. Game Play: Fun, but unforgiving in the skill point tree. Achievements: Mostly challenging grindy or RNG achievements. Price: Free, for everything else... there's Master card.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update April 11, 2015:small grammar, spelling, and punctuation fix

number of helpful: 14 of 19 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I never thought I'd love Path of Exile as much as I love Torchlight 2. I love the idea of the huge passive skill tree and Final Fantasy style active skill system. Instead of providing a linear active skill tree, skills in Path of Exile are itemized onto "Skill Gems". These gems can be activated by socketing them into your equipment. With the addition of a "Support-Gem", you can make your own unique skill. For example a simple fireball gem combined with "Multiple Projectiles" gem will turn your fireball skill into multiple fireballs. You can experiment and make your own active skills. There are thousands of combinations of skills and augmentations.The most important thing -- the game is completely free! PoE offers ethical micro-transactions. There is no pay-to-win element. People can buy only cosmetic items for real-world money.If you are going to give this game a try then remember to pre-plan your build or get ready to create new characters many times because "Math of Exile" punishes casual players.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												It starts of as a pretty nice game, but after you play for 100+ hours you start to understand how this game works.The skill tree is not as impressive as it might seem, all characters end up being the exact same thing, 1 skill linked to support gems on a 6Link for the sole purpose of spamming in AOE. There is no skill, it's all about maxing out your character through gear to spam the same spell over and over again. You can play how you like, but the end game is just that. Every single build will mass AOE spam, there is no alternative. The passive skill tree and every single gem is nullifed because of this, it is all essecially the same thing. Everything ends up being AOE, it doesn't matter if you're melee or a spellcaster. Games like torchlight 2, the combat is more entertaining, you need to rotate multiple spells, its more combat focused. This game lacks major combat enjoyment.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Do you like loot? Do you like the ability to build your character and class almost any way you want? Do you want a game where the only purchasable items in the microtransaction shop are visual effects and won't help a uber rich person ruin the game? How about a very fleshed out damage and defense system? And finally, do like RPG's? Well then, this Free-2-Play Action RPG is for you! You get the ability to create a build that could be super tanky, super DPS oriented, or a mixture of both. There are so many Unique (Legendary) items with interesting stats and mechanics that you can be an adept Spellcaster that has mastered Lightning attacks, or a Berserker that has invested points in Fire and can crush his enemies with a menacing maul! Or maybe a Ranger who could freeze her enemies using her Ice based arrows! Or you could be the support, the one who masters Auras and gives huge buffs to themself and their party members! You can call upon Ancient Totems to do your dirty work, or raise Zombies and Skeletons, and maybe even raise a Ghost of a fallen enemy or two! With this game, the ways you can dispatch enemies is almost limitless, and the fact that this game is F2P is awesome. Path of Exile is constantly updated, and every few months a new content patch is implemented, so you can expect this game to live for a long time to come. The only problems I have with it are the always online DRM. Desync has accounted for many of my deaths, some of them in Races, and that is a giant bummer. If we were able to rely on our internet as little as possible, then I think this game could get a lot better. Trading is also hit and miss, as there is no universal currency. You pick up currency items, which are, for the most part, Orbs and Scrolls, and trade them up and down, depending on how rare they are and what  you need. All Currency is usable in the way that resources in other games such as Minecraft are. A Alchemy Orb will upgrade a normal item to a rare, and thus is worth more than a Transmutaion Orb which only goes to a Blue, etc. Overall, I love this game and will continue to create new builds and characters. I'd give PoE a 8/10 on my scale. EDIT!!!After playing this game for hours, I am dropping the naive rating of 8/10 to 6.5/10, JUST FOR THE ♥♥♥♥ING LAG. ♥♥♥♥ the lag. This game would be 100% more fun if your very life didn't depend on the server's synchronization with your client. 80% of my game deaths have been from a sudden lag surge from 50~ ping to 1000 ping, which occur VERY OFTEN. I really wish they would add in an offline mode or just fix the desynchronization issues, because they REALLY just kill the game after good sessions of wrecking faces in.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16
Path of Exile from Grinding Gear Games (GGG) does offer an complete Free2Play Hack'n'Slay Game that doesn`t have to hide behind Diablo II or even the current Diablo IIIMy first playthrough took me around 38 hours with a Ranger Class. And while I tried to get as deep as I could into the Game and some of it`s skill mechanics it seems that I have so far only seen and understood the tip of the iceberg if it comes to the hole skill-tree stuff in Path of Exile (PoE) or the High-Level End Content..But let`s start at the beginning..The start felt partly rough since storywise if I would compare PoE to Games like Titan Quest, Grim Dawn or Diablo II....PoE missed the chance to have an stronger story-driven entrance over the first chapter. But as soon as I had accepted that and started to look what the Game had otherwise more to offer I came to the conclusion that the Story was just an small part of an bigger picture that was more or less just an layout for everything that might follow afterwards when you are finished with the Game for the first time.Trying to dig myself into the Skill Tree it seem to me that this is actually where POE has it`s biggest strengths if you can accept that the end content of the Game is less story-driven and more about what you do with your skill and character class in the long term.Some might not like that if it comes to PoE but if you are up for some Skill Tree Tweaking and care less about a End Game Story this could be your new homeWatching myself over the last couple of weeks looking more and more about how I would tweak my Ranger differently then I did on my first playthrough so far and where I had done some mistakes became actually an part of the Game on it`s own.Watching countless YouTube PoE Skill Videos, reading Skill Trees Tutorials on the Forum and in the end spending more time outside of the Game then actually InGame made kinda clear to me why so many are willing to buy one of those $400 Supporter Packs of the Game since PoE can really become an huge time sink if you are willing to get the most out of it and are open minded about such a game.Path of Exile makes pretty much everything right if it comes to the F2P Part and as far as I can tell after 38. hours with it the InGame Shop doesn`t offer anything that you must buy to be able to play through the Game.I was honestly suprised when I realized that even with the smaller inventory which was sometimes an issue it still didn`t felt like such an big deal to me that I had to buy the Upgrade on the InGame Store to get myself an bigger Inventory.I knew it was there but in the end I still sold some of the crap that I didn`t needed or wasn`t for my Class before I had even considered using the InGame Story.On the other hand PoE does offer so much in return that I kinda felt bad for not at least buying one of the smaller Supporter PackS ($30/$60) or at lease some of those Account Feature Upgrades. Considering all this and that I had besides only once with the Game technical issues where the latency was really going bad while the rest of the time i had not an single issue with the Game I can`t really say anything bad about the Game at all.Conlusion:Therefore my Rating for Path of Exile from Grinding Gear Games can only point into one direction. Up as high as it can get. Well done GGG!Thumbs Up.That´s it. Thanks for reading and have a great time ;-)

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												I'm nearing 1000 hours on the Steam version and figure I should add my input about the game.  I don't think I can recommend this anymore after the 2.0 patch.Biggest complaints:Game risk/reward does not exist.  They destroyed player defense and offense, increased monster health and damage across the board, and made the high-end maps drop even less.  So you prepare yourself, make the tankiest / decent character you can, roll the hard mods and then what happens?  You get nothing valuable in the entire run, no map to replenish your stock and are worse off than before you started.Trading/economy is awful.  A literal hellhole.  There are players that scam people all day long for currency, work the market, and create monopolies all over the board; essentially, making it impossible for people to advance in the game depending on your build unless you give them all your currency.  Most of the time?  They're AFK!  Feels like a giant troll cesspool.There is no auction place, the trading utilites are limited (like, one or two external sites that require additional external software to run in conjunction with PoE to properly operate)The racing scene feels impossible to get into.  Not a twitch.tv streamer?  Good luck ever winning non-solo events!Gameplay becomes stale.  After you create enough characters, look at enough builds on the forums, theorycraft your own, etc.  You realize something, you do the same thing for every character and only replace a few skills and links appropriately.  You have auto-casted defensive skills, spam one skill and run around while popping potions.  It's boring.  And this feels like the only way to be successful, not die and continue progressing.  And to really try something out of the norm, you better be rich or one of those people creating the monopoly or you'll just get stuck into a loop of poorly performing budget builds.Last point on negatives: build enabling uniques, div cards, etc. are all too rare still.  They added these div cards to increase diversity and make it possible to farm for unique items or otherwise, but it's still useless.  The individual cards are as rare as the item you're trying to find, making them pointless to exist in the first place!  Seemingly zero influence on the economy of items they exist for.After all that, the game does have good points, though.  It was a fun thousand hours for the majority.  It was worth the few hundred I donated to GGG.  I still play because it is still the best ARPG I've found.  If I had the opportunity to not try in the first place, I probably would take it.  It has been a very frustrating run with all the build nerfs, item nerfs, drop rate nerfs, and almost nothing in the opposite direction to make it feel like everything might not be getting worse.  They had a series called "Build of the week" which may as well have been "nerf of the week" since they destroyed any build that appeared in it in the patch following the video release.

Posted: November 18, 2015
												This is a fun Diablo 2 type game, however, every 4-6 months Grinding Gear Games patches the game so utterly that three times in 1.5 years all of my character classes were botched or totally ruined. For those who have played games like these, leveling up is the easy part...buying gear for the class of character is not. So when my 5 characters hit level 90 finally, GGG actually came out with their new Act 4 expansion which completely ruined each one of my characters to such a high degree that I needed to redo their entire play style...which made all that gear I spent months buying obsolete. This is definitely a game to stay away from. So much fun, free, sociable and simple but the absurb time needed for leveling and gear make it impossible to enjoy knowing that all of your hard work and god-seeki-ness will be undone in as small as a 5MB patch that alters the skill nodes!

Posted: May 6, 2014
												Path of Exile is probably the right game for everyone who thought Diablo 3 was dumbed down too much compared to its predecessor; it's definitely the go-to ARPG for hardcore Hack 'n' Slashers with a crazy amount of possibilities when it comes to item & character builds, a huge skill tree, the freedom to combine active skills with an incredible amount of support skills and many exciting unique items that open up entirely new play styles.It may seem a bit overwhelming at first but it's easy enough to figure out all aspects of the game on the go if you played other ARPGs before. The developers try to keep the replay value high with a constant influx of new leagues, events and content updates.Pros:- Free to play- No pay to win- Active community- Devs listen to feedback- Regular content updates and patches- Great depth- Lots of character build optionsCons:- The depth can be overwhelming for new players- Game mechanics might take some time getting used to

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												Grinding Gear Games' game design is quite simple: they made a game they themselves want to play. They tend and nurture it with parental-like care. They experiment, extrapolate, temper, and refine; constantly in pursuit of perfection, while having the humility to realize they will never reach it. Path of Exile is an ever-evolving masterpiece... and GGG gives it to us for free... No pay-gates. No tedious time sinks. Free to play in purity. What's the catch then? How do they make money? Well, I like to think of GGG like that friend who offers to help you move or pick you up from the airport without you having need ask. You can't help but want to reward their generosity by buying them beer or pizza or paying for gas.If you're a gaming enthusiast with any interest in the genre, you owe it to yourself to give Path of Exile a try. You quite literally have nothing to lose.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												As a big fan of Diablo 2's visual presentation coupled with great music and a broody, dark and menacing atmosphere I found myself very dissappointed with Diablo 3. That said I was very relieved when I first played the beta to Path of Exile. Although the beta for POE was not as polished and the gameplay abit clunky compared to D3, when POE launched the final version they did so with "guns ablazing". The final version is slick, fluid and visually pleasing. And with the FF7 inspired "MATERIA" or "GEMS" as POE calls them I  find no reason to return to the D3 debauchery that many of us waited so long for. In the end I give POE an 8\10 only falling short a 9\10 because of how short the game is. But I highly recommend POE to anyone who is a fan of action RPG's and Diablo 2.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Many, many others have already said it, but at risk of sounding like a mindless parrot drone - this game is MUCH closer to what most Diablo fans wanted D3 to be (including myself). I won't necessarily say this game is what Diablo 3 should have been, but it's certainly not difficult for me to imagine that most people would have been much happier if it had turned out exactly like PoE has. As it states in the last bullet point in the "Key Features" section: "You cannot gain gameplay advantage by spending real money in Path of Exile." This alone is such a massive gamechanger, and in a good way. I don't know about you, but I don't particularly tend to enjoy games which incorporate a "pay to win" mentality. Sure it isn't absolutely necessary to shell out any additional cash to be sucessful in D3, but just the fact that it is an option eventually helped drive me and many others away. Also, let's be honest - the loot system in D3 was (and still is) horrendous and only serves to further the agenda of Diablo 3's Real Money Auction House (which they are finally going to do away with early next year along with most likely bettering your chances of finding good gear). Go figure that! Anyway I digress, this isn't about D3. I only mention it because if you intend to play an ARPG on the PC, it's probably going to be one of these two. What you need to know is that PoE offers a truly rewarding and deep experience throughout. Character development boasts outstanding flexibility and viability of unique builds with a complex and rich skill-point system coupled with ability gems that allow you to specifically tailor any class in the game to be played the way you prefer. Of course some work better than others, but that's just how it goes. In summation, whether you are tired of D3 and looking for your ARPG fix elsewhere or just plain want a fun new game to play in this genre, do yourself a favor and click "Play Game." After all, who needs to be convinced by reviews from strangers when you can experience it yourself for free?

												A ranger, a barbarian, and a witch walk into a bar on Wraeclast. They proceed to argue over who would win in a fight.BARTENDER: What'll it be ladies? WITCH: Give me the blood of a newt, the ear of an ox, the tail of a rat, and Grey Goose. SHAKEN NOT STIRRED!BARTENDER: I'm not sure I can...RANGER: I'll take the oil of hyssop, a sprinkling of gypsum, a sprig of rosemary, honey, and gin.BARTENDER: I don't think you quite know what sort of establishment...BARBARIAN: GIVE LONG ISLAND ICE TEA OR I SMASH.RANGER: On second thought, I'll take one of those.WITCH: Yes, me as well.BARTENDER: Three Long Island's coming right up.60 minutes and an unknown quantity of booze later...BARBARIAN: I SMASH, I no care you ladies. I take club and club heads. I GO CLUBBIN' I CLUB ALL NIGHT!RANGER: I think big boy here has been a teeny tiny bit overserved. Ooh a Kitty! Ranger grabs a stray cat hiding under a table in the corner.WITCH: You smash huh? And how would you smash when you are frozen with a flick of my wand? BARBARIAN: I BREAK ICE, I SMASH ICE WITH STRONG MUSCLES, I FLEX, ICE GONE. The ranger returns stroking the cat. It seems resigned to being held.RANGER: Guys, can't we all just love nature? If we spent less time talking about fighting and more time planting trees, think about how much better the world...BARBARIAN: I do love tree. Tree make shade. Tree make fun fort. Tree make good club FOR ME SMASH YOU HEAD!WITCH: Oh silence, silly girl. You environmentalists are so naive. Do you know what I think of naive people? I think they should ripped apart by skeletons while I electrocute them with my wand, which is what I will do to you! Annoying tree hugger, "maybe if we just planted trees..." How about I rain hellfire down from the sky on your precious forest?!RANGER: You take it back. Nobody insults trees.BARBARIAN: YEAH! NO MEAN TREE WORDS OR I....WITCH: Smash? BARBARIAN: NO. I...I...CRUSH!WITCH: Ranger has been teaching you new words again, has she? I'm surprised your brain isn't bleeding with all of that new information.BARBARIAN: I NO UNDERSTAND. WHICH MAKE ME ANGRY. BARTENDER! MORE LONG ISLAND. NOW!RANGER: Listen, Witch. You have five seconds to take back your treesult or I will have kitty here rip out your throat. WITCH: Hahahahaahaahahahaha.....hahaha...hah....hah. That is good. RANGER: OK. You brought this on yourself. KITTY, ATTACK!KITTY: Meow. RANGER: No. Bad Kitty! Kitty attack the mean lady. She hates you!KITTY: MrarwRANGER: KITTY! GO! NOW!WITCH: Hahahaha. AHHHHHH!!!!!RANGER: GOOD KITTY! CLAW HER FACE! YES THE EYES THAT'S IT!BARBARIAN: HA HA. You find funny cat. Witch scream. Me have warm feeling in chest. Me like you ranger. Me no smash.WITCH: PREPARE...TO...DIE...KITTY! With a flick of the wand, the witch sends out a blast that knocks the cat across the room. It jumps up. The witch casts spell after spell, but the kitty dodges and runs out the door. WITCH: INFERNAL FELINE! RANGER: I warned you, witch.WITCH: You've made a huge mistake. YOU SHALL PERISH!BARBARIAN: YOU NO HURT FRIEND! Barbarian clubs the witch with a nearby bar stool. She lands on the floor with a thud.BARBARIAN: I TOLD YOU I GO CLUBBING! I CLUB 'TILL SUNRISE!RANGER: Thanks, buddy. BARBARIAN: We go hug tree. Ranger: Best idea I've heard all day. BARBARIAN: BARTENDER! TWO LONG ISLANDS TO GO. NOW. OR I...PULVERIZE! HAH. ME SMART.  11/10, would Long Island again.Read the Full Review Here[zeemodernnerdblog.wordpress.com]

Posted: April 12, 2015
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

												I truely respect the developers of Path of Exile. Not only have they made an awesome Diablo 2-esque free to play game. But they continue to release new content and even full fledges expansions without asking for a single dime. Not only that, but everything they have available for purchase is completely cosmetic. There is no pay to win mumbo jumbo in this one folks.I have found many hours of enjoyment in this game and highly recommend it to anybody who enjoys top down games like Diablo & Diablo 2. I mean, might as well give it a shot. It's free, and it's fun.I can't really seem to get into the story very well however. My main character is a witch. She was sentenced to death for you know, being a witch. Stealing peoples children and junk. But she escaped I guess and went into exile... Uh.. and now i'm trying to kill this dude that's responsible.. I don't know. All the bosses seem normal-ish at first, but then they turn into giant monsters. I don't really know what they are or what's going on. But the game is fun so I just roll with it. Guess i'll try and pay attention to the dialogue at some point. The story itself just seems sort of boring. Anyway, none of that♥♥♥♥♥♥matters very much. It's a good game, you'll be too busy leveling your character and building it to care about what's going on anyway.Final Verdict: (4.3 out of 5)

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												One of my main problems with the Action RPG genre is that they tend to be repetitive and boring, which is something that Path of Exile managed to surprise me with, especially so when you consider it's Free to Play (and not Pay to Win -all in game purchases are vanity purchases or stash spaces). The game can seem a little overwhelming at first with it's enormous and deeply complex skill tree and its myriad of skills. The combination of the two mean that you can make hundreds, even thousands of different combinations of characters and still find fresh and new builds.The game content (storyline) itself is rather short with it being easily possible to move through the story on all three difficulties within 10-15 hours before reaching the endgame content known as Maps. Maps have endless possibilities and are actually item drops much like weapons and armour which can also be enchanted using the various orbs in the game which also double as the currency as Path of Exile relies on a barter trade system rather than gold which is an interesting solution to the currency sink/inflation balance issue that plagues many games which rely on an economy.Path of Exile also has multiple leagues running at once, there are standard and hardcore leagues which are the life-long leagues which will run till the servers shutdown for the game which have economies that never get reset. Along side the two long running leagues there are 'mutation' 4 month leagues which will add a flavour onto the standard gameplay model and also allow players to start in a fresh economy on a regular basis which gives newer players an equal chance to acquire wealth. Once these leagues come to an end the player's wealth will be moved to the respective parent league (standard/hardcore). Further more Path of Exile also challenges players in short term leagues known as races where players will compete to reach the highest level or the furtherest through the content with different modifiers on each short term race, from turbo enemies, to endless monster farming zones ranging anywhere from 30 minutes to 1 week. Players will earn points during these races which get added up over the course of a race season to earn valuable unique items as rewards.That said, the thing that stopped me from playing the game was issues with ping spikes and lagging out, albeit most likely due to my connection, it seemed to be exacerbated by their lag compensation methods with consant desyncs and disconnects something I rarely suffer from in most other games I've played. That aside I would still strong recommend Path of Exile to anyone even remotely interested in ARPGs or looking for something new to play but don't want to spend much money.-----------------------------------------------------tl;dr-F2P not P2W.-Complex and deep. High replayability-Interesting economy.-Lag/internet issues seem to be more noticeable in this game compared to most other games.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												TL:DR - It's a very fun game and worth your time if you are a fan of point and click ARPGs. There is a lot of build variety and tons of gear to find. MTXs are fair and there are no PTW aspects. Stash tabs are the only thing that offer an advantage but that's mainly to make things easier for trading and hoarding. You can fully enjoy the game with the base 4 tabs if you manage your invetory as all ARPGs require. Avoid if you expect GGG support to help you in any cases where they may have made a mistake. Great game if you plan on playing for free. Start to spend money on it and pray to God that GGG never screws up an order that you made. Any kind of notice about it to them will result in a long and annoying process of proving you never got your goods and that they either never sent it. Any kind of positive resolution in your favor will most likely result in losing your account as was the case with mine. Bought the highest tier supporter pack they had for ascendancy league. Been supporting this game since closed beta (Steam time shows playtime during Perandus League) and when my signed art pack / T-Shirt never arrived in the mail and I only received half of the points I paid for due to some error with the package upgrades, I contacted GGG support. At first they appeared to be aware of the issue and told me to just wait a few days for them to sort it out. Days turned into weeks and after waiting from 3/13/16 to 4/12/16 I contacted them again. Still the deflection of, "We're aware and we apologize. Please give us more time and we will make sure to contact you when your goods have been shipped." I contacted my bank and explained the issue to them. They contacted GGG and GGG never replied. I contacted GGG again letting them know that I didn't want a refund but instead wanted what I paid for. End result, banning my account before a refund was even issued, emails going unanswered, and no shipping information received. So I got my refund and lost 3 years worth of support and effort. The only saving grace is that I managed to get my ascendancy pack refunded in full since terminating my account before any resolution could be reached results in a forfeit of sale.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2013
												Path of Exile > Torchlight 2 & Diablo 3.PoE is quite rare as it's one of the few true free to play games around, yet it offers plenty of content and depth compared to its competition which you have to pay for. Despite this the developers are maintaining a range of dedicated servers so even though you're forced to play online (just like D3), more people are able to have a decent online experience (they're even running an Australian server - something Blizzard has never bothered to do). In terms of visuals PoE might lack some polish, but it's refreshing to see the return of a gritty art style in a dark universe that isn't compromised so that more kiddies are able to play.As it stands PoE is definitely worth a try if you're into dungeon crawlers or just looking for a quick bash at multiplayer with friends.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												An awesome hack & slash game, some say the true Successor of Diablo 2.One of the few f2p games that contains so much content and replayability, it's a wonder it's not a full price retail game.The setting is strongly exotic, New Zealand-like, with many resemblances to Maori culture.The classes are quite definitive, but at the same time the game doesn't throw strict restriction on build paths and it makes for a pretty free selection of roles for your chars.The "talent tree" speaks for itself, the jokes about it's vastness are quite the thing amongst hack and slash gamers, but be advised, they are not that far from the truth.The skill system using gems is nice, fresh touch to the genre, the combat is rewarding, occasionally even challenging.Once you get into the game, the numerous temporary events (races and leagues) add one more unique touch to a game that is pretty innovative, even without them.The optimization is quite sufficient, it ran surprisingly smoothly on a kinda old rig.Definite recommendation to any hack & slash fan, or even to those new to the genre.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This game is alot of fun. I never played diablo 2, but based on all the hype surrounding D3 I bought and played it. I couldnt get into it at all and got bored with it pretty fast. I saw this game got good reviews and was free so figured what the hell. Glad I did because it is great. For one thing, its completly free. No need to buy anything to progress in the game. I love the massive skill tree....it would have been incredible if they had an active skill tree like that as well. But on the flip side you have the skill orbs which adds an amazing amount of depth to the game. The further you go the more cool things you find that allow you to play around with the gem sockets to create some cool power effects. I love having cool spells to cast and the visuals in the game look great. No framerate drops or lagging ever. Beating up on bad guys never gets old and finding those rare peices of loot is always a joy. I have no idea what the story is about and dont really care. I just want to level up and expand on that massive skill tree while creating some killer gear. Highly recommend giving this game a look. You cant go wrong with free. This game could easily get retail value if they wanted. The folks at GGG should be commended for their efforts. Just a fantastic game.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Path of exile Developer: Grinding Gear Games (GGG)Grade 9/10Review updated 3.11.2015 to take into account recent patches and expansionsFirst short review for those too well accustomed to modern hectic society:  Great game, although not flawless. Most importantly Path of exile is one of the most fair free to play games available.  As such there really is no good reason to not to try it.Good/bad:+ One of the most fair free to play games + Gameplay+ Variety of viable character builds+ Graphics+ Economy (from stability point of view)- Legacy items- More content would be appreciated (more coming but slowly)- Trading is difficultFull review:Before going to actual gameplay I want to emphasize the fact how fair this game is for a free to play game. Usually free to play games are more or less pay to win games but Path of exile is almost complete exception to this. Only pay to win feature of Path of exile is that with real money player can buy more stash tabs to which store stuff that can be shared by player’s characters in the same league.The extra stash tabs naturally do give minor advantage but this really starts to have an effect only when the player has played the game for hundreds of hours.  Thus the money grabbing is aimed at those players who already have played and enjoyed the game a lot and thus one could claim that these players ought to pay a little to support such an enjoyable game. Even then the payment is one time as those bought tabs are permanent. Most importantly however the extra stash tabs are definitely not mandatory even after hundreds of hours of gameplay. Next to the game itself. I am not expert when it comes to Action RPG games. As a prime example I never played Diablo 2 for which many people claim Path of exile to be better successor than Diablo 3 (which I haven’t played either). I would however claim Path of exile to be very good game. The main reason for this is the gameplay itself. It feels satiffying and the enemies are difficult but not too impossible. With many different viable builds in the game (more on this on nextt paragraph) can be replayed many times with different experience. with different characters (more on this later. As free game, you can easily go and verify this if you don't believe me.Another good thing is the skill tree, which is identical for all the classes. (classes only have different starting positions in the tree). This allows creating very interesting builds for your characters and actually surprisingly many of them are viable. With viable I mean reaching the end game. Naturally the amount of end game builds is bit smaller but even it is surprisingly large (especially according to what I have heard to be the case in other action RPG games. The different builds also seem to relatively balanced except temporary anomalies created by game updates. These are fixed usually sooner or later.Graphics are great which is always nice. The minimum graphical settings in this game are however quite high so low end PC owners may be in need of upgrade for playing this game (but as free game, try before upgrading)As he last notable good thing (writing more would make this review way too long) I am going to mention economy. All I can personally say is that it seems to work. Why this is important is that I have heard that in many other RPG games the economy does not work but instead for example the inflation of prices becomes ridiculous and starts to affect the game negatively.<The complaints about desynchronisation were here. Now GGG has finally introduced lockstep mode --> By default hit and movement detection works now like in MOBA's and RTS games, which is much much better than the original implementation. Desycnhronization issues are now problem only for those living really far from servers>The main flaw of the game is legacy items in permanent leagues. Legacy items are items that are no longer obtainable other than by trading from other players who already own them (with extremely high price of course). Unfortunately most of the legacy items were created by weakening the normally obtainable versions of these items. As result people who have these legacy versions are in practice equipped with items that are too powerful (balance wise) and obtaining these items is difficult for new players.Legacy items are not a problem in temporary leagues but some people like myself who would like to play in permanent leagues are forced to choose between two bad options: living with legacy items or playing temporary leagues.Second problem of Path of exile is lack story content. At the time of writing this the game has 4 chapters, which player has to pass in three difficulties before the "end game". More acts are coming but the progress is painfully slow. It should be noted that the end game is well done and that lessens this problem. When 5th chapter comes I will consider the amount of content acceptable. Third problem is that trading is impractical. The intended way to sell or buy items happens through trade chat, which is horribly flooded and yet very likely the people who would be willing to sell or buy what you want are not there when you are. There however are for example third party websites for listing items which helps a lot but GGG should really do something to fix this in-game.To summarize. The game definitely has some flaws but the good sides very clearly overcome these problems. As a very fair free to play game there is therefore no reason for not trying this game.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Let me start off by saying this is a fantastic ARPG.  I love the classes, the items, the spells, the customization with the passive skill tree, the viability of many builds.  I love this game.  But this game suffers from a fundamental, glaring, insulting and infuriating flaw (well, flaws, but more about that later).It desyncs constantly.  This may not be a big deal in early levels when mobs are fairly easy and the named/elite champs you fight aren't rocking proximity shields and damage reflection.  But when you're 60+, dealing with a room full of mobs that can literally 2-shot you if they get too close, it's borderline unplayable.  The difficulty factor would be perfect (probably a little too easy for archers) if it wasn't for these sneaky ninja-mobs that just show up and beat the living hell out of you.Another flaw (imo) is the gem system.  In games like Diablo, gems/runes are used to augment abilities or add buffs/bonuses.  In PoE, however, gems are both your skills and your buffs/augments.  On my 61 Ranger I have maybe 13 gems, 6 of which are skills and 3 of which are buffs.  That leaves me with 4 or 5 support gems, not a big deal.  The problem is that in order to upgrade a piece of equipment, I have to find one that is an ilvl upgrade, has a specific number of sockets in specific colors and in a specifically-linked configuration, is a rare or better, and has to have good modifiers.  The alternative is finding a random piece of equipment and burning mats to change the number/color/linkage/quality/attributes/bonuses.  This makes the game feel like a grind-fest.   And even then, I'd forgive this aspect if I didn't constantly desync.I want to love this game.  I've spent quite a lot of time playing, but I simply cannot play it anymore.  The desync issue is out of control, and absolutely breaks this game.

For example after finishing the single-player I asked on chat "How do I join pvp now, as there is no tutorial about it or anything." As response I was attacked by 20 people calling me troll and idiot. Not even single person with positive attitude! - Super slow loading time, even on machine with 32GB of RAM. Just bad design.- too much "rare" items dropping, to the point where your inventory is full every 5 minutes seconds with rare and magical items- Very bad story telling, ruining the storyline.- Forced restarts of map every few minutes, which is super frustrating when you are in city and want to take 10 minute brake and sell the items. When you come back - your previously cleared  map is  restarted and replaced with other, making the progress in the game very slow, as you will be forced to re-do the same maps over and over if you dare to take 10 minute brake or got disconnection...Conclusion:Nice Diablo 2 style game, very playable, but ruined by bad storyline and shockingly rude and immature community. 5/10

content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
												Possibly a best Hack and Slash Action RPG game that is free to play without any pay to win things.I have logged lots of hours, played it religiously I am well aware of it's pros and cons without being biased like many of the fans are. I still do believe this game is how Diablo 3 should have been.But it still has few problems and is far from perfection.Game play 7/10-----------------------+ Decision makings are important and need to research a lot about the game+ Skill tree makes you think a lot.+ Orb Trading system+ Variety of skill gems + Free to play+ No pay to win (except stash tabs)-  Legacy items-  Bad economy in permanent leagues-  Balance changes that may destroy your builds.-  Desync related problems that may get fixed later.-  Map system that is too RNG based.-  Frequent Nerfs and balance changes- Act 4 requires reflexes and some mechanics that are unfriendly to newbies.- Overtuned mobs and survivability is more important than Damage to level up or stay in HC ladder. Graphis 7/10------------+ Dark and Gloomy atmosphere for mature players.+ Realistic and not cartoony Graphics like TL2 or Diablo 3.-  Arrows on rocks and do not disappear.- Monsters stay on ground causing clutter.Story 9/10---------------+A story that reminds you of relationship between England and Australia, where protagonist is exiled into a fearsome island named, Wreclast.+Story is still being worked on, but really need to think and read everything in order to understand what is going on with the history of the island.+Dependent on flavor texsts of unique items, npcs, and objects in level, it's more of a game where you have to pick up clues and solve the puzzle.+Dark fantasyOverall its a great game, but you may want to think about builds (if devs like it or not and pay lots of attention to patch notes if you are concerned about nerfs).For a bonus.PoE in Nutshell for pre-2.0---------------------------------------lvl 1-60= build check lvl 60-80= gear check lvl 80-90= luck check lvl 90-100= patience checkPot in Nutshell of 2.0-------------------------------Act 1- Act 3= ez modeAct 4= Farming barrier until next difficulty.GLHF.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												This game in a nutshell: Great game, but....It is what Diablo 3 should be, but has the biggest problem of Diablo 3 at release you always need to be connected. That is already a problem itself, but the game has a HUGE problem of desync. You can't move when you are surrounded by mobs or you may risk a desync. You can't use movement skills when near corners or you may risk a desync. That gets really annoying and completely remove some possible builds of the game. Why? You can't go glass cannon and rely in your skill to stay alive when the server can just say it didn't like what you were doing and throw you back 2 secs in the past, a place that now is surrounded by enemies.There's no "class". Every character can use all items and skills in the game. In fact skills are actual gems, that you equip in items. Nice idea... but the characters lose identity. Instead of picking the character they should allow you to make your own customization.And what is worse.The game has a clean HUD, BUT it has 0 notification. miss, damage taken, damage done or whatever. You have 0 notifications if your character that is swinging the weapon in the air is missing, got desynced or is just out of range.For what i googled people were complaining since release but the devs want to keep the game "clean". Instead of allowing the player to turn notification on and off, they play the game "daddy know better" and make a game with alot of potential into something that you end with mixed feelings about.TL:DR The game is good, but there's issues that will make you made. At lower difficulties you will not notice, but later on you will feel and hate it, ALOT.Edit: I forgot a important point.Back into the "no class" thing. While it looks nice and all, it kills melee characters. Why? Ranged characters can have the same armor, life, evasion and damage that you while being ranged, there's no mechanic that a melee character can do that one ranged can't do. Add that with Monsters that have skills that kite, blind, freeze, release cloud of poison/fire/ice/lightning or even, in most of the bosses, oneshot your character there's NO reason to play a melee character unless you want to prove something. And i'm serious. Playing melee is at least 3x harder than a ranged character.And again the devs play the "daddy know better" game.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												500 hours in and no end in sight, speaks for itself. If you like ARPG, Path of Exile is the must play to end all must plays.ProsEconomic design is intricate and thrivingSkill and character progression has depth beyond measureArt, sound, and animation is beautifulCustomizable player housingPerfect league and ladder designFrequent large content updatesTrue free to play, no pay walls periodConsMy singular issue with the game is how anticheat is handled. The methods used are extremely overbearing. All actions are controlled by a prediction system at the server level, and it is frequently confused. The result feels like lag but is actually the server forcing erronious corrections on your client. This has a large negative impact on the game.Overall, 9/10. If they rethought and redesigned their anticheat system it would be 11/10.Version 2.0 Edit:Thought I'd update this and say they have now greatly improved, if not entirely fixed my concerns with the predictive server syncing. They've improved this from a few different angles. Firstly they've diversified their datacenter locations so you're much more likely to be on a low latency server. Secondly they've added a new primary data sync mode called lockstep which does not desync but only works well on low latency connections. Thirdly they've improved the overall responsiveness and accuracy of the predictive sync mode for high latency players. I was not the only one who felt the old predictive mode stifled this game's quality feel. They've heard our concerns and went to incredible lengths to do right for us. Game is now a serious, solid 11/10.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
The real sequel to Diablo 2.Diablo was fun. Diablo 2 was amazing, years past it's prime. Median mod brought life back to it as it aged. Diablo 3 was announced and everyone celebrated but as more and more came out about it gamer's hopes were dashed. All the brilliance that Blizzard North had created in the franchise, the things that made Diablo what it was, left the company with the people who originally made it. Thanks to some active, gamer-friendly, chatty developers in New Zealand, Path of Exile is as close as what would have been as crowdfunding and copyrights allow.Pros: Free to play, reasonable system requirements, Diablo 3, wonderous innovations to the genre, very deep, infinite endgame, friendly chat-available developers, great events and leagues.Cons: No classic Diablo story or characters, no offline/LAN play, complex trading economy, higher learning curve than more popular titles. No full tutorial.Other: BRUTAL sometimes offensive and very "mature" community in chat. Not a game, nor community for children or people with delicate sensibilities. Remember classic Battle.net? It's like that but ruder and smarter. I entirely prefer the "free speech" approach but some, maybe most, may not.I don't think there's anything Diablo 3 got right that Path of Exile got wrong. The only issue I personally have with the game is the complexity of attempting to trade for gear and currency items that I need. WHEN you play the game, make sure to pay close attention to what little instructional help it provides, because you don't get much.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Henk Lostsword isn't your average exile.  He's on a path.  Is he on a path of good or of bad?  Well, that's up to you.It's easy to criticize this game for what it is not.  It's not Diablo, despite what others may tell you, and the differences can be a letdown to some.  It's not a first-person shooter, nor is it a side-scrolling beat 'em up.  It's not particularly novel in its handling of top down, hack-slash-and-loot gameplay.  It's not an episode of "Cheers" re-recorded on VHS with a two minute portion of "Scarecrow and Mrs. King" still left at the beginning that you have to wait through.  It's not a warm buttered scone on a Tuesday morning.  What the game is, is a solid beefsome electronic hoppy experience with a bold hearty finish and a wide variety of gameplay options to delight gamers of any age group or gender identity.You play as one of two types of mystical beings from the Immortal Cube, a land beyond time and space where immaterial aberrations sleep until it is their time to manifest as Daemons in the mortal realm.  One playable Daemon type is the Whiteshadow, who benefits from high Space and low Time; a natural healer and tank, who pulls damage and watches over the party's HP during critical combat encounters.  The other playable Dragoon is Melissa: She's a hacker from a near-future Australia, during a cyberwar that threatens to destroy both Western and Asian infrastructure.  Exiled from her home country as the world is divided into two key factions, she takes refuge on a series of interconnected rogue naval vessels in international waters and plans her digital assault from her "pirate flotilla".So here's the deal: Each piece of equipment that the party obtains has "battle magic slots", refered to in the game's media as BMS.  Each BMS lets you assign a new battle magic to your mech.  Some of the slots are linked together, allowing for Fusion Magic and other neat ways to upgrade your Core Stats.  Coming up with creative ways to augment and empower your spells is critical to your success, as the game's many different challenges diminish the successes of raw number stacking.  Adaptation Gems, when slotted in the correct gear, can make this task easier, by automatically mutating your battle magic to the necessary Color that will deal the most damage.  I had the most fun using Adaptation Gems and series of low level Fusions, linked together so I didn't have to worry about picking which magic to use.  This allowed me to focus on the dodge and roll techniques crucial to the game's action.  But there's definitely a play style for the calculating tacticians, too, where deliberate decision-making and pre-battle planning can give your mech an unbeatable advantage.Get this♥♥♥♥♥♥The game's level pacing is excellent.  Every fifteen to thirty minutes of gameplay, you increase in level and get to add a new Spirit Sphere to your Mana Web.  Every four of those causes one of your Core Stats to increment, allowing you to hold a new piece of gear associated with that stat.  What starts as a simple game becomes intriguingly complex after just a few hours of gameplay, and those decisions are neatly folded into your gameplay before other considerations arise later on.  But if you make a bad choice early on, don't fret!  Take-Em-Bax, a special Game Token provided in the in-game store, allows you to reassign any one skill that you regret assigning.  Take-Em-Bax cost a mere $0.75 per skill, allowing you to build a fresh new character at level 100 for about $8.  The cosmetics available in the store, however, have price tags that are a little too lofty for my liking.  You Rockafellers out there may disagree.The hacking minigame still needs work, as does the lockpicking drudgery (I found myself using triangle to "skip action sequence" at least five separate times), but the other aspects of gameplay fall neatly into place without disrupting the continuous "movie-like" quality of the game.  While not the most visually-stunning game of 2014, it has the best audio by far and has committed much of its budget to its all-star cast, including Joan Jett voicing one of the game's more memorable NPCs.All things considered, I give this game 500 value points for art, 800 for gameplay, and another 150 bonus, and 15 points.  Pick this game up if you have some wealth, ♥♥♥♥o.  If not, why not get paid already?  People respect you and they respect your talents.  Just apply what you do here to your career, to your family, to everything you do.  You are important.  But you sell yourself short too often--we all see it.How do you know they won't hire you if you don't try?  Just put out the application and say "♥♥♥♥ it" if it doesn't pan out.  You do this five or ten times, you're getting hired somewhere.  No one lands that dream job first thing.  The baby boomer's ideal of the American dream is over.  Jobs are scarce, so learn to make your goals a little more realistic.  Start reasonable and work your way up.  Before you know it, you've got $30 in your pocket--and that's enough to get started on your very own Pathof Exile.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												I've been playing this for over 3,000 hours, and I don't think I'll stop anytime soon. Sure, I might take a break to play something else, but Path of Exile has a way of drawing me back in. This is the best of free to play, in that everything you can buy is purely cosmetic (with the exception of extra stash tabs and character slots, but I've yet to hit the default character limit of 24). Having played Diablo 2, years ago, and having gotten tired of a game that I enjoyed being neglected by its developer, Path of Exile makes me happy in ways that game never did, with constant updates, fixes, and new content that continually expand the game and make it feel like there's always something new to try.I won't lie - the learning curve can be steep, and your first character or two will ultimately be ill equipped to handle the highest difficulty level, e.g. the third play through at high level. That's when you have to look up build guides on the forums, for tested builds that can survive the punishment that is Merciless difficulty and thrive. The passive skill tree is enormous and sprawling, and takes time to memorize and navigate, and many mechanics can be confusing until later on.All that said, when you start to get the hang of it, and you've conquered the basics, a whole new level of possibilities open up. It's hard to describe, but I'd like it to learning to ride a bike - once you get the basics, you can experiment with the more advanced stuff.Lastly, the developers are really good at replying to questions and suggestions, whether it's by email or on their forums. I have yet to play another game with this level of support.All in all, this is my favourite ARPG, and will likely remain so for years to come.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Path of Exile is a great diablo style RPG to play for a variety of reasons.First of all it's free but even if it wasn't i'd still recommend it, second of all it adds enough interesting and unique gameplay mechanics that helps seperate itself from all the other action RPG's while still keeping that familiar style intact.The first of these is the new healing system, instead of collecting dozens of potions you now only have 3-5 flasks that you fill up by killing enemies, meaning that you never run out of healing items as long as you have monsters to kill.I feel that this helps the flow of the game a lot better than the usual potion system and it's a very welcome addition.Next up is the new currency system, instead of collecting gold you collect scrolls and orbs that you earn from quest rewards and pick up as loot, this means that you can buy most items for only a few scrolls (Orbs on later levels) instead of lots of gold so you usually always have enough to buy what you want which is another nice addition.Finally theres the gem system, all spells and magical abilities are now the gems that you equip on your armour, this means that they are now integral to gameplay as they also level up through usage, you can also create cool combinations through the gem links.I'm also a big fan of the dark graphic style the game utilizes and the voice acting is proffessional enough so as not to sound cheesy.All that along with great music and plenty of interesting areas to explore/monsters to kill that i'd recommend this to anyone that likes Action RPG's.

												One of the greatest concepts ever. The highly customizable builds makes this game sometimes a bit too much enjoyable actually, beside the fact the desync is a thing since release. Desync is really a thing you need to admit to at this game and if you can't you'll end up ragequitting anyways. Had the most fun I've ever had in a game with a build (Facebreaker Cyclone) which actually 'caused desync quite a bit and it didn't irritated me at all to be honest. The gem system is really worked out well and the replay value of endgame is amazingly high. Don't expect to see other mobs or other maps a lot, but expect to see dangerous and deadly combinations of these two a lot if you wan't to risk it! You need to make this game enjoyable yourself by asking help of others as well, the game is kind of hard to get into but once you're in it's hard to get out. This game is one of the definitions of addiction and dedication but it's totally worth it. I would highly recommend to start the game in a heroic league, the best way to learn is failing in this game!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Excellent game with zero pay to win, and a playerbase comprised of cancerous bootlickers. Too bad, the game had so much to offer.If you play this game entirely solo, you will not be able to advance on the hardest difficulty since you have to trade with players to get the best gear using the game's flawed bartering system. And since the playerbase is a huge mass of elitists the higher up and further you progress, the more cancer you will have to deal with.Upvote for anything before the midgame, downvote for anything afterwards, downvote overall since the game's design encourages this kind of interaction.Edit: One other thing. The game has the biggest skill system of all time. It's massive, and it's fun to experiment with. However, there is no way to full reset your entire skill tree, other than by getting extremely rare orbs that only remove a single skill selection that you recently picked at a time. Given how massive the tree is, this means if you plot out a massive map of where all your skills go, but you later find out your plot had a poor selection anywhere near the beginning, you have essentially no way to undo all the way back to the mistake and fix it. Furthermore, if you get bored of one particularly long line of skill progression, you have almost no way to undo back to the beginning and reset your entire tree and re-allocate it.For many in the cancerous community, this is just great! They have no lives and are willing to spend 60 hours getting to max level and then restarting a whole new character just to try out an alternate build. For people like me with a job, this means you will either be perpetually stuck in the first 30-60ish levels of a character build as you reset a whole new character to try a new skill build, or you can only play one character for 85 hours before finding out all your effort was wasted and your character sucks.If Diablo 3 can have a way smaller skill system with the ability to full reset a character, so can this game. I am not buying the playerbase's excuses for the devs reasoning for intentionally leaving this out.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Path of Exile is a Hack and Slash game, It's F2P and you basically get an full game for no price at all. You can however spend some money to get some Pay 2 look damn good effects. What they offer is:  New Helmet models, Alternative Spell effects, small and cute pets and finally of what i know there are several kinds of Wing effects. Anyways, to the basic works and system of the game. The game is built on a Leveling system that gives your character one Passive skill point per level to put in an gigantic skill tree.  Wanna know how big this skill tree is?  It's makes the FFXII licence board look like a little plate of NOTHING. You got so many option on this tree, you could create a Witch that hacks people with axes and swords. Or an big, strong and scary marauder that walk around casting fireballs with a wand that's only the size of his fingers. That is what makes this game so awesome, you can do whatever you want.  Want a fire casting and teleporting necromancer that has an army of dead at his command? Go for it, works just fine. And never forget to ask in the general chat for advice... Though sometimes you can get some.. odd answers. I won't say to much, cuz that's not how i do. Know this.. The game might be slow in the beginning, but when you reach the mid to higher levels... This turn into a crash fest of chopping, freezing, burning and exploding every foul dark creatures that stand in your way. But never let your guard down... Anything can kill you if you're not carefull.*Edit: They also gradually add more content to the game, Skills, areas, expansions, visual effects etc.All i gotta say is i really think this game is awesome and that it's totally free, yet It's got better quality gameplay than most games that cost over 20 Euro to play.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												This game is irritatingly addictive.  I spent the weekend I got it playing it, instead of doing work I had intended to do.This is an ARPG, and as such, there's not a whole lot of innovation when it comes to the actualy gameplay.  Overhead view, point a spam your mousebutton, pick up loot.  This isn't to say it doesn't do this well, as I found the experience to be enjoyable.  Intuitive controls, good challenge level (i.e., I'm not throwing my mouse in frustration of how hard it is, but I do sometimes have to think tactically, and retreat to defeat the horde against me).Where this game earns its points is in its passive skill tree, it's gem-based skills (think materia from FFVII), and its in-game economy.The passive skill tree can be a little overwhelming at first, since there is a LOT.  Once you spend a little time perusing it, and understanding how it works, it can start to seem kind of dull (how many times can you get a +10 to dex before you're looking for a little more, though there are other nodes to work with!).  Then, it hits you.  I can completely customize this character, and how it plays.  Want to be a duel-weilding lighning specialist?  Can do.  Fire-based summoner?  Alright, we can do that.  Want to just TANK with a really big axe?  We can do that, too.  The possibilities for different builds are bountiful.Combine the skill tree with experience-gaining leveling skill orbs that can be socketed into items, and you have a great combination for customization.The economy is another place where the devs took a different route than many others.  Money doesn't exist in this game.  Instead, you have barter system.  Normal items give you pieces of Wisdom scrolls (read: identify item), which eventually form into a whole scroll.  Whole scrolls also drop as loot, so this isn't your only means of ID'g an item.  Magical itmes might be worth augmentation shards, or transmutation shards, or other items.  While there is a formula to what the vendors give in exchange for what, it does teach you to think about loot grabs differently than other games.  In Diablo, or Torchlight for example, eventually normal items got left behind for magical, and even those eventaully weren't worth the inventory space.  In PoE, every item gets looked at individually.  Are you in need of ID scrolls?  Start picking up low-space normals.  Are you looking for a specific socket pattern for a weapon you want to try to craft?  Each item could be that thing you want!  Even that normal sword that, in other ARPGs would get left behind!  I personally found this to be a refreshing change of pace.Even the meta-economy gets a little more interesting with no money.  What exactly is that unique piece of armor worth to you?The best part of this game is its price.  Free.  And actually FREE.  Not, "free to sign up, but in order to beat this boss you need to spend $5 to get this one item you will only use once."  GGG has made a commitment to makig this game truly free.  While there are microtransactions available, they are purely cosmetic, offer no advantage, and are completely voluntary.  I am more likely to spend money on these, because they aren't forced on me, than I am any "need to buy to progress" stuff.  If you are enjoying the game, I suggest grabbing some of this as it helps the devs continue to make great games, and you get nifty effects for your character (like flaming footprints, or glowing blue weapons!) I haven't done any parties or PvP yet, so I can't comment on those mechanics, but I plan to check those out a little more as the time goes on.So far, great game.  The first expansion is being released in a few days from this review, and I can't wait to see what these guys come up with!

content:
Posted: January 7
												This game is a bit of an oddity... when you begin to play, the content and possibilities are so far beyond comprehension. So you will basically create couple (2 - 5) characters that are completely unplayable because you don't know what you're doing. Eventually you get the idea behind creating characters that should be viable, and then create a couple (2-5) characters that are viable until the late stages of the game and only then become unviable to play... Eventually you get frustrated and go see a tutorial and realize none of your characters actually had any potential because you weren't familiar with aspects such as douple dipping, defences and minmaxing one aspect of the game to its fullest potential. Then you create a recommended character, grind and farm for weeks and then you realize that the freedom you originally thought you had in creating characters was lost somewhere. Having played ~1300 hours of this, I still don't know how to make unique characters that can finish the entire game - that said, maybe I am just a slow learner. Perhaps the next ~1300 hours are the key of understanding...

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												The core game is pretty good with lots of character diversity and future potential, however the end game is currently rather lack luster having a high barrier to entry putting you largely at the mercy of the gods of RNG, who are never kind. This game suffers from some of the worst RNG issues i've ever seen, and generally is designed to cater to the super hardcore element. The cosmetic microtransactions which fund the game are extremely expensive however there is no pay to win, unless you count buying extra stash space which to be honest is kind of necessary for any serious player; expect to dump $50-$100 on stash tabs if you get sucked into this game just to have room for your basic needs. The amount of storage space you get for free is rather pitiful; my advice is to wait for a stash tab bundle sale as they seem to happen on average once a month. The biggest thing holding this game back is the antiquated trade system. Because of the bad RNG issue the only way to truely progress into end game is to trade for the things you need, if you try and play only self found you will get no where in end game very slowly. The developer promissed a robust trade system through their website back in beta but have so far failed to deliver and don't seem to have it as a development priority; the game suffers immensely because of this.I'd recommend POE If you were a fan of diablo 2 and thought diablo 3 was terrible, you will probably enjoy this game. If you are the kind of person who can't handle complex character development then you will definately hate this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Great game, and completely free to boot.  If you love the Diablo game but weren't crazy about Diablo 3, I'd highly recommend checking this game out if you haven't already. Pros- The amount of customization and ways you can tweak your powers are limitless.  Whole builds can be made around single unique items that change your powers in interesting ways.- Solid story and interesting world.- Uses FF7 Materia system for powers- Has really solid hardcore play for those who hate themselves (me)- Powers fit the mood, no sparkly effect or silly sounds.- Free!- Purchase amounts are fair and are usable/tradable between characters.Cons- Skill tree can be off-putting for new players, you may have to look up some builds on the internet- Actual gameplay can get repetative after a while, most of the fun is in building cool characters and trying to survive- Bosses can be ruthless if you're not prepared, you can be easily carving your way through minions then get 1 shot by a unique boss (build defense and offense)Overall I'd say the game's greatest asset is how much customization you can do in building and leveling characters.  The game's biggest flaw is easily the steep learning curve that newer players will face.  But if you stick with the game and do some research, Path of Exile offers hours of gameplay as you try to build an effective and interesting character.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Path of Exile is actually one of the BEST MMOs I've ever played. The combat itself isn't really different from any other MMORPG's, but the gem system and how they give you skills is definitely pretty unique. You aren't bombarded by microtransactions, if at all, and I like how it works on an instance system.So far the game hasn't been overly hard, but I've died here and there. There are a few especially hard parts that I really liked, like the final boss of Act 1.The community is definitely a big part of the game. Most people in chat are kind enough to give new players help, and having the trade chat helps people trade stuff for other stuff.What I really love is the flexibility of each character, due to the passive skills. It's totally viable to make your duelist magic-focused, ranged, or even all-around. Graphics-wise, the game looks pretty great. The places in game are beautiful, especially the forest areas in Act 2 and the town in Act 3. It's also pretty aesthetically pleasing, and has a nice vibrant mood to it.The only complaints I have are how long it takes for the game to load up sometimes, but that's probably because of my mediocre laptop. The story is a little negligible and none of the NPCs so far have really been memorable, but they're nice to have around anyways.Overall, yes, you should try this game. It's free to play, so you've got nothing to lose by at least trying it out, but if you like other games like Torchlight or Diablo, then you'll definitely like this game too.
