number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												I am old as dirt, have played this game 4k+ hrs. It still fells new with every new char, every new challenge league. Our guild now has 28 members, spread over the whole world (of which I am the humble leader). Play it with friends, new or old, preferably over Skype or Teamspeak.Join a guild if your old friends don't get it, or make your own guild and invite people you find nice in the game.  The community is mostly very nice. Immature (not young-age has nothing to do with it) or cocky players tend to quit, cause the learning treshold is quite high. Be nice ingame, and you will get all the help you need. Global chat can be a way to meet other players (or get trolled if you are unlucky), or just throw in some questions if you trade.To summarise: PoE is a game that never gets old. Frustrating as hell sometimes, for sure, but never boring.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												This game is awesome.I played Diablo II religiously for a little over a decade (a few breaks here and there..) but I had to quit after bots just COMPLETELY INFESTED Battlenet. I bought Diablo III and wish I didn't spend $60 on it ...I will never play it again. I thought my days of playing Action RPGs were over ......until I found Path Of Exile. Its like the ......spiritual successor to Diablo2 but with enough twists and a few drastic differences (THE SKILL TREE) to keep me hooked. The icing on the cake is that this game is FREE. LOVE IT.Regardless, I highly recommend this game if you are into ARPGs, like Torchlight..or if you are a fan of classic Diablo games. It takes a little bit of time to get used to how the "currency"/skill tree/item socket systems work but once you get the hang of it ...you'll see the genius behind it. I just dont have enough time to play this game ...or any of my games for that matter D:9/10

												Up to Act 2, this game is really awesome. Even tho I'm not an hardcore fan of genre I still did like it. Hardness added as you progress is really amazing as well, every enemy has interesting mechanic that will make you think if you don't want to die. This also doesn't mind the levels. If your stats are bad or you try to rush in group of them, you will find yourself dying even if you are couple of levels above the enemy. That's amazing but even more awesome is talent tree that is realy huge. I don't know will I be able to reset those later (there is refund for couple) but I'm quite sure I wont make the best out of it in my first play through. Sure, there is room for some improvements that will make gameplay experience even better, but this game is really alright and it managed to leave good impression on me.

												A diablo clone that has done a good job of keeping all the goods things and avoiding all the bad things. You will still be excited to find rare items, but given a lot of flexibility to change them. THe skill tree is large, but likely only portions of the grid work for certain characters. There is some room to take back skill points and add them elsewhere. Gems and sockets are a nice touch on how they can be combined and work together. The game revolves partly around crafting, but its not clunky like many games make it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2013
												After not enjoying the Closed Beta and early Open Beta (after climbing to level 36, and 29 in each) I decided that the game was sluggish and "Not For Me" while admiring the dark Diablo 1 and Diablo 2 style Art Design and attempted feel, along with the best ARPG graphic engine and shadows to be displayed in a ARPG title yet.Luckily GGC has been able to pull off an amazing development cycle since that point, I read up on it finally being released after 7 years &decided to give it another shot! I am glad I did, as all issues I had with the game are not only fixed, but changed in a way that feels perfect in all aspects - I do not see any area that they could have improved on further from the point I started playing at to the release; with that in mind some of these aspeccts and more will be altered further making the title even better. After only 22 levels as a Shadow going for a unique twist on the Dual Spike Armor/HP/Regen/HealthMana Leeching builds out there (I allocated 75 points that I thought seemed perfect; 85  "In case I grind that much out" 100 as "Pipe Dream Build" The developers stated that Magic The Gathering was the main inspiration for the Skill Web allowing any class to "Break the Rules" tactically and come up with their own vision of a build that developers may not have assumed would "Work" as cited by GGC for MTG how endless players such as I made decks in the standard rotation that nobody thought of doing as it seemed unconventional; every tournament and magic event I went to with my most recent deck right prior to Theros being released shook my hand even if I took the loss of the set stating "Thats the most interesting" or "That is one of the most amazing decks I've seen" "or Played against" - Nothing feels better than building ideas on your own with a vision of HOW it should be executed.PoE allows this My shadow is going to turn many heads and just as I "Broke" the way "WoW's Burning Crusade" end game worked (as stated by Mod on a Forum Post) by allocating a skill tree never displayed prior online (or until 3-4 months of using it, then I personally posted it so other Hunters could try it) along with a Mixture of PVP Arena Gear and Raid gear to keep the #1 DPS spot in Raids; while without switching abilities or gear be top of any battleground Leaderboard with (for example 24 Kills, 11 assists and 3 deaths.) - With that mindset...PoE allows you to not have to depend on just gear or just a build ; aside from the endless web of skills and attribute boosts that makes FFX look like Diablo 3 in "Scope, Scale and Staggering Size" The gems being socketed into gear that you alter with interconnecting slots to have multiple abilities chained with multiple support (such as three elements per Double Strike or Multi-strike with a Crit Damage Support Gem alongside the Double Strike (depending on how the sockets are connected)  New Players will feel at home but may need to check how the skill trees differentiate or do not differentiate each class. Along with how a Common item drop may end up being one of the most devestating pieces of gear you find depending on how you alter it after using an unhealthy amount of Armor or Weapon Quality Upgrades; which then allows the Gem Socket change gem to have higher % chance of adding more sockets (I was able to get a 5 socketed claw at level 22 due to this method upgraded to yellow; with stats that are mind blowing). It shows that the user is really in control.I cannot reccommend this game enough giving it an honest solid 9.1/10 *my rating scale is very very "this game needs to be perfect to be perfect* as seeon my IGN profile reviews for each title I own. - I deducted .1 points due to a rather insane 9 dollars per card drop for steam cards or else it would be a 9.2; if it was 9 dollars to initiate all card drops the score would remain the same.That's a solid 9.1/10 PLAY IT. NOW.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												When it comes to Arps it doesn't get much better than this.  I have tried many games since POE was first released on steam and I keep coming back to it.  It's fun, addictive, and the sheer amount of customization you can do to your character is impressive. (Not just visually, but in the way your character plays, abilities and such)  Honestly, it's better than alot of games I have spent 60 dollars on a piece over the years, and it is completely free.  If you can play through the whole game once without putting any money in (completely doable,  all monetary transactions are cosmetic) and not feel at least a little guilty, there's something wrong with you.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2013
												I did once a review of this game, but I have played much more since then and I feel that I have to change that review.Is a "Diablo style" game, so you don´t need to read more if you did not like at all Diablo. Is nicely done. The graphics are ok, and there is a huge variety of possiblilities about leveling your character. So many that you can experiment and replay the game many times with differents characters and differents skills. That was one of the reasons why I expent more than 230 hours playing. The other reason, a feature called "Hardcore leagues". When you create a new character you can select this league. Is a permanent death style and I love that. I played Diablo that way and I know that is just a matter of quit the game when you die, but I like much that this is included as a part of the game. Sometimes the smallest details make a big difference, and the developers have done a really good job with this game. They are also active improving the game and there are no tricks or pay to win, the game is free. You can buy cosmetic things such a flame texture for your weapon, a new texture for a pice or armor, a pet, etc.If you liked once Diablo, try this. If you have never played Diablo or any other "hack and slash" game and want to give a chance to the genre, this is a good one.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												I thought this game deserved a further review considering the hours I tanked into it recently.(My original review is still at the bottom)Path of Exile is amazing, comparing it to diablo dosen't do it any justice, it's an ARPG and borrows some fundementals set by the old style games, but gives you so much more to work with. When you start the game you choose a class (starting place on the talent tree) and you are dumped on a beach, and you go from there. What skills you use, what gear you wear, however you want to roleplay is upto the player.\PoE has near infinite hours of replayability, new builds, challenge leagues, races and PVP, freedom is the name of the game. It's open.If you like the sound of creating a build from the huge range of options or like deleting hoards of goatmen, or want to spend all day trading, or want to measure your e-peen on one of the ladders. PoE has something that'll hook you.GGG, to me, seem like one of the best games developers I've seen, and they do a tremendous job bringing new content to the player-base... for free! Microtransactions are free, there are no pay-to-win features at all, cosmetics and storage space are most of what you can find. It's refreshing to see microtransations not being shoved down your throat, they are expensive enough that they are not all that common, but still affordable, while making the game profitable for GGG.=======================================================================I dont use the steam client because the official one is more my style. (Thats why it says I only have 11 hours)Great ARPG. So many ways to play this game. Can't recommend it enough if you are looking for a timekiller that dosent require too much effort.It's also has a very fair free-to-play model, based off buying storage space, character slots and cosmetics, all the people complaining about having to get more storage etc, should take a look at how much goes into this game, and consider the price-tag.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												This game is a phenomenal example of Free to Play and Action RPGs done right. Non-intrusive microtransactions, all of the content in the game, sans cosmetic skins, is available for free. The game has an incredible amount of complexity and character customization, which is constantly getting better as the developers fine tune and iterate each patch / "mini-expansion".The only concern I've ever had was Desync, which depending on your character build, will either be negligible or a major problem to deal with. Desync essentially being a period of time where your client and the game server disagree on where you or monsters are, potentially resulting in sudden death as one or the other catches up, only for you to realize that the clear field you thought you were in is actually full of deadly face-eating skeletons.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												This is one of the best games ever made, and when played on hardcore it is one of the most difficult, challenging and rewarding games of the modern era, a triumph over most games of this generation, and a callback to times when every player had to learn the game they were playing in order to succeed, rather than being catered to and handheld. Except this time you have an interactive community to help you along the way, as the game features trading, partying, player housing, and an 'interesting' global chat. And what a journey it will be, the atmosphere of this game feels like a blend of Dark Souls meets Diablo. Despite the graphics being pretty simple there's a ton of heart and fantastic art direction+flavour paving every step of the way. There's literally thousands upon thousands of ways to build your character. (Despite this 90%* of the community just plays CoC builds) *hyperboleThe best part? The game is free, aside from some purely aesthetic microtransactions which look very nice. No pay2win here. (Until you need more stash tabs i.e storage space) The community is one of the most diverse (for better & for worse) communities I've ever encountered, and the depth of this game is greater than most MMORPG's, despite this genre being an online ARPG. The difficulty scales to an absurd extent, you can never truly "Faceroll" every aspect of this game,(Unless you play CoC, in which case please uninstall--you're not a good player, stop uploading twinned boss map clear videos to Reddit, nobody cares--except for other CoC players) and there's just so much depth and replayable value to this game that I really can't recommend it enough. The endgame, on hardcore, is insanely fun and often times heartracing, with immense risk and reward being omnipresent throughout the experience. The more you play this game, the more you want to play it, and that is a surefire sign of both an addictive problem and a masterpiece. On the negative side of things, the early portion of this game is a total, unintuitive mess--if you're unfamiliar with the ARPG genre, or even if you're somewhat familiar with it, the game will likely feel far too overwhelming to bother with, it doesn't even bother trying to tutorialize you, and while the exploratory independence the game gives you is ultimately empowering, it's a little too vacuous for genuinely new players. Several of the game's mechanics & character features are amazingly in depth and customizable once you begin to grasp them, but unfortunately they also come off as very hard to understand initially, and even once you begin to understand them you'll likely fail to fully realize what you can do with them for quite some time. None of this is necessarily "bad", but it could certainly be offputting to a large demographic. The pace of the game is also painfully slow early on, this is especially true if you have no gear and if you're new to the game-most new players and even several veteran players don't know how to level efficiently, and waste a lot of excess time doing certain pointless side quests, picking up every useless item, killing every mob, doing irrelevant side areas, etc. Bluntly put, combat will not feel satisfying for a while, but when your build starts to come together and the enemies start to possess actually significant mechanics, boy oh boy does the world ever turn upside down. On top of that, the "true" game doesn't kick off until merciless difficulty, by which point you'll already have "beaten the campaign" twice, and this is presently very unintuitive to newer players, so a significant portion of the "playerbase" ends up "beating" the game (in their eyes) on normal and then never returning, even though the real experience hasn't even begun yet (Although regardless, at least these people get to experience the boss fight "Malachai", which is something you'll probably not soon forget). However, I'd still implore anyone who might turn away from the game because of these reasons to *just trudge through it* because, come merciless difficulty, come MAPS, it'll all prove to be deeply worth it. Once you get your first good unique item, once you 5 link or 6 link your first item, etc. etc., you'll have nowhere to go but up. That is, until your character dies and you angrily uninstall or reroll a CoC build. Screw CoC builds they're killing the game and trivializing the content, alright GGG you caught me this was all really an elaborate ruse with the actual intent of this review being nothing more than a rant about CoC builds. CoC builds are utterly faceroll and negate all strategic thought, difficulty, mechanics, and build variety involved in this game. Also nerf lightning coil and blade vortex. GOTY.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												This game will eat your life.I love and hate this game at the same time. It is starting to get dated, but new players will find so much to do that they won't even notice.The game has settled into two basic groups. 1) The 500+ hour player who is still struggles to make a character that is viable for end game content and 2) the 2000+ hour gamers who know every explot in the game and post videos on youtube about it.  Both groups still seem to have fun.The game has a steep learning curve for an AARPG, but can still be played with just basic understanding.  The most overwhelming thing is the skill tree. You will certainly mess up your first few characters, but that is part of the fun.It is the closest toa truly "free-to-play" game I've ever seen of its quality. The only real $ transactions are for asthetics and extra storage.  As long as you're not a pack rat, you never have to spend a dime. However, if you find that you put in 100+ hours on the game, you won't feel too bad dropping a little cash for storage and the money sorting system.Get it, play it, hate it, love it.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												TL;DR sum-up of PoE:  FTP Diablo 2.PoE is a FTP Diablo 2 knock off and I mean that in the most lovingly way possible.  Honestly, I'm surprised Blizzard hasn't gone after their asses.  From the character choices, graphics, minions (goat-men!!), hell, even the music, anyone who has played D2 will know immediately what I'm talking about. I, like many others, was crushed by what D3 turned into.  Looking for what D3 should have been?  Here's your answer.Is it really FTP?  yes.  The only, and I mean ONLY, things you can buy are cosmetic enhancements. Yay, glowing swords....Did I tell you there are almost daily competitions and races?  Well there are.  Examples:    Who can run the fastest through the game only using melee?  Oh you're a witch?  Well, better get swinging!    Unique dungeon crawls where you can't go home and fix your boo-boos or buy better equipment.  Use what you find, son!And don't worry, the playing field is leveled for this:  to do a race you must start with a brand new character.  Only your wits will help you prevail!  ...And lucky loot drops.I recommend this game, and for those nostalgic for D2; the first goat-bleat will warm your soul.  Happy left-button smashing!

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												After spending a very large portion of the past 2 years of my life playing and thoroughly enjoying this game I thought I would write a little review on it.This game innovates the ARPG genre in so many ways while remaining true to the genre's roots. The passive and skill gem system provide considerable customization and drive to improve your character, the visuals while not always AAA standards are fantastic and really help set the mood for the dark forsaken continent of Wraeclast. I dont listen to the music often as I am typically on mumble with my guild, but the sound design is also fantastic, particularly the Scion character's voice acting, you can truly feel her passion/heartache at the right moments, the game's sound effect often clearly illustrate finer details of the game such as a pile of loot dropping, a unique item dropping or a critical strike. With the frequent free content patches and the microtransactions that at the very most increase convenience make you well aware that these developers have the hardcore gamer's best interests at heart while still making the game accessible to newer and more casual players by involving the community in such things as game/build guides as well as a few podcasts that help you keep updated on what new patches mean and how the game's meta is shifting. On top of that the game's streaming community are mostly very helpful and educational with each streamer giving you something to take away and apply to your own character, whether it be one of Ziggyd's beginner guides or Havoc616 and Mathil's  attempts to farm the endiest endgame content imaginable or even Willywonka/Helman/Raizqt for their unique content, there is always something to learn.If I had one complaint it would be that a few engine issues keep it from being perfect. oh, and there isnt enough time to do all the builds that I think up.Thank you Grinding Gear Games for giving me such an amazing experience to share with my friends all across the globe.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2013
												Path of Exile is a complex and engaging free to play action RPG set in the grim world of Wraeclast. The atmosphere is very dark and interesting. Players slowly uncover the secrets behind their exile and Wraeclast. The lore is scattered throughout the game world and really adds to the immersion.The passive tree is absolutely massive and extremely diverse, allowing for almost any playstyle imaginable. Skills can be augmented with "Support Gems" to significantly modify what they do and to create some truly outrageous combinations. The amazing unique items in the game only add to the already overwhelming amount of character customization. The result is a theorycrafter's wet dream. Another major feature is that there is no "gold" as a form of currency. Instead there are numerous items of varying rarity that modify almost every aspect of items you find. These currency items allow players to custom tailor their gear while simultaneously combating inflation of the economy since they are consumed on use.The game also features "Races", which are timed competitve events ranging from a few minutes to a couple hours. Races can have many additional features and restrictions to make them more fun and challenging. Some races are designed to be almost an entire different game mode than the base game. Races are separated by Seasons, allowing players to earn points and win limited time alternate art unique items.On top of all this, Grinding Gear Games is one of the most communicative developers I have ever experienced. They are very active in the community and take all suggestions and feedback seriously. Lastly, the game features a completely non pay to win microtransaction model. All game content is available right from the start. Real money will only buy you cosmetic effects to make your character look awesome and a few account features for convenience. I highly recommend trying out Path of Exile if you have even the slightest bit of interest in the genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												POE is like no other dungeon crawler I've ever played. The passive tree and skill gems are such unique character building mechanics that they became my favorite part of the game. The currency system has been excellently designed too; each unit of value is not only  valuable because it is money but because currency itself is expendable for varying magical effects on your items, transportation etc. The graphics are beautiful and controls are easy to pick up/remappable.  Some monsters, especially dungeon bosses can be very challenging (not to mention on higher difficulties - Cruel, Merciless) and take multiple tries to beat. The game lets you spawn back into the dungeon with damage you've already dealt persisting on the bosses so eventually you can brute force it if that's what you want to do, unless you are on Hardcore, in which case - Permadeath. Home building is mainly a neat distraction and hub for the Masters you can use to more easily craft powerful gear. My only complaint is that progressing through the whole life of a character to the end game requires that you do the same quest/storyline several times in a sort of new game plus style. The storyline is not bad by any means, in fact the world lore and theme is pretty cool but it can start to get repetitive. One of the best things about it, I've never spent a single dime and I get the same gameplay that anyone else who spends money on it does, because the majority of purchases available, other than more stash room (not necessary they give you plenty) are cosmetic only.Highly highly recommend to anyone who enjoys dungeon crawlers, and to anyone who hasn't tried one before, why not give it a shot? Free-2-Play after all.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												TL:DR – A fun, free, online, click, click, click RPG that’s light on story with enough things to do that will keep all but the most hardcore player interested (for a bit, at least).I’ll just start with the greatest selling point of Path of Exile—no selling point. Free helps as most of the flaws don’t seem quite so harsh at that price. You’ll click on wave after wave of bad guy as you roll the loot piñata dice in hopes that this time the Staff of Iwin drops. Path of Exile is a fun little game that you’ll find yourself loading up from time to time to kill a couple of waves of bad guys before your wrist starts to hurt. 7/10.The Good—Free: Only costs bandwidth and time to download.Characters: Lots of character classes.Items: Lots of stuffs with skills being placed on gem drops to make the game different. Grinding: Now with 10% less hamster wheel.Online Community: Friends need only apply. Leagues: Lots of different events and contests for frequent players.Updates: Fairly often with new expansions and drastic changes to gameplay to keep the game interesting.The Bad—Repetitive: You better like killing snakes in the forest zone, because you’ll do lots of it.Graphics: Not bad, but worse than the competition. Much worse.Online: People who are not your friend will annoy you. Greatly.In Game Purchases: Currently, this isn’t bad but things could easily be changed to bad and make the game not worth running.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												In a world where free titles either A) try to force you into microtransactions to win, or B) just plain suck, Path of Exile breaks the mold and is, well, neither. Every aspect of this game is polished. With the exception of some sporadic server issues, I can't find much of anything to dislike about this ARPG. You've got the whole package: highly customizable (and good) graphics, good OST for that dark ambience, tons of voice acting that isn't cheesy, online play (though it's required of course), and really fun skill customization. Think Final Fantasy 7's materia system (the skill orbs you put on your gear) and Final Fantasy 10's skill tree system (a huge web of connected orbs that give you a clear route as to what playstyle you want to go with). As for microtransactions, your instinct probably tells you this could potentially be pay-to-win. But fear not! All of the items purchased from the shop are purely cosmetic (with the exception of extra bank and character slots for those REALLY hardcore players). To me, this says the developers are confident that you might support them in the future for making such a killer game and just giving it away.Overall, PoE takes a fresh spin on a tired genre and gives it to you for free. If nothing else, just download this and keep it for a rainy day when you wanna scratch that ARPG itch.

content:
Posted: April 17
												ABOUT THIS GAMEYou are an Exile, struggling to survive on the dark continent of Wraeclast, as you fight to earn power that will allow you to exact your revenge against those who wronged you. Created by hardcore gamers, Path of Exile is an online Action RPG set in a dark fantasy world. With a focus on visceral action combat, powerful items and deep character customization, Path of Exile is completely free and will never be pay-to-win.Key FeaturesFreedom. Power. Revenge.Banished for your misdeeds to the dark, brutal world of Wraeclast, you play as the Duelist, Witch, Ranger, Templar, Marauder, Shadow or the Scion class. From forsaken shores through to the ruined city of Sarn, explore Wraeclast and uncover the ancient secrets waiting for you.Unlimited Character CustomizationCreate and customize hundreds of unique skill combinations from tradable itemized gems and our gigantic passive skill tree. Combine skill gems, support gems and trigger gems to create your own unique combination of power, defense and destruction.Deadly MissionsThe Forsaken Masters each have their own style of mission and each of these missions has many variations. As you explore deeper into Wraeclast, the pool of available variations increases to challenge you in new ways. All of the Missions and their variations can occur anywhere in the game, including within end-game Maps.Dressed to KillPath of Exile is all about items. Find, collect and trade magic, rare and unique items with arcane properties, then customize your character build around the deadliest combinations you possess.Brutal Competitive PlayBattle in PvP tournaments seasons and Capture the Flag events for worldwide recognition. Compete in Daily Leagues and Race Events that run as separate game worlds with their own ladders and economies to win valuable prizes.Customise Your Hideout​In their extensive travels throughout Wraeclast, the Forsaken Masters have discovered ideal locations for an Exile to use as their own secret Hideout. Once you've earned a Master's trust, you may be taken to a Hideout, where you can create your own personalised town. Masters residing in your Hideout offer you daily Missions and train you in advanced crafting options. Use your Hideout as a quiet place to craft after battle, or expand it and use it as a personalised Guild Hall with hundreds of decorations.Fair-To-Play. Never Pay-To-Win. We're committed to creating a fair playing field for all players. You cannot gain gameplay advantage by spending real money in Path of Exile.

												One of the most addicting and rewarding Action Role Playing games to date. It features an extensive passive tree with over hundreds of possibilities with extreme character progression and builds.The game features 7 different classes each with their own unique abilities and play styles which caters to any individuals type of play-through, whether you are a brute tank (The Marauder) or a necromancer witch who can use arcane magic and call upon the dead for help.The best feature of the game is that it is free to play! There are in-game purchases but they're merely cosmetic items which don't effect the balancing of the game as the developers have been strict on making a fair game.You will almost certainly have a good time leveling up with your friends.  As there is no gold in this game, You may get turned off by the extreme reliance on trading that is a consequence of the frustratingly unrewarding item drops and PoE's annoyingly random orb system The game itself looks rather nice, even if it isn't up to par with the AAA games out there, it is a free to play and not 60$.All in all, I'd say pick this one up! It's free after all and if you enjoy ARPG's then you'll enjoy this one!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I thought I would try and write up a few words about this game, as I really enjoy the ARPG games and played through most of them (Diablo I & II, Titan Quest & IT, Torchlight I & II, Van Helsing, and only don't have D3 due to cost - though this may change when the patch comes) and for me, the Daddy of them all has been Titan Quest. I probably sunk 200+ hrs in that and Immortal Throne (they don't show on my Steam games as I had them pre-steam and loved the game so much I rebought them on Steam) and played through the game on all three difficulty ratings. So how does Path of Exile square up to these other great ARPG's? Bloody good actually. Really bloody good.Graphics The effects on everything are superb, the gem levelling, the elemental attacks, the frozen or burning mob/player effects, the animations for mobs blinking, tunnelling, dissolving, ghosting, all of it. The backdrops for locations (towns, villages, caves, forests, battlegrounds) are lush with a huge amount of detail, the characters look excellent, with a large amount of clothing variants.Maps Excellent. How many ways can you actually put dead ends into a seemingly open ended area? You will be surprised, and they do it very well. With some much detail, the minimap adds yellow 'corridors' to show connecting areas in case the foliage or camera angle is in your way, and there are plenty of variations - cave textures are repeated more often than not, but I suppose its quite hard to come up with new ways to portray rocks, so I will let them off that.Mobs A Huge amount of variation with the usual casters, fighters and ranged mobs, and then mixed abilities, casting, teleporting, swarms, etc. There is a nice mix of normal and yellow bosses, and then end of act bosses. I think I would have liked to see more 'bigger than yellow but less than end of act bosses' like in TQ, but other than that, jolly good indeed.Skill Tree & Classes Ah, the bread and butter of all ARPG's, the skill tree. This is where PoE fails, as it has no skill tree at all! Instead, it has a freaking skill WEB. No mere tree for this game, but a spiders web that depending on class, your start point changes. You gain skill points per level and for completing some quests and you can customise your (one of 6) classes to a stupid amount of variations. I thought TQ ability to combine two classes and then pick and choose from their respective trees brilliantly varied, but this is something else.Loot Ah, the loot. You want to pour of the minute of the items found, min/maxing to gain resists/hp/regen/dps? You will spend hours doing so. You want the ability to create and improve items? You will spend hours doing so. You want to take your item as you like the look of it, wipe it, and new stats, add sockets and reforge links? You will spend hours doing so. Like most other ARPGs, you never seem to find the right item for your class, but this only makes you want to farm and then replay the whole game again on the next difficulty. There are sockets to add spells and effects to your attacks, and gems to improve the quality of the items - so the combinations of items available is staggering.Overall So add them all together and what have you got? A cracking game, and even diehard 'nothing will beat Titan Quest' ARPGers will admit that this is fantastic. The game itself is free, and you really do not need to spend a penny to enjoy it - I may drop some money on it to say thanks rather than any real need to want a shiny effect on my hat or glowing footprints (even though they do look smart) A fourth act or more locations per act may have tipped it over the edge, but this is right up there, surpassing both Torchlights and Van Helsing, and right on the tailcoats of TQ. There is simply not an excuse to not download this on Steam right now.

												+Decent build variety, dizzying depth+Decent graphics+Fast paced ARPG gameplay+Great bosses+Great endgame system+Hideouts with a real crafting system+True F2P, no pay2win or pay2skip+Desync is fixed, if you have less than 100ms ping+All gameplay, no cutscenes or forced story moments.-High loading times, initial startup time is 20 seconds on SSD, up to 3-5 mins on HDD-Framerate issues, when there are a lot of enemies and effects on-screen it can kill even the most beast computers-Everything keeps getting nerfed and you have to make new characters because your old ones are♥♥♥♥♥♥now-Reliance on trading, slow trading system, no mailboxes or auction house-Reliance on third party tools, such as poe.trade and♥♥♥♥♥♥br>-Crash bugs-Horrid storytelling, you have to pay attention to lore objects and read all the dialogue before you have an inkling of what's going on, not a game for story lovers.-Dodgy servers, sometimes you will have bad routing to the servers and they throw a hissy fit if you drop one packet-New players will find the game extremely boring until at least Act 3, especially if they don't understand the game's mechanics- or + Game is very hardcore, you will have to play for many months before you are able to tackle the hardest content this game has to offer.Overall I'd give this game a 9/10 it ruined my life for sure.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												This game is amazing."That's great," you say. "Another ARPG. So what?"So let me get this out from the start: I am not someone who usually likes ARPGs. I liked Diablo II quite a bit back when it was new. Torchlight was good. Torchlight II was good. Titan Quest was good. But I got bored of all of them before I hit the ten hour mark; some less than that. For the latter few games, I only lasted that long because I had friends to co-op with. I have played around 180 hours of Path of Exile. Half of that was solo. I find myself playing this over games I've actually paid for - all 200+ of them.To me, this game has streamlined the process of playing an ARPG:- Clear desirable attributes for items and the ability to socket and unsocket gems at will eliminates the tedium of sorting out loot while you're in town, allowing you to quickly get back to the business of killing everything that moves or looks at you funny.- Unique currency-barter system- The community is helpful.- The devs are active.- The gameplay is challenging but not too difficult.- This game is free-to-play powered by microtransactions so unobtrusive you would be forgiven for forgetting they were there at all.I'm trying to think of some complaints here. Something to say "this could be improved by such and such" and honestly nothing immediately comes to mind. There are no major bugs that ruin the game. Each class is viable, though some are more effective than others.All in all, if you're looking to find something to play without paying a cent, and the idea of being able to leave a trail of destruction behind you in the quest for more items and power sounds appealing, it's hard to do better.5/5

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												First of all let me say that i totally recommend this game to everybody who played Diablo III and got utterly disappointed by it. Path of Exile is comparable to older Diablo titles in its atmosphere and skill level and it is of course free to play. I always use PoE as an example for one of the best f2p titles out there since there is not a single pay to win aspect in the game. All you can buy with real life money are cosmetic changes to your character or more stash tabs to store items (not to be confused with your actually relevant character inventory!). Path of Exile offers  the standard action RPG game style with serveral  acts and several playthroughs, one a little harder then the other. For the first few characters that system never gets boring, but it lacks a bit of long time motivation, especially since the late game aspect of the game (maps you can find and replay zones on a higher level through them) gets boring after some time, too. PoE has something to offer for every kind of ARPG player. Those who simply want to play a hack and slay game can do so, but also players who like to think a lot about optimizing their build will be satisfied thanks to the unique and massive skill tree.There really is no reason not to check out Path of Exile, especially since it is totally free!

												If you want a dark, gritty, lore rich, complex, mechanically astounding, overwelmingly rewarding labour of love ARPG then this is YOUR game as it is all of ours. This is catagorically and apsolutly the best ARPG ever created! and by the way the game has been continuously developed with a heavy bias towards community I have no doubt at all that it will be for years to come. 900 hours on steam, must be over 7000 hours out of steam AT LEAST. I dont buy any games and have spent about £40 a month on this one game for the last 4 1/2 years, what does it get me? Nothing that someone who paid £0 would (apart from quality of life stash tabs which is catagorically not pay to win). I have however designed and created 2 unique items ingame and obtained all the pets, armours, skill affects, hideout decorations (yes you have your own base to create and customise) I can get my hands on!!!!! Not to mention various T-Shirts, artwork and the comics. Ignore everything after D2 upto Path of Exile and ignore everything after Path of Exile after Path of Exile, you wont be disappointed i garentee it. GG GGG

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Having an *ahem* history with Diablo 2 LoD, I was preparing very hard to be disappointed here. I'm very specific about what I enjoy in aRPG's, but this definitely delivers on all the fronts that I've come to like. The maps are repetitive but random (this is a good thing) and there is an obscene amount of loot to find. The currency system is different, but better (I remember vividly how useless gold was in D2 - no more). The passive tree isn't very intuitive (if you want a competitive character, that is), but it does offer a lot of potential for theorycrafting if that is what you enjoy. As far as I can tell the classic aRPG class niches have all been nicely filled. If you don't feel like theorycrafting, there's an active forum community (official forums, obviously - not the steam ones) that probably has a guide for the thing that you want to play somewhere. If you're looking for Diablo 2, but not Diablo 2 itself, you will like this.

												Addicted. That is all I would say if I was trying to sum this up in a few words.This game is absolutely amazing, my mate messaged me on steam saying "Yo man, I found this game, you should check it out, its an RPG with like mages and stuff" Usually I don't take much interest to games like this, but boy am I glad I took a chance with this game.The first hour of gametime I was feeling a bit like "eh, this game is alright, its free cant get any better than what this is"If I could go back in time, I would go back and slap myself and say it is one of the best games I will ever play. Then after a few hours, I got better gear, better stats, and the longer I played it, the more I loved it.So here I am, finished the game on Normal Difficulty, and just heading into Act II on Cruel Difficulty, and I am loving it even more, it is so satisfying when you get even better gear because its so rare to find something that is better than the last when you have awesome magic attributes on your gear.Overall: Awesome game, if you haven't downloaded it yet, played it yet, or you don't really find these sort of games entertaining, download it right now, I promise you, coming from a guy who loves FPS Games this is completely different and I love it to bits.I have 1 issue with the game but it is understandable why it is the way it is. And the issue is the price of the Microtransations, but since the game is free they gotta make some of that $$$ somehow :D

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Best action RPG out there right now, but not without its problems:PoE requires too much dedication for hard working students and people with jobs or a family who want to maintain a healthy lifestyle. If you don't have a lot of time on your hands, you're better off playing some other game because you won't get much out of PoE.The skill tree doesn't offer as much freedom as it first appears to. While the overall selection does greatly affect how your character works under the hood, they are still passive skills, most of which are just tiny percentage buffs and seriously underwhelming on their own.I'm not a fan of D3, but the active skills in PoE do not satisfy like D3's do. There aren't any active skills that really make me want to build a PoE character.In PoE you tend to build a character around one attack and spam that single one until you're blue in the face. Other action RPGs typically offer combined use of more active skills.PoE is a thinking person's game, challenging, huge depth in its mechanics. It takes a long time and a lot of reading to learn how to create strong characters and it takes forever to get characters to a high level. The learning process is a joy, but respeccing isn't really doable.The game changes a lot. If you leave the game and return after some months, you'll need to relearn wat makes a strong character, and all your character's passive skill trees will have been reset because the game's skill tree was likely updated. Your characters won't function until you reinvest those skillpoints. After returning to the game you likely won't know the current trade value of items.The game doesn't comfortably let you take a few months off and then come back.They went too crazy with the socket colours and linked sockets. While fun at first, the impossibly low odds of getting the right sockets and links on your gear become an annoying limiting factor to how you build your character. Specifically, part of the problem is that the type of defence stat (armor, energy shield, or evasion) on a gear item determines what socket colour is most likely to show up on it. Active kills are gems that need to be socketed before you can use them, and they will only fit in sockets of the matching colour. This effectively forces you to focus on a specific defence type based on what active skills you want to use, severely restricting the endless freedom that the passive skill tree initially appears to provide.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Close your eyes and go back to the year 2000 and remember the amazing times you had in Diablo 2 and open your eyes and wake back up in a beautiful modern take on that gritty ARPG you once loved.Path of Exile offers an incredible amount of flexibility the skill tree overwhelms many at first glance but once you tame that beast the freedom it gives you is unparalleled, it will honestly ruin all other ARPG's for you making you feel claustrophobic and want to escape back to the freedom that PoE gives you.Most communities are pretty toxic online and you might presume this to be the same but crack that hard outer shell and most people are willing to take the time to discuss their builds give you advice if you are stuck and sometimes even give you a hand killing a boss you are stuck/scared to take on or even give you some gear to help you move on.Not only does it crush all other ARPG's currently on the market it keeps evolving as well.The developers respond minutes within issues with the servers and listen to the community (not just the ones that whine the most), they consistently update the "meta" and have always tried to push the boundaries with adding various mechanics and adding new content whether it is new unique weapons or fresh mechanics and bosses.It's a game I've thoroughly enjoyed investing over 1000 hours into and I'm sure I will continue to invest 1000's more.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												This game is very fun. It keeps you stuck to the game, and never wanting to stop playing. I must confess: I've only played an hour of this game, but out of that hour was one of the best hours I have ever had. In the first part, you basicly just choose a class, big deal, right? Well, you get shipwrecked, then you talk to a guy, and fend off a horde of the undead. After killing some more undead, you get some more items, then, comes out a boss. He is acually pretty hard, so, I recommend leveling up once or twice and getting some gear before you fight him. After that, you get in a town, and then your adventure starts from there! You can do some sidequests there, later gaining people's trust. After a while, you realize how far and how good you are doing with this game, trust me, this game is amazing. The controls are pretty easy to handle. The gameplay, however, is laggy at times, but eventually stops. Also, one bad thing about your character, when you pick your main weapon, you're bound to want to get another one, but you realize it is not the same with your old weapon(s). For example, I had a rusted sword and a claw. I wanted to try out a bow and arrow. I found out that I had to un-equip both weapons(duh) and equip the bow. After I did that, I realized it wasn't the same with my life stealing claw and sword, so, I switched. So, I strongly suggest that you should get this game. Also, one thing, I think that this game is somewhat similar to League of Legends or Dota 2. That's what I think, I don't know about the rest of you. Anyway, download Path of Exile, and be prepared to fight and be addicted to this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												+Addictive ARPG Gameplay+Multiple Character Options+Coherent ARPG Story+Free-To-Play without the Freemium-Pacing drags towards the endPath of Exile is the best Free-to-Play game on the PC market.  The monetization of the game is never shoved into your face and the game never feels like it is giving you a lesser experience for playing without spending.The Action Role Playing Game (ARPG) elements are excelent as the various special abilities express variabilty in game mechanics while providing satisfying feedback in the form of crunchy-gory slaughter.  While there is plenty of good enemy variability throughout the campaign, your primary tactics will most likely not vary until you come accross large groups of enemies or platoons that mix range and melee combatants.The character customization is limited to the items you wear and the sprawling skill tree that makes up the leveling system for the game.  While skill gems provide the meat of experience in terms of move sets, the skill tree simply determines what weapons and armor you can equip while providing percentage bonus to your damage and attack speeds.All character classes are viable, however, it is important to note their specialties to best equip and advance your character for optimal slaying.  While the game is not necessarily difficult, deaths become common when you make haphazard or impatient mistakes to bring the fight to a large group of enemies.  Boss encounters can seem daunting at first, however, once you understand to eliminate their followers and then carefully avoid their primary attack, the fights become very manageable.Path of Exile introduces some innovations or rather differing mechanics for bartering and potion use.  When you trade an item into a vendor, you recieve peices of identifying scrolls or alchemy gems that can be used to identify or make magic items respectively.  This displaces the importance of accumulated wealth into a more free form experimentation with getting better gear as you can often make a better item from a non-magical item and a few alchemy gems.  Potions are recharged from slaying enemies rather than consumed on an individual basis, which adjusts your tactics as you become heavily damaged.Overall, I think Path of Exile is a great game, free-to-play or not.  I found it more engaging than Diablo III and Torchlight II, however, your experience might vary based on how the art style and story appeals to your tastes.  The game, though, is just fun and should be at least tried.[GET ASAP]

It has a good community, enough players that you can always find a party to play with, but the game is just as much fun to play alone if soloing is more your style. it is COMPLETELY F2P, with the only paid content being cosmetics. The difficulty curve is just steep enough to be challenging, without repeatedly reducing you to pounding the keys and screaming incoherently into your mic. The controls and gameplay take some getting used to, but if you've played similar games before you should have no trouble. One thing i found interesting is that there is no in-game currency. Instead, items are purchased using a barter system that uses items you can find while playing, and these items have their own uses as well. You start out with one of six classes, which each have their own strengths and weaknesses. However, the skills and abilities of these classes are infinitly customizable, giving you the freedom to play however you want. The story is not the most detailed I've seen, not by a long shot, but it's definitely there. All in all, this is one of the best games I've played in a long time, and i would definitely recommend that you play it.Serious rating: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Hardcore action rpg fans will love this game. If you're new to the action rpg scene(like i was), conquering this game may prove extremely difficult. The graphics are above average for a free to play game, providing a very dark world with creepy crawlers (lots of spiders) and catastrophobic caverns (lots of undead). The story is almost non existent with the game but it does try its best to add some lore. The game offers deep customisation in how you build your character, issuing one of the largest passive skill (yes passive) trees i have encountered in an action rpg (i have only played three). You can choose from 7 characters (1 is unlocked throughout the game), each differing in lore, sex and appearance. Path of exile lends it self to very deep builds and theorycrafting, which hardcore players will adore. Skills are collected from the world either from quests, drops or from trading with players. These skills are called "skill gems" and begin as your fundamental action rpg spells. You will later acquire support gems which will provide unqiue abilites to the skill gems resulting in some nice effects adding to the games fluid combat. The game offers an in game store, however this is purely cosmetics based and storage space extensions which is initially huge anyway, offering no "pay to win" bonuses. After a few run throughs (i did about three messing up all three characters after and before release) and starting a new character today, i felt the repetitive nature of the story and dungeons, and caverns overwhelm me. This is purely point subjective and will differ within the community. 11 hours of gameplay plus about 5-6hours during beta is nowhere near enough to fully enjoy and experience this game to its fullest. But i feel thats all this game will get out of me, which is a shame because i really do want to support the developers for their efforts.Path of exile is an above average free to play action rpg fans of the original diablo games will enjoy. Get your pens, papers, mathematics ready, this game's going to need it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												In a world where free titles either A) try to force you into microtransactions to win, or B) just plain suck, Path of Exile breaks the mold and is, well, neither. Every aspect of this game is polished. With the exception of some sporadic server issues, I can't find much of anything to dislike about this ARPG. You've got the whole package: highly customizable (and good) graphics, good OST for that dark ambience, tons of voice acting that isn't cheesy, online play (though it's required of course), and really fun skill customization. Think Final Fantasy 7's materia system (the skill orbs you put on your gear) and Final Fantasy 10's skill tree system (a huge web of connected orbs that give you a clear route as to what playstyle you want to go with). As for microtransactions, your instinct probably tells you this could potentially be pay-to-win. But fear not! All of the items purchased from the shop are purely cosmetic (with the exception of extra bank and character slots for those REALLY hardcore players). To me, this says the developers are confident that you might support them in the future for making such a killer game and just giving it away.Overall, PoE takes a fresh spin on a tired genre and gives it to you for free. If nothing else, just download this and keep it for a rainy day when you wanna scratch that ARPG itch.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												"Path of Exile is everything that Diablo 3 failed to produce on launch" is what I hear being said a lot.What I'd like you to know is that Path of Exile is it's own game, with it's own idea, and a solid planning stage. Because of the lack of a "standard" currency system such a gold, or coin, players have to be a more evolved breed to approach this game. With a constantly evolving roster of events such as races, seasons and leagues, Path of Exile is the kind of game you can be a bit bored with and come back to months later and feel like you're in a completley new product!Most of the microtransactions by which the game survives are completely reasonably priced. A few extra bag pages for your stash, a couple cosmetic upgrades so you feel outside the norm, totally worth putting a bit into the company to say thanks for making a real hit. Enjoy Path of Exile, it's worth the download.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												I played the hell out of Diablo 2. Slapping people with a shield while I had a perfectly good sword, and playing as undead midget necromancers with armies of summons were some of my favorite past-times. Diablo 3 was a mess. I wanted nothing to do with it, when eventually a friend reccomended Path of Exile to me. PoE takes those silly moments of experimentation and turns it up to 11. You can make totems that cast spells for you, fill the screen with chain-lightning effect spells and arrows, convert enemies to fight for you, and raise an army of flying swords, tapestries and skulls as well as the undead. You can even re-create Touhou with fireballs.Definitely worth a try if you're into point-and-click hack-n-slash insanity, it definitely takes it in a new direction.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												If you enjoyed Diablo 2, you will enjoy this. If you loved Diablo 2, you will love this. I think Diablo 3 is fun, but a little less difficult than this game. Path of Exile really puts you on the spot every time you go somewhere. You make a mistake on this hostile island full of murderous creatures and evil beings, and boom. You die. GGG's alternative to "end-game" content is pretty interesting too, even though I haven't reached that point yet, and they encourage people to try new things with their ever-changing Seasonal Events, and Races. Rewards just for playing them, no pay-to-win, and plenty of friendly people in-game makes for pretty happy players.UPDATE TO REVIEW: I have since reached endgame content and by all that is ♥♥♥♥ing holy this game is amazing.Far better with friends, too. Since most people like to do so, here's a Pros and Cons setup:Pros:+ Gameplay: Like I described above, the game feels ultimately rather similar to Diablo in how it is played, until you get into the real meat and potatoes of it, somewhere usually around level 30-35 or so.+ Community: The community is amazing. Sure, we'll mess with people and provide peanut gallery level commentary on everything (hell, one of my characters is named "Cactus_Chucker" for god's sakes) but we also help out players who are legitimately just asking questions, or learning aspects of the game for the first time. Everyone started somewhere, and not all of us have ~800 hours.+ NOT PAY TO WIN: Grinding Gear Games has absolutely nothing functional that you can pay for aside from storage space. Considering that storage space does not affect your characters in any way, shape, or form in how they are played, how their damage is calculated, or anything, the game cannot be classified as pay to win. Just pay to look dope as ♥♥♥♥ and have all the shiny things stashed away where they'll never see the light of day.+ Co-Op: You can play with friends! It is free! Invite your friends and show them the glory of PUNCHING THINGS SO HARD THEY EXPLODE! (Infernal Blow Facebreakers)+ Hardware Limitations: I run this game on an 8 year old HP laptop. Obviously that means that it isn't super hardware intensive. Makes it easier to play with friends who aren't as up to date on their tech.Cons:- Connection Required: Yeah, this is kind of annoying. Being online at all times makes this kind of a hassle if there are things happening like inclement weather, or other things like repairs on hardware in your area. Not a huge con, but still worth mentioning.- Desync: This one is mostly a "new player" problem, and is easily fixed. By changing your connection settings in the Main Menu (note: CANNOT BE DONE WHILE IN GAME, MUST BE DONE BEFORE SELECTING A CHARACTER) under Input from "Predictive" to "Lockstep". Basically changes from "game assumes where you will be, reacts from there" to "client tells game where you are, game reacts from there". Saves many deaths.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												If you liked Diablo 2, you will probably love this game. It is similar in many aspects, but introduces mechanics which work out great: they are similar to the Materia System and the Sphere Grid from Final Fantasy: the result is a huge variety of possible builds. The passive skill tree stays mostly the same for your character. There are 1000+ nodes and refunding too many will start to cost ingame currency, so this is something you have to plan a bit ahead. however, it's not as insanely overwhelming as it sounds. depending on how you play, only a fraction of these nodes will make sense for your character. You get a complete, optional passive-tree reset for free with major patches. Skills/auras/etc. can be (un)equipped at will: they are found, rewarded and traded throughout the game. And they level up individually and independend of each other. In the end, this makes it much easier to try something new and experiment with different skill combinations, because you don't lose much when exchanging a skill for a different one. You can also combine skills with support skills to buff or change a specific aspect of the skill, usually at the price of increased mana cost or some other tradeoff. For example you could cast 5 projectiles instead of one, but at slightly lower damage. You could also turn the skill passive, so that it triggers at a certain condition, e.g. whenever you take a certain amount of damage. Each projectile could curse an enemy it hits, e.g. making it easier to freeze them with subsequent spells. In later stages of the game, you can add up to 5 effects to a skill if you want. There are many more minor/mediocre changes too, e.g. gold has been replaced by various currency items which can all be consumed for personal use, mostly to enhance or adjust items. You can change the amount, compatibility and connections between the slots in which the skills and effects are being placed. You can exchange the properties of a magic with newly generated ones. You can find a great non-magical ("white") item and upgrade it to a rare one. Potions don't stack: you have 5 slots (there are many special types besides just refilling mana or health, e.g. increasing damage, movement speed, resistances and whatnot) in which you put 5 potions. Most potions can be used multiple times and they automatically refill as you (or your party) kills enemies. As for significant original content: aside from many differently themed areas, monsters and skills, there are a LOT of unique items (some significantly change the way you play) and tons of additional content to discover. E.g. an optional, rogue-like labyrinth which grants some exclusive boni for beating it, but has to be beaten in one sitting (~30-45 mins) without dying (with lots of traps and 3 mandatory boss fights). You can "corrupt" an item (even unique item which are otherwise not "editable" with one other exception), altering it in unexpected ways, some of which otherwise could never occur. But you can corrupt items only once, then nobody can change them afterwards (except the slots for skills, but thats very, very expensive). This is one of several examples on how you can end up with some random "nice to have" effects you would otherwise not bother with, because the other properties of the item are very powerful. You can also find coins which can be spend to have up to 8 prophecies, which are basically semi-random side-quests (there are ordinary story-side quests too) you can then fullfill. You can choose your own hideout style and decorate it (if you want). You can invite certain masters there, which give you daily quests to level them up. These are basically optional but you only need to level the masters globally across all your characters and doing so will give you even more crafting options and also refresh/improve what they sell you. You can also download community-made loot-filters which blend out the majority of useless items you find lying around sometimes (you can configure it if you want, but they work great by default). Theres also PVP which I haven't tried yet. The list goes on and on, this game grew a lot in well-designed, high quality content over the years and still continues to do so at an amazing pace (6(!) new acts coming in june, wtf...). It's free to play and not pay to win. The only gameplay advantage you can buy is a bigger stash, but you already start out with 4 pages that are much much bigger than the single small chest in diablo 2. The stash is shared among all your characters for each league so you don't have to create mules (but you still can, just for having more space). When a league ends, you don't even have to merge these stashes with the standard league: the become additional, remove-only stash-pages. Overall, the game turned out great: 9/10. Only only downside I can see is that it's not that accessible in all areas of the game. You can play it casually and beat it without a problem but reaching the end-game content (the atlas of worlds) will probably require some research/planning. Still, well worth the investment in my opinion. If you want to give this game a try, I have three major suggestions:1. get a loot filter, e.g. google "neversinks lootfilter" 2. sooner or later, look up the most important "vendor recipes". this will improve the currency items you accumulate a bit (especially later on) and acts as some minor crafting option, e.g. "selling" 3 bottles of the same type gives you a higher-tier one. 3. if you play with other people, don't let them "pull" you through the game with a high-level character. they won't be doing you a favor. you will lose all sense of progression (and most of the fun) and it will not benefit you much anyway: if the monster level is much different than yours, there is a experience penalty that can get very big.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												I was surprised that I did not have a review written for PoE, I have 2300+ hours played on the game. Let me preface this review by stating that if you know anything about the ARPG genre then you are probably already playing this game, but if you don't this review is for you. With all my experience I hope I can help you make the decision if this is the right game for you. So without further delay lets jump right in.The pros:- This game has a lot of content, more than most free to play games I have played. The developers actively and in a timely manner release new content, items and game mechanics on a 2~3 month cycle. They diligently pay attention to the continued existance of their game, I respect them for that.- The game is hard, especially for a new player. Don' listen to people who write in their reviews that the game has lost all challenge, these are usually people with thousands of hours played using the most expensive builds in the game to trivialize content like those builds are meant to. In this experience you can really fine tune how challenging the game is if you are after that.- The game has a very deep level of customization for builds, you can pick it up and play it no matter what you build, but don't expect your first build to carry you far. This game is most of all a learning experience, knowledge here really is power.- The visual design and music score are great, they really work to bring the world to life. There is plenty of lore hidden in item descriptions and places around the world. You can also build your own hideout from different items that the master NPCs in the game offer if you are into that like me.- This game is truly free, no content is held behind a pay wall. Crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥I know, but don't expect it to be given to you on a silver platter. However, no matter what you do every moment you sink into the game is worthwhile, everything you pick up no matter how incrementally leads to you reaching your goals. That is something that I can not say for most the experiences on the market.The cons:- The game is hard and unforgiving. You will die to random things while playing and have to piece back together what you did wrong if you don't want to die again. Do not get discouraged, it happens to literally everyone.- Trading is an essential skill you need to learn to get ahead in the game, but the trading community is very toxic. People trying to make a profit constantly prey on new players so learn how to use poe.trade and check it to make purchases and sales. Know what something is worth before you sell or buy.- The learning curve is steep, but there are plenty of resources to prepare you for it. You tube guides, the game forums and the amazing wiki have everything you could ever need to get started. Do not ask people in game to explain a nebulous concept to you, most of the game mechanics require several paragraphs to explain, use those other resources and feel free to ask specific questions about what you want to know.- The gap between the rich players and the poor players is truly vast, bridging it is impossible without a lot of effort. You can't pay to win and if you do to one of the illegal bots expect to get banned, the developers stay on top of that.In my opinion this is the best ARPG on the market and it keeps evolving to stay that way. I enjoy playing and supporting a game made by people who convey a level of professionalism one expects from people running a business and not just working on their game "hobby".

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												If you liked Diablo 2, you will probably love this game. It is similar in many aspects, but introduces mechanics which work out great: they are similar to the Materia System and the Sphere Grid from Final Fantasy: the result is a huge variety of possible builds. The passive skill tree stays mostly the same for your character. There are 1000+ nodes and refunding too many will start to cost ingame currency, so this is something you have to plan a bit ahead. however, it's not as insanely overwhelming as it sounds. depending on how you play, only a fraction of these nodes will make sense for your character. You get a complete, optional passive-tree reset for free with major patches. Skills/auras/etc. can be (un)equipped at will: they are found, rewarded and traded throughout the game. And they level up individually and independend of each other. In the end, this makes it much easier to try something new and experiment with different skill combinations, because you don't lose much when exchanging a skill for a different one. You can also combine skills with support skills to buff or change a specific aspect of the skill, usually at the price of increased mana cost or some other tradeoff. For example you could cast 5 projectiles instead of one, but at slightly lower damage. You could also turn the skill passive, so that it triggers at a certain condition, e.g. whenever you take a certain amount of damage. Each projectile could curse an enemy it hits, e.g. making it easier to freeze them with subsequent spells. In later stages of the game, you can add up to 5 effects to a skill if you want. There are many more minor/mediocre changes too, e.g. gold has been replaced by various currency items which can all be consumed for personal use, mostly to enhance or adjust items. You can change the amount, compatibility and connections between the slots in which the skills and effects are being placed. You can exchange the properties of a magic with newly generated ones. You can find a great non-magical ("white") item and upgrade it to a rare one. Potions don't stack: you have 5 slots (there are many special types besides just refilling mana or health, e.g. increasing damage, movement speed, resistances and whatnot) in which you put 5 potions. Most potions can be used multiple times and they automatically refill as you (or your party) kills enemies. As for significant original content: aside from many differently themed areas, monsters and skills, there are a LOT of unique items (some significantly change the way you play) and tons of additional content to discover. E.g. an optional, rogue-like labyrinth which grants some exclusive boni for beating it, but has to be beaten in one sitting (~30-45 mins) without dying (with lots of traps and 3 mandatory boss fights). You can "corrupt" an item (even unique item which are otherwise not "editable" with one other exception), altering it in unexpected ways, some of which otherwise could never occur. But you can corrupt items only once, then nobody can change them afterwards (except the slots for skills, but thats very, very expensive). This is one of several examples on how you can end up with some random "nice to have" effects you would otherwise not bother with, because the other properties of the item are very powerful. You can also find coins which can be spend to have up to 8 prophecies, which are basically semi-random side-quests (there are ordinary story-side quests too) you can then fullfill. You can choose your own hideout style and decorate it (if you want). You can invite certain masters there, which give you daily quests to level them up. These are basically optional but you only need to level the masters globally across all your characters and doing so will give you even more crafting options and also refresh/improve what they sell you. You can also download community-made loot-filters which blend out the majority of useless items you find lying around sometimes (you can configure it if you want, but they work great by default). Theres also PVP which I haven't tried yet. The list goes on and on, this game grew a lot in well-designed, high quality content over the years and still continues to do so at an amazing pace (6(!) new acts coming in june, wtf...). It's free to play and not pay to win. The only gameplay advantage you can buy is a bigger stash, but you already start out with 4 pages that are much much bigger than the single small chest in diablo 2. The stash is shared among all your characters for each league so you don't have to create mules (but you still can, just for having more space). When a league ends, you don't even have to merge these stashes with the standard league: the become additional, remove-only stash-pages. Overall, the game turned out great: 9/10. Only only downside I can see is that it's not that accessible in all areas of the game. You can play it casually and beat it without a problem but reaching the end-game content (the atlas of worlds) will probably require some research/planning. Still, well worth the investment in my opinion. If you want to give this game a try, I have three major suggestions:1. get a loot filter, e.g. google "neversinks lootfilter" 2. sooner or later, look up the most important "vendor recipes". this will improve the currency items you accumulate a bit (especially later on) and acts as some minor crafting option, e.g. "selling" 3 bottles of the same type gives you a higher-tier one. 3. if you play with other people, don't let them "pull" you through the game with a high-level character. they won't be doing you a favor. you will lose all sense of progression (and most of the fun) and it will not benefit you much anyway: if the monster level is much different than yours, there is a experience penalty that can get very big.
