content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												You bloody kiwis, you've done it. This is the best thing that came out of NZ, since Peter Jackson. Yes, the very famous description of Path of Exile is pretty accurate. This game IS what Diablo 3 should have been. Simply because Grinding Gear made some very brave decisions that Blizzard was too afraid to make. Skill runes was on the table for D3 for a long time but Blizzard didn't go through with it. GG did and it paid off. It works perfectly and brings another dimension to looting. It's rewarding enough to make you stick with a set of skills and flexible enough to get you to try different things. Concept of linking gems is almost perfect and I love experimenting with it. Removal of gold and the barter system is a very bold decision. A big name studio wouldn't have considered this because it makes the game too complicated for noobs and people who would want to buy their way through obstacles. It breaks the cycle of loot/sell and forces you to think about what you're going to do with your loot. I mean you can trade your Orb of Chances for an item you like or you can use them to get something better. It's a quite exciting concept for a purist looter. Another bold decision which makes this game a little complicated for a newbie is the colossal passive skill tree. I think this decision is a clear indication of who GG's target audience for PoE. To be succesful, you have to study the whole skill tree and plan your route. You can't just randomly allocate points and hope to survive. Not many games nowadays, encourages players to actually "think" and "plan". These words are considered "out of fashion" and "bad for business" in today's gaming world. Yeah, these are pretty brave decisions but what is bolder than giving your precious game free and having only cosmetic microtransactions in it? As if the guys in Grinding Gear tried to do opposite of everything Blizzard did with D3. "Blizzard put a $70 price tag on the game and tried to suck even more money out of the games with their RMAH. Alright, let's make PoE free and have no way of buying success in this game." This is truly a noble strategy and because of this, first time I finished PoE during public beta, I felt that I owed these guys something. I bought cosmetic improvements for the first time in my gaming life and it felt bloody good. I will do it again as long as I keep playing the game. The game is all round well polished and very skillfully executed. All the bold decisions I mentioned above made PoE truly a great game. But unfortunately, I wouldn't give it a 10/10. There's one decision prevents me calling this game "perfect" and it's decision that doomed D3 from the start: Having to be online to play a single player campaign. You can give me the logical reasons behind this decision but none of them would be convincing enough to change my mind about this. I understand that it's a richer experience with a party and multiplayer is well integrated to the game, but, I simply do not want lag during a single player campaign session. It's not so much of an issue at the start but once you make it to 60+ maps, lag/loss turns into your biggest enemy. I mean, it doesn't make it unplayable but it's quite annoying when I lose 15 mins of experience because of 1 second of lag. I can't see why this game cannot have an offline single player campaign and my rating will stay at 9/10 until this becomes the reality.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
 IntroductionPath Of Exile is an Action RPG Hack and Slash game that is true gem within its genre. Nobody should ever pass the opportunity to try the game if they are into Hardcore games with learning curves that come out of game experience. The game offers a gigantic Passive Skill tree that will enable any sort of build you might come up with. This game will please alot of thinkers as long as they are willing to understand the rules of the game but at the same time can also please the most casual of the players that just want to be there for the action.The Pros: The Combat System: Path of Exile has a unique way of combining gems. Gems represent castable skills that can either be buffing auras , statuses , combat spells , multipliers and so on. Those gems can be equiped into sockets that your gear has, combining those spells if met said requirements can make them more powerful, for example you can add a gem that allows you to fire more projectiles with your main combat ability , or you can make the projectiles have a chain effect on the enemies. This allows for insane theory crafting and build creations and cycling through many skills you can find what you truly want to play by testing it yourself or simply following guides of other experienced players on the official forums which is what I would recommend for newcommers!  Replay Value: The game offers 4 Acts Of Story , 3 Difficulties and Endgame Maps , Races that last from hours to weeks and can reward you with Permanent Items/Skins. Two Core leagues for both Casual and Hardcore players Hardcore being the one with Permanent death as result. And season leagues that last for 3 months in which you start-over with everybody else and they have their own unique mods that change the gameplay. With the Passive Tree system and the way that Skills work you can made infinite builds on any character you like , either make your own builds or test the shared ones which you can find at the official forums of the game. Refreshing Gameplay Elements: The 3 Month League system is a great feature that more games should use. Giving the original gameplay a new taste every now and then and reseting the ladders allowing people to re-compete from ground 0 is a great way to make people enjoy the game and the better part is that if you are not interested in such a thing you can always stick with Permanent leagues. This gives a further meaning to the infinite builds you can already create because in different scenarios they may work better or worse. Aside from all this, these leagues have achievements of their own which by completion you can recieve awards at the end that you would otherwise need to pay real money for. Developer relationship with Community: If Grinding Gear Games has done anything right aside from their game itself is listening to the community and delivering. Their plan is to do a content update every 6 months and an expansion one the next cycle. The game is F2P and has no P2W elements at all , yet it works really well for them. That is a phenomenom rarely seen in the F2P market nowdays and is certainely honourable.The Cons:Difficulty Curve and Player Taste: While this is not necessarily a negative feature of the game its worth noting that the game is really punishing. That can be either the beauty of the game for some , or their breaking point to quit the game and move on to the next one. While the game can be played casually , if you are seeking to play in a Hardcore league you better get ready to die, LOTS of times and then find yourself knowing the limits of your character and the strengths of certain monsters.Monotonic Visual theme and Soundtracks: While the game itself looks gorgeous in many ways and has a decent ammount of soundtracks. If you find yourself becoming a veteran you may feel a sense of dullness because the dark theme around the game starts to feel very monotonic over many hours played. With that being said at first glance you will certainely love the game if you are into the dark theme and wont have a problem, but if you end up playing alot you will notice that in the gameplay. Aside from that, specificly for soundtracks. They fit thematically really well but I cannot personally say that anything really stands out.Co-Op cross Continent can be brutal: The game offers a big selection of servers with realtime ping check before entering in and no borders in between (Meaning you can swap to any server at anytime and keep your progress) , the grouping system makes the Leader of the Group the host of the instance so if you are planning to play with friends from a different continent (on a game like this which death could be a matter of half a second) having low and stable ping is really important , it can be really troublesome.ConclussionI do recommend this game for both the casual and the hardcore gamers. The game offers huge ammount of unique playtime whether you plan on sticking around for long and being active or hopping in the game here and there. If you are a fan to the genre this is a welcoming game as it has many elements from many popular games such as Diablo and Torchlight which has taken direct inspiration from. This is one of the games that have to be in your "Must Try" collection so if you decide on playing , best of luck to you , Exile.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Downloaded on a whim, Absolutely fantastic, if u were disapointed with diablo 3 download this now,  if ur like me someone who has played some diablo (played the first 2 a little, mostly 3 not much tho), and torchlight 2 but cant get into it completely for whatever reason and always end up not coming back to it, this is the game for u, yes i just downloaded today, yes ive only played 5 hours, but for me downloading this with no real hope for it, i was extraordinarily delighted to find myself playing a game i could see my self playing next year, or the year after that. It is simply put, Fantastic, the creature design, the voice acting and the visuals are all on par (or succeed) the big games (torchlight, diablo(yee im talking u deckard cain), etc) by far. The way u earn abilities and equip them is one of the most original and inovative ways ive ever seen a game go about it, any class can use any weapon (as far as im aware so far on my adventure :P) now the question is (the question that may or may not be preventing u from downloading this game) is it pay to win? drum roll..... curtains open... NOPE, and for once its completely true,u wanna spend 50 bucks on some really good gear that will make u 10x better than any one else, well to bad mofo not gonna happen, anything in the game u buy with real money is purely cosmetic (except pets? not sure havent got one or played with anyone yet who has, so if u know please leave a comment) or for upgrades to your account (extra item tabs, extra character slots etc). anyway in conclusion if u are a fan (or like me not, but waiting for the right one) of these types of rpg action games, then download it now, its free so why not :P and it has definitely become my favorite game in this genre.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												 Has a slow ramp up, but a good skill cieling.  The game is heavy on the theorycrafting so expect to spend a few hours on the web looking at builds if you want to get the most out of your character.   Respecs are done through rare ingame loot, it is not practical to respec most characters, so expect to create multiple characters over time.After a hundred or so hours of playtime it becomes necessary to spend a few bucks on inventory/character expansion slots.  If you find yourself spending more time, you can expect to spend $20 to $30 for quality of life improvements.   Other than that microtransactions are pay to cool not pay to win.There are full price AAA titles that provide less entertainment, absolutley no reason not to give this game a go.

												Time to write a proper review this time. WARNING - LONG :) TL:DR at the bottom.Path of Exile is a hardcore ARPG produced by Grinding Gear Games (GGG). The game has 7 different classes, one of which can only be unlocked further on in the story. Don't let that put you off though. The classes simply determine where you start on the gigantic passive skill tree (more on that later) and what your base attributes are. Attributes consist of strength (red), dexterity (green) and intelligence (blue). Items and skills have attribute requirements that must be met before the item can be equipped or used, with higher level items requiring a higher attribute level. Once again, don't worry if you are a witch and need more strength to equip that one item as you can get attributes from several places (again, explained later).PoE centres around chopping, smashing, shooting, burning, freezing, shocking or poisoning your way throughout an expansive storymode campaign consisting of four Acts with three difficulties: Normal, Cruel and Merciless. Normal is a nice introduction to game mechanics and build theorycrafting and creation. Enemies are easy enough to kill and you level your character reasonably quickly. Once you have completed Act 4, you can take a portal to Cruel difficulty and start again from Act 1 with your current character. Cruel begins to test the defences of your build sich as your resistances to elemental and physical damage. Merciless is where things get tough. Even your standard skeleton WILL kill you if you let your guard down or go AFK in a dungeon (seriously, don't do this). There are literally thousands of possible build ideas to centre around and either follow or diversify. Your build however will focus primarily on a specific set of skills.Skills in PoE are your abilities. The attacks, curses, auras and spells you use to decimate your foes. They take the form of coloured gems that you socket into your equipment. Skill gems have attribute requirements. For example, red gems need mainly strength. Attack skills use base stats from your weapon(s) and likely deal a % of your base damage as either physical or elemental, sometimes both. Curses are debuffs you apply to enemies (simple enough). Auras are powerful buffs that "reserve" a defined % of your maximum mana. And spells have a flat damage that scales with % modifiers from gear, usually completely ignoring a weapons base damage. Skill gems gain experience as you do, and they will eventually level up, drastically increasing their power but also increasing their attribute requirements. Gems can be added and removed at any time, even in the middle of a boss fight (if you absolutely must). A useful piece of knowledge: At level 20 (max level for gems), it will need 155 of a specific attribute. So keep that in mind. There are also support gems. These augment your active skills to give them a massive damage boost while also increasing their mana cost. Support gems only apply if they are linked to an active gem. Links are the little golden bars between sockets on gear. For a skill to be as powerful as you can get, a 5 link or 6 link will be reccomended, but not required. These are generally quite expensive but can be bought fairly cheaply for a plain white item with no modifiers. You can then craft the item with a selection of orbs and currency items.This is where the in-game monetary part of PoE must be explained because it can be confusing for new players. There is no single currency, i.e - gold. Instead there are 24 different types of orbs and scrolls that all have different values are rarities. To save me from typing them all, here is a link to the forum page explaining what they all do. https://www.pathofexile.com/item-data/currencyYou use these orbs to change attributes on your gear, making them (hopefully) more powerful and beneficial to your character. You can also trade these with other players for items. The two trading orbs are almost always Chaos orbs (fairly easy to get) and Exalted orbs (a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to get. You have a 0.055% to get an Exalt from a monster). Get a lot of orbs and you are considered "rich". Please note, in almost 350 hours of playing I have found about 40 chaos orbs, 2 divine orbs and 1 exalted orb. Don't expect to get rich quickly unless you are the living embodiment of good RNG.This is most likely a lot to take in. There are many, many, MANY more aspects of the game, however they will need to be explained by someone else or discovered on your own as my fingers hurt from all this typing. Play the game, get stuck in and you WILL gain wealth and power. Try as many different builds as you want, or stick with one character to pour all your orbz into. TL:DR - Amazingly complex and addictive gameplay and a robust and rewarding economy. And you wanna know the best part? Everything is free. All the storyline is free. No hidden paywalls to unlock high level items. Free expansions. Free endgame. The devs are so non-greedy it is almost staggering, that they would put a game of this quality for everyone to enjoy. There is a cash shop containing cosmetics, skill skins and extra stash tabs (for the loot hoarders), and never once is it advertised with a huge banner ad plastered across your screen. Or even a tiny one in the top corner. I almost felt obliged to buy some extra stash tabs (I'm definitely a hoarder) and a few skins and I still feel like I robbed GGG, like I pirated a costly game.Overall rating: 10/10 - best ARPG ever released (along with Diablo II of course)

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												You bloody kiwis, you've done it. This is the best thing that came out of NZ, since Peter Jackson. Yes, the very famous description of Path of Exile is pretty accurate. This game IS what Diablo 3 should have been. Simply because Grinding Gear made some very brave decisions that Blizzard was too afraid to make. Skill runes was on the table for D3 for a long time but Blizzard didn't go through with it. GG did and it paid off. It works perfectly and brings another dimension to looting. It's rewarding enough to make you stick with a set of skills and flexible enough to get you to try different things. Concept of linking gems is almost perfect and I love experimenting with it. Removal of gold and the barter system is a very bold decision. A big name studio wouldn't have considered this because it makes the game too complicated for noobs and people who would want to buy their way through obstacles. It breaks the cycle of loot/sell and forces you to think about what you're going to do with your loot. I mean you can trade your Orb of Chances for an item you like or you can use them to get something better. It's a quite exciting concept for a purist looter. Another bold decision which makes this game a little complicated for a newbie is the colossal passive skill tree. I think this decision is a clear indication of who GG's target audience for PoE. To be succesful, you have to study the whole skill tree and plan your route. You can't just randomly allocate points and hope to survive. Not many games nowadays, encourages players to actually "think" and "plan". These words are considered "out of fashion" and "bad for business" in today's gaming world. Yeah, these are pretty brave decisions but what is bolder than giving your precious game free and having only cosmetic microtransactions in it? As if the guys in Grinding Gear tried to do opposite of everything Blizzard did with D3. "Blizzard put a $70 price tag on the game and tried to suck even more money out of the games with their RMAH. Alright, let's make PoE free and have no way of buying success in this game." This is truly a noble strategy and because of this, first time I finished PoE during public beta, I felt that I owed these guys something. I bought cosmetic improvements for the first time in my gaming life and it felt bloody good. I will do it again as long as I keep playing the game. The game is all round well polished and very skillfully executed. All the bold decisions I mentioned above made PoE truly a great game. But unfortunately, I wouldn't give it a 10/10. There's one decision prevents me calling this game "perfect" and it's decision that doomed D3 from the start: Having to be online to play a single player campaign. You can give me the logical reasons behind this decision but none of them would be convincing enough to change my mind about this. I understand that it's a richer experience with a party and multiplayer is well integrated to the game, but, I simply do not want lag during a single player campaign session. It's not so much of an issue at the start but once you make it to 60+ maps, lag/loss turns into your biggest enemy. I mean, it doesn't make it unplayable but it's quite annoying when I lose 15 mins of experience because of 1 second of lag. I can't see why this game cannot have an offline single player campaign and my rating will stay at 9/10 until this becomes the reality.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Path of Exile is not for everyone. It's pretty much Diablo 2 with a watered down color palette, a less immersive setting, and a super intense skill tree... oh the skill tree! It deserved to be in a better game. It's beautiful!http://www.pathofexile.com/passive-skill-treeThat web page contains everything you need to know about Path of Exile. Judge it and you judge the game.I love the tree. I loved tinkering with possible builds on that website. I loved mapping out the path of my new Templar. I hated trudging through all the bland grind required to carry out the plan. For me, screwing around with the skill tree on their website was actually more fun than playing the game.Their forums hint at an active community and substantial end-game content. If you have the patience to make it pay off, I'm certain you'll greatly enjoy PoE. But after 8 hours I'm uninstalling and not looking back. Thumbs up for its small target audience.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												Path of exile is by far the most riveting and intriguing game I have ever played.  Through the variations of character selection and weapon/armor  types it is just absolutely superior to all other games.  Through my career of working for Riot games I have earned the opportunity to play and help design many variations of video games.  I truly believe that no other game compares to this one.  Path of exile is a game that you will not soon forget and will not easily get bored of. Path of exile leads you to many hours of action packed game play.  From the start of the game you are immediately thrown into action as you wash up on the shore and you find that everyone is dead around and you are surrounded by flesh eating zombies as well as many other creatures.  You have to fight your way through the unforgiving world as you collect new weapons, armor, stones, wands, and many other achievable items.  I believe that this is the best action RPG I have ever played.

												I have put  over 700+ hours on this game over the last year and a half. I have thoroughly enjoyed it and I am always keeping up with the changes that GGG are making to their game. It does have its faults, the crafting system is not rewarding to casual players and the LFG message board has turned into a trade board. GGG have stated they are wanting to address this in the near future and unlike many companies who say "the near future", I believe them. After everything is said and done, if you like personalization in all aspects of your ARPGS, nothing on the market comes close to Path of Exile.Edit, 11/26/2016: 2.6k hours and it's even better now and it just keeps getting better.

												Let me start by saying: this game is far superior to Diablo or any game of that kind. But if you just want a Diablo-like game to play for a little bit, then Path of Exile isn't for you. This game is really hard and requires a lot of time investment. However, if you can invest a lot of time to learn how to correctly build a character and level it up, then you will have a great time. The developers also release new content regularly for free.If you want to spend some money, you can purchase cosmetic items, which are completely optional, but also a little bit expensive (a full cosmetic armor set can cost around 20$). But since you can play absolutely for free, this sn't that big of a problem.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												A love letter to Diablo 2, and the deepest Action RPG I have ever played.  On top of that, they add things to make it deeper faster than I can keep up.  I play solo exclusively.It's not perfect, but for fans of the genre, I give it a 9.5/10.  For everyone else I give it a fair (non-inflated) score of 8.3.  The only noticeable problem is rubber-banding, though it also has a few telltale signs of being developed by a small studio, such as a few errors here and there in the dialogues, or voice-acting errors (incorrect emphasis, non-volume-normalized transitions showing that two recordings have been patched together into one, etc.).  Nothing that is likely to bother you, unless you are as anal as I am about these things and/or extremely observant.  One or two voice actors are terrible, but that's probably noticeable because most of the remaining did a superb job.If you hate action RPGS, then this one won't change your mind.  (Sorry.)  But if you're curious, give it a try, since it's free.None of the microtransactions are pay2win except for additional stash space, but they give you enough to start with that you won't feel cramped until you have multiple characters.  At that point you will no longer mind shelling out some cash for the game.  I think the developers have more than earned it, and you are likely to feel the same way at that point.The remainder of the business model consists of cosmetic microtransactions: costumes, weapon/skill effects, and pets.  But the vanilla costumes and effects are good enough to enjoy this game completely, in my opinion.Protip: Wait for a premium stash tab bundle sale.  Then spend $30-$40 on tabs, and that's probably all you will need for many years; i.e., you've essentially bought the game for yourself.  And that's a lot less than you spent just to be disappointed by Diablo 3.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												The only aRPG to rule them all. Can be a fairly hard learning curve. When you first start this game you either hate it or love it. It all really depends what kind of person you are. Your first character will practically ALWAYS fail, and 2 things can happen. You either get overwhelmed and can't get yourself to try again, or you can accept what happened and start up another character.(Perhaps the same build tweaked or another one entirely) For strategists and rpg enthuisests this game is  gold, over 1100 passive skill points to choose from with 7 different classes on the same tree. Meaning that there is no "right class" or "right build".(although some builds can be much easier/harder then others). A very unique skill system with an equally unique crafting system only makes characters more diverse with every player. If your skeptical, why not go ahead and try it, it's free and has no Pay2Win BS being shoved down your throat. If you love the game then you can buy microtransactions for cosmetic items, but isn't necassary at all. :)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												To start: this game is probably one of the best structured free to play games simply because the extent of the cash shop outside of cosmetic items is extra shared stash tabs (which you might need more tabs later on, but with a bit of organization it's usually not too bad). The way the skill system works allows for some nice builds, with a slotting and linking system not too different from Final Fantasy 7, like if you have a spell that shoots a fireball, you can put that gem in a socket in your armor and have it linked to a gem that makes it a spell totem and allows you to summon a totem that shoots fireballs. Keeping on with the Final Fantasy comparisons, the Passive tree is huge, with each class starting off in different areas of it, sort of similar to how Final Fantasy 10 was like and each point making a decent difference, and there is the choice of respeccing, but it's a bit tough to do (it partially requires a currency item for large respecs, you get respec points for some quests throughout the game but for anything more than 10 points it requires this currency item).A very unique aspect about the game as well is that it has no gold or equivalent, rather there are "Currency Items" that all have different uses like a scroll that identifies items, an orb that creates a rare from a normal weapon, and even an extremely rare item that can clone an item. All of these types of items take the place of gold and it works fairly well for the most part except for when trying to first start player trading, as it's a bit hard to learn the rates of all the items if you're hard pressed to get a certain item/currency.As for the gameplay, it feels good, especially with critical hits where if certain elements crit, they'll have a different effect, like if an Ice spell crits the enemies that get hit by it are frozen. There are also different leagues that change up how the game itself works, and even race leagues that are only open for usually an hour and earns you "Season Points" for collecting and getting alternate artwork uniques in game. It plays really well with certain builds getting ludicrously fast paced later on or if you want to take your time there are builds for that too, the game is very flexible when it comes to available builds but that has a problem for me: Desync. Since this game is online only it is always correcting itself to the server, and it's fairly common to end up getting warped to a different area that you were earlier because the server didn't think you were actually able to walk somewhere when you could (for example you got surrounded but were able to get out of it, sometimes the server will warp you back into it because it thought the tiny opening you walked out of was closed.) For the impact this has on builds is simple: some builds just aren't viable because of the danger of being placed into an area you didn't want to go, and not to mention some skills just plain desync more often than others because of being movement skills/spells.In short: The game is pretty much perfect in my opinion except for desync, which is a very large issue that can really kill any enjoyment I'm having no matter where I'm at in the game if it happens in a fatal way.Score: 4/5

content:
Posted: March 28
												Holy crap this game is addictive. If you like anything about the Diablo series, this is the game for you. While it is free to play and has microtransactions for support, most of them are only for cosmetic and convienience items. You can pick up silly stuff like visual effects for your weapons and footprints or even a pet to follow you around. The only really beneficial purchases I found were inventory expansions that would probably be boderline necessary in the later game. Speaking of late game, be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to grinding and exploring before you are anywhere near leveled up or powerful. While its farly easy to outpace the starting areas, the game has a ton of content and it wil take a huge ammount of time to level up a single character to 80. And while we are forwarning, its also not one of those hold your hand and guide you through everything kind of games. It will giive you general directions and show you the basics of controls then you are on your own. Want to know how a spell or weapon works? Read the detail screens then put it on and try it out. There is no real explination to anything aside form short decriptive texts on items and abilities. Be prepared to work to learn this game, while its not as brutal as Dark Souls, it will not hold your hand and tell you when to hit "A".Overall, this is a fantastic game but will devour your free time if you let it. I've had to cut back recently because I know that if I start a game I will feel the need to continue for hours before I find a reasonable stopping point. Absolutly worth the time though, so go try it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Whenever I was young, I used to drop thousands of hours into Diablo II. Every waking moment of my life was spent grinding my way to max level on all characters, gathering immense amounts of loot, and playing around with friends for hours at a time. The game offered me massive amounts of reward, enjoyability, and replayability. So, naturally, when I heard that Blizzard was coming out with a new Diablo game, I thought my prayers had been answered. No more watered-down Triple-A games; this was it, my love of gaming was supposed to pool back into me with Diablo III. Then I was disappointed - severely disappointed. Diablo III was nothing like the game I had played back in the day and I couldn't understand how Blizzard could screw up something so beautiful. With nothing left to turn to, I sauntered about the internet, searching for the ARPG that would take me away from the pain Blizzard had brought to myself. Torchlight was decent, but nothing too special. Drakensang was okay, but nothing to write home about. Then I stumbled upon Path of Exile. I was hesitant, to be honest with you. The game looked solid from the screenshots, but I could never really know unless I downloaded it. Let me tell you, after 400 hours of this game, this is completely raising the standards for ARPGs and nothing (as of the date on this review) could ever come close to the quality of this game.  A massive skill tree, making for complete build diversity.  Overwhelmingly brilliant, lore-based atmospheres.  Visually stunning; what Diablo should have been.  Endless amounts of fun, especially with friends.  Developers that actually care! Amazing F2P business model.I will forever be loyal to Path of Exile. This gave me my love of gaming back. This is what Diablo III should have been and wishes it was. If you're not sold yet, go ahead and download the game for a trial run. Every bit of content is free and there's nothing to lose. I guarantee you won't ever regret it.Update for Atlas of WorldsMy review was done before the Atlas of Worlds expansion hit and I would like to reassure anyone wondering: yes, this expansion is amazing and, yes, the game is still just as good as it has always been.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												Time to write a proper review this time. WARNING - LONG :) TL:DR at the bottom.Path of Exile is a hardcore ARPG produced by Grinding Gear Games (GGG). The game has 7 different classes, one of which can only be unlocked further on in the story. Don't let that put you off though. The classes simply determine where you start on the gigantic passive skill tree (more on that later) and what your base attributes are. Attributes consist of strength (red), dexterity (green) and intelligence (blue). Items and skills have attribute requirements that must be met before the item can be equipped or used, with higher level items requiring a higher attribute level. Once again, don't worry if you are a witch and need more strength to equip that one item as you can get attributes from several places (again, explained later).PoE centres around chopping, smashing, shooting, burning, freezing, shocking or poisoning your way throughout an expansive storymode campaign consisting of four Acts with three difficulties: Normal, Cruel and Merciless. Normal is a nice introduction to game mechanics and build theorycrafting and creation. Enemies are easy enough to kill and you level your character reasonably quickly. Once you have completed Act 4, you can take a portal to Cruel difficulty and start again from Act 1 with your current character. Cruel begins to test the defences of your build sich as your resistances to elemental and physical damage. Merciless is where things get tough. Even your standard skeleton WILL kill you if you let your guard down or go AFK in a dungeon (seriously, don't do this). There are literally thousands of possible build ideas to centre around and either follow or diversify. Your build however will focus primarily on a specific set of skills.Skills in PoE are your abilities. The attacks, curses, auras and spells you use to decimate your foes. They take the form of coloured gems that you socket into your equipment. Skill gems have attribute requirements. For example, red gems need mainly strength. Attack skills use base stats from your weapon(s) and likely deal a % of your base damage as either physical or elemental, sometimes both. Curses are debuffs you apply to enemies (simple enough). Auras are powerful buffs that "reserve" a defined % of your maximum mana. And spells have a flat damage that scales with % modifiers from gear, usually completely ignoring a weapons base damage. Skill gems gain experience as you do, and they will eventually level up, drastically increasing their power but also increasing their attribute requirements. Gems can be added and removed at any time, even in the middle of a boss fight (if you absolutely must). A useful piece of knowledge: At level 20 (max level for gems), it will need 155 of a specific attribute. So keep that in mind. There are also support gems. These augment your active skills to give them a massive damage boost while also increasing their mana cost. Support gems only apply if they are linked to an active gem. Links are the little golden bars between sockets on gear. For a skill to be as powerful as you can get, a 5 link or 6 link will be reccomended, but not required. These are generally quite expensive but can be bought fairly cheaply for a plain white item with no modifiers. You can then craft the item with a selection of orbs and currency items.This is where the in-game monetary part of PoE must be explained because it can be confusing for new players. There is no single currency, i.e - gold. Instead there are 24 different types of orbs and scrolls that all have different values are rarities. To save me from typing them all, here is a link to the forum page explaining what they all do. https://www.pathofexile.com/item-data/currencyYou use these orbs to change attributes on your gear, making them (hopefully) more powerful and beneficial to your character. You can also trade these with other players for items. The two trading orbs are almost always Chaos orbs (fairly easy to get) and Exalted orbs (a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to get. You have a 0.055% to get an Exalt from a monster). Get a lot of orbs and you are considered "rich". Please note, in almost 350 hours of playing I have found about 40 chaos orbs, 2 divine orbs and 1 exalted orb. Don't expect to get rich quickly unless you are the living embodiment of good RNG.This is most likely a lot to take in. There are many, many, MANY more aspects of the game, however they will need to be explained by someone else or discovered on your own as my fingers hurt from all this typing. Play the game, get stuck in and you WILL gain wealth and power. Try as many different builds as you want, or stick with one character to pour all your orbz into. TL:DR - Amazingly complex and addictive gameplay and a robust and rewarding economy. And you wanna know the best part? Everything is free. All the storyline is free. No hidden paywalls to unlock high level items. Free expansions. Free endgame. The devs are so non-greedy it is almost staggering, that they would put a game of this quality for everyone to enjoy. There is a cash shop containing cosmetics, skill skins and extra stash tabs (for the loot hoarders), and never once is it advertised with a huge banner ad plastered across your screen. Or even a tiny one in the top corner. I almost felt obliged to buy some extra stash tabs (I'm definitely a hoarder) and a few skins and I still feel like I robbed GGG, like I pirated a costly game.Overall rating: 10/10 - best ARPG ever released (along with Diablo II of course)

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Path of Exile is a FREE 2 PLAY!! action roleplaying hack and slash game comparable to the likes of Diablo 2 and the Dungeon Siege games. You play as an exile facing the harshness of the continent of Wraeclast, fighting enemies and exploring the land but mostly HOARDING items. The game allows to experience the story through 6 classes from the start plus another one that is unlocked by completing the storyline. It uses a third person or an overhead view and combat is lucid and unstiff. The world of Wraeclast is really beautiful, the dark artstyle compliments the tone. The skill tree is very diverse allowing vast customization of your character. The weapons are very diverse through different modifiers and items are tradable amongst players. The game has a PvP and Co-op options which allows you to interact with others or your friends through your journey across Wraeclast. Let's talk about the free2play model, it is not Pay2Win. Everything that you can purchase is cosmetics or stash space which does not affect the game. The game is regularly updated and devs seem very dedicated to the game. Rating: 92/100

												Let me start by saying: this game is far superior to Diablo or any game of that kind. But if you just want a Diablo-like game to play for a little bit, then Path of Exile isn't for you. This game is really hard and requires a lot of time investment. However, if you can invest a lot of time to learn how to correctly build a character and level it up, then you will have a great time. The developers also release new content regularly for free.If you want to spend some money, you can purchase cosmetic items, which are completely optional, but also a little bit expensive (a full cosmetic armor set can cost around 20$). But since you can play absolutely for free, this sn't that big of a problem.

												When I first entered the game, I was expecting the worst. I honestly didn't expect what I was about to see in this wonderful game.The good:God damn the skilltrees are absolutely MASSIVE. I mean literally my entire screen is filled with buttons and different paths to many different places, and I'm not exaggerating in the slightest!The graphics are fine, the blood is great! The game looks great!It reminds me heavily of Diablo.It's FREE. Like, literally 100% free, sure there are microtransactions in game but that's just to make you look good and to buy more stash space, really, it doesn't give people an advantage.The questline is enjoyable and I'm only just starting out in it.The gem system in which gems give you special abilities is really cool and I think it fits perfectly.The bad:The animations for the attacks could do with a bit more... Oomph, they don't feel very powerful at the moment. (Disclaimer: The abilities are not weak, it is just they look weak)The entrances to places need to look better (The white box that appears over the entrances blocks what is there to be seen, it's intruding on the atmosphere of the game!)The map is pretty bad looking, it needs a graphical update (It works, but it looks bad)In short: I would highly recommend this game, I'm beginning to like it more than Diablo 3 at the moment, and I've only played it for a bit.Definitely get this game, it's free and it's great fun, what else do you need in a game?!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Overview: Path of ExileThis game is technically an MMO, but you will seldom encounter other players unless you choose to invite them to a squad with you. If it weren't for global chat, you may or may not realize that anyone else even owns the game while you're not in a major city. The gameplay is very dungeon-crawler(esque) with a good deal of lootfest and skill tree elements. Storyline: lol didn't read it, nobody has time for that (doubting anyone has time to read reviews either, but these devs deserve the time it took to give the review). Difficulty: initially there is only a normal difficulty, but a character can access a higher difficulty (cruel, the merciless) after beating the quest line on their current difficulty. Additionally, you can create normal or hardcore characters, the difference being that hardcore characters recieve better loot, but on death, they convert to standard characters, and all their gear becomes standard gear (and cannot be traded back to a hardcore character).Pros: 1) Microtransactions aren't needed for late game.. in fact, there is nothing you can buy with money that results in an in-game advantage beyond a larger storage chest. 2) Character Balance and Variety. There are nearly infinite amounts of viable character builds and skills, not just 2-3 "use these or always lose" web builds for "op classes" - from what I've seen, the classes are surprisingly well balanced.3) Community. There are usually a lot of people chatting in global, and many people are willing to provide help either in-game or just give advice on items if you're inclined to ask. As always on the internet, there's a healthy amount of salt, and a few trolls, but such is the price we pay for gaming with other people.4) Audio. The ambient sounds and the soundtracks for the game are both excellent, and the character attack sound effects manage to avoid being irritating although you end up hearing the same ones hundreds of times in the course of an hour.5) Details. The devs clearly spent enough time in other games to understand what's annoying in an mmo, and they did their best to remove those elements. Most notably, potions don't clutter your inventory - instead, you can carry up to 5 potions, which refill as you slay enemies. The game doesn't have currency, instead players trade with chaos/fusing orbs, materials which can actually be used to upgrade items, rather than exclusively be used for buying and selling.Cons:1) Repetition. Although the creatures and attacks change, but essentially every level plays out the same. It's quite grind-heavy in that even if you progress through new areas as soon as you finish the quests, the actual gameplay remains redundant.2) Actually.. being bored by the redundancy of combat is my only complaint. Although boredom is a death sentence in most games, I think I'll still keep playing this one... and even if you do quit if you become bored, there's easily 20 hours of early-game content which you'll probably complete before reaching that point.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												To start: this game is probably one of the best structured free to play games simply because the extent of the cash shop outside of cosmetic items is extra shared stash tabs (which you might need more tabs later on, but with a bit of organization it's usually not too bad). The way the skill system works allows for some nice builds, with a slotting and linking system not too different from Final Fantasy 7, like if you have a spell that shoots a fireball, you can put that gem in a socket in your armor and have it linked to a gem that makes it a spell totem and allows you to summon a totem that shoots fireballs. Keeping on with the Final Fantasy comparisons, the Passive tree is huge, with each class starting off in different areas of it, sort of similar to how Final Fantasy 10 was like and each point making a decent difference, and there is the choice of respeccing, but it's a bit tough to do (it partially requires a currency item for large respecs, you get respec points for some quests throughout the game but for anything more than 10 points it requires this currency item).A very unique aspect about the game as well is that it has no gold or equivalent, rather there are "Currency Items" that all have different uses like a scroll that identifies items, an orb that creates a rare from a normal weapon, and even an extremely rare item that can clone an item. All of these types of items take the place of gold and it works fairly well for the most part except for when trying to first start player trading, as it's a bit hard to learn the rates of all the items if you're hard pressed to get a certain item/currency.As for the gameplay, it feels good, especially with critical hits where if certain elements crit, they'll have a different effect, like if an Ice spell crits the enemies that get hit by it are frozen. There are also different leagues that change up how the game itself works, and even race leagues that are only open for usually an hour and earns you "Season Points" for collecting and getting alternate artwork uniques in game. It plays really well with certain builds getting ludicrously fast paced later on or if you want to take your time there are builds for that too, the game is very flexible when it comes to available builds but that has a problem for me: Desync. Since this game is online only it is always correcting itself to the server, and it's fairly common to end up getting warped to a different area that you were earlier because the server didn't think you were actually able to walk somewhere when you could (for example you got surrounded but were able to get out of it, sometimes the server will warp you back into it because it thought the tiny opening you walked out of was closed.) For the impact this has on builds is simple: some builds just aren't viable because of the danger of being placed into an area you didn't want to go, and not to mention some skills just plain desync more often than others because of being movement skills/spells.In short: The game is pretty much perfect in my opinion except for desync, which is a very large issue that can really kill any enjoyment I'm having no matter where I'm at in the game if it happens in a fatal way.Score: 4/5

												Let me start by saying: this game is far superior to Diablo or any game of that kind. But if you just want a Diablo-like game to play for a little bit, then Path of Exile isn't for you. This game is really hard and requires a lot of time investment. However, if you can invest a lot of time to learn how to correctly build a character and level it up, then you will have a great time. The developers also release new content regularly for free.If you want to spend some money, you can purchase cosmetic items, which are completely optional, but also a little bit expensive (a full cosmetic armor set can cost around 20$). But since you can play absolutely for free, this sn't that big of a problem.

												Beautiful game, it is what Diablo 3 should have been and so much more, having played since open beta, I am happy to see it on steam! The gameplay is wonderful, if a bit desync prone. It boasts a massive passive skill tree, one that would take studying to even comprehend, and a wide varierty of mixable skills, mind boggling amounts noting the randomized drops and active skill links! The only downside to this game really, is its tendency to desync during heavy amounts of combat and when theres plenty of mobs on your screen.3 Year Update: So, this game has gotten so much better over the past three years, in that time problems have come and gone, and currently, I have nothing but praise for this game, it's a masterpiece of an ARPG, my hours on Steam do not reflect my hours on it, because I play it frequently at a friend's house using her computer, I would whole heartedly recommend this, all prior praise holds true, and since then, more content has been created and added, if you like ARPGs, play this, and thank us all later.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												A love letter to Diablo 2, and the deepest Action RPG I have ever played.  On top of that, they add things to make it deeper faster than I can keep up.  I play solo exclusively.It's not perfect, but for fans of the genre, I give it a 9.5/10.  For everyone else I give it a fair (non-inflated) score of 8.3.  The only noticeable problem is rubber-banding, though it also has a few telltale signs of being developed by a small studio, such as a few errors here and there in the dialogues, or voice-acting errors (incorrect emphasis, non-volume-normalized transitions showing that two recordings have been patched together into one, etc.).  Nothing that is likely to bother you, unless you are as anal as I am about these things and/or extremely observant.  One or two voice actors are terrible, but that's probably noticeable because most of the remaining did a superb job.If you hate action RPGS, then this one won't change your mind.  (Sorry.)  But if you're curious, give it a try, since it's free.None of the microtransactions are pay2win except for additional stash space, but they give you enough to start with that you won't feel cramped until you have multiple characters.  At that point you will no longer mind shelling out some cash for the game.  I think the developers have more than earned it, and you are likely to feel the same way at that point.The remainder of the business model consists of cosmetic microtransactions: costumes, weapon/skill effects, and pets.  But the vanilla costumes and effects are good enough to enjoy this game completely, in my opinion.Protip: Wait for a premium stash tab bundle sale.  Then spend $30-$40 on tabs, and that's probably all you will need for many years; i.e., you've essentially bought the game for yourself.  And that's a lot less than you spent just to be disappointed by Diablo 3.

												I have played this game, time to time all the way from beta. It has always been free to play (devs get money only for graphical microtransactions.)This game offers everything that would be expected from a D2 like Hack 'n' Slash game, and even more. (atleast not from GGG)-Race seasons and ladder seasons (New leagues are started and old ones are merged to standard leagues)-HC leagues, play till you die. I personally love it.-Thousands of hours to play, and never reach "end".Cons:-Servers can be quite laggy (make GGG more money = better servers?)-Huge skilltree and lots of skill gems and supports can be difficult to a new player.-If you're looking for AAA-grapichs, sorry.All in all it's a free game, why wouldn't you try it?

content:
Posted: March 28
												Holy crap this game is addictive. If you like anything about the Diablo series, this is the game for you. While it is free to play and has microtransactions for support, most of them are only for cosmetic and convienience items. You can pick up silly stuff like visual effects for your weapons and footprints or even a pet to follow you around. The only really beneficial purchases I found were inventory expansions that would probably be boderline necessary in the later game. Speaking of late game, be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to grinding and exploring before you are anywhere near leveled up or powerful. While its farly easy to outpace the starting areas, the game has a ton of content and it wil take a huge ammount of time to level up a single character to 80. And while we are forwarning, its also not one of those hold your hand and guide you through everything kind of games. It will giive you general directions and show you the basics of controls then you are on your own. Want to know how a spell or weapon works? Read the detail screens then put it on and try it out. There is no real explination to anything aside form short decriptive texts on items and abilities. Be prepared to work to learn this game, while its not as brutal as Dark Souls, it will not hold your hand and tell you when to hit "A".Overall, this is a fantastic game but will devour your free time if you let it. I've had to cut back recently because I know that if I start a game I will feel the need to continue for hours before I find a reasonable stopping point. Absolutly worth the time though, so go try it.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												To start: this game is probably one of the best structured free to play games simply because the extent of the cash shop outside of cosmetic items is extra shared stash tabs (which you might need more tabs later on, but with a bit of organization it's usually not too bad). The way the skill system works allows for some nice builds, with a slotting and linking system not too different from Final Fantasy 7, like if you have a spell that shoots a fireball, you can put that gem in a socket in your armor and have it linked to a gem that makes it a spell totem and allows you to summon a totem that shoots fireballs. Keeping on with the Final Fantasy comparisons, the Passive tree is huge, with each class starting off in different areas of it, sort of similar to how Final Fantasy 10 was like and each point making a decent difference, and there is the choice of respeccing, but it's a bit tough to do (it partially requires a currency item for large respecs, you get respec points for some quests throughout the game but for anything more than 10 points it requires this currency item).A very unique aspect about the game as well is that it has no gold or equivalent, rather there are "Currency Items" that all have different uses like a scroll that identifies items, an orb that creates a rare from a normal weapon, and even an extremely rare item that can clone an item. All of these types of items take the place of gold and it works fairly well for the most part except for when trying to first start player trading, as it's a bit hard to learn the rates of all the items if you're hard pressed to get a certain item/currency.As for the gameplay, it feels good, especially with critical hits where if certain elements crit, they'll have a different effect, like if an Ice spell crits the enemies that get hit by it are frozen. There are also different leagues that change up how the game itself works, and even race leagues that are only open for usually an hour and earns you "Season Points" for collecting and getting alternate artwork uniques in game. It plays really well with certain builds getting ludicrously fast paced later on or if you want to take your time there are builds for that too, the game is very flexible when it comes to available builds but that has a problem for me: Desync. Since this game is online only it is always correcting itself to the server, and it's fairly common to end up getting warped to a different area that you were earlier because the server didn't think you were actually able to walk somewhere when you could (for example you got surrounded but were able to get out of it, sometimes the server will warp you back into it because it thought the tiny opening you walked out of was closed.) For the impact this has on builds is simple: some builds just aren't viable because of the danger of being placed into an area you didn't want to go, and not to mention some skills just plain desync more often than others because of being movement skills/spells.In short: The game is pretty much perfect in my opinion except for desync, which is a very large issue that can really kill any enjoyment I'm having no matter where I'm at in the game if it happens in a fatal way.Score: 4/5

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
5/5 ::::: Essential PlayI've never played Diablo 3, but this game makes me not mind. Surely the best action RPG on the market, and it's free. How can you not give it a try? If you preferred the skill trees of Diablo II over the third entry's approach, you have to check out Path of Exile: certainly one of the most enormous and complex skill trees I've ever encountered in a game, though I've heard the meta is apparently much more simple.There's a fairly crazy amount of depth to this game. Passive skills are earned on the skill tree, but active skills are found in the form of gems, items that are socketed (and unsocketed) into your equipment. There seems to be a lot of complexity to the system and I've barely scratched the surface myself. Beginners will definitely want to research good builds online at some point. Then there's the player hideout which you can customize to your hearts' content, and a whole world of upper-level play I haven't reached yet; you could say that the game hasn't really even begun on your first playthrough.It plays like a single player game, but it's online. I haven't grouped into any parties or traded yet, so the most noticeable online feature for me is the global chat. The one significant edit I'm bothering to make in this review after investing 100+ hours is to say: chat is addicting, but the community is pretty toxic. Channel 1 is the worst, but every channel is full of your typical Internet nihilists. This being one of my first online games, I have no idea if this is to be expected. Luckily, there is the incredible feature to turn global chat OFF. It completely transforms the game, I recommend giving it a try! Difficulty is challenging throughout; players may well breeze through earlier sections, but find themselves needing to rethink things once the difficulty ramps up at various points, especially with the relatively recently-added fourth act. Finally, did I mention it's free? Give it a try; you may just find your new obsession.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												If you loved Diablo II and haven't been satisfied with an aRPG since, this is the game for you. Now, I've enjoyed a few (wrote a review a couple of months back for Titan Quest which I still think is a great game), but this one is by far the most reminiscant of the greatest of them all.Where this game surpasses all others is flexibility. With the enormous passive tree and the skill gem and linking system the possibilities are nearly endless. and these possibilities exist for each class.Now I must also add, the one weakness of the game is also in its flexibility. It's entirely possible to build a character that will become useless past a certain difficulty. It can be very hard to get the correct gear in combination with skill gems that will fit in that gear. But these challenges just increase the reward when you get something that works, rather than guaranteeing you with a functional build from the get go by boxing you into a very specific path (a la Diablo 3... and no hate for D3 it's just an entirely different beast)btw... this is FREE. So even if the good only sounds okay and the bad sounds really rough, it's still worth it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2013
												Path of Exile is a very interesting game. With heavy emphasis on mirroring a big portion of Diablo II's successes, Path of Exile presents itself as a serviceable and even downright appealing in a truly Free-to-Play game focusing on the idea of "Ethical Microtransactions."As an action-RPG, it naturally gets compared to the likes of Diablo III, with a lot of players touting the oft-uttered "This is what Diablo III should have been" among forumgoers. The comparison is hard to avoid since the game has similar mechanics but with a stronger emphasis on having choices with consequence.Visually, the game's aesthetic is much more dark. In line with it's inspiration for gothic architecture and a lot of depressing atmospheres. Proper use of lighting to provide contrast in dark places in junction with lighting reduction as you're damaged really brings in the sense of dread when you are outnumbered and it becomes a matter of seconds before you die.The game's soundtrack is absolutely stunning. They blend well with the environments without sounding far too similar to that of it's inspiration.  Ambient audio also adds another line of what sounds like a full range of what belongs in each stage.The passive skill tree is daunting at first, but once you manage to realize it's merely a presentation that can overwhelm you and that everything goes from point-to-point, it becomes fairly simple to figure out how to use it. Each class starts in a position and moves along the "rails" one by one as they gain levels and skill points.  Choices are fairly permanent, which is quite refreshing in an age where games continually make such decisions meaningless by offering people a chance to try again with no dedication.Active skills could be compared to things like Final Fantasy VII's materia system. Each piece of gear will have a slot, which is color-coded for gem type. Green, Blue, Red, or elusive Whites. Some are support gems that enhance active abilities. Some are trigger gems, ones that cause an effect when triggered by play.  All of which gain XP and level up when you use them.Despite being a Free to Play game, Path of Exile manages to hold fairly fast to it's "Ethical Microtransactions" platform which is to say that none of their purchasable items are to give any mechanical benefit. While people can argue that character slots (of which you start with 24) and stash tabs (of which you start with 4, and can be fine with) are a mechanical advantage, the game is very much "Free to Play" in the literal sense.  Gear drop rates are not based on cash spent. Drop quality is not based on cash spent. You can't buy better gear, and you can't buy experience potions.So, Path of Exile has so far proven itself tremendously. It does a great job keeping itself reigned in, shying away from the easy-money route that other Free-to-Play games do, while providing an experience that even the bigger powerhouses in the market failed to provide.Play this game. If you loved Diablo II, you'll be hard pressed to not enjoy this.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This is a very solid ARPG, at this point it has become a cliche to say that it's a better successor to Diablo 2 than Diablo 3. The passive skill system may seem a bit weird at first, but it's a very good gameplay mechanic once you get used to it. Loot is also great, you should have no problem keeping your characters equipped nicely through persistent playing.Active skills are realized through gems, which you can freely remove from items after inserting them. Gems level up on their own, and can additionally be "augmented" with special support gems, which is overall a very fresh mechanic that works quite well.The best part is that there are no "pay to win" mechanics in this game, everything you can buy with real cash is cosmetic (with the exception of extra chest pages and character slots, but you're given enough of those for free anyway).The only area where the game is a bit weak is the story, it doesn't really shine with anything special there. This personally doesn't bother me as I play ARPGs primarily for the gameplay, I didn't even pay much attention to what was going on in Diablo 2's storyline. Even POE's story beats the quality of writing in Diablo 3 though :)

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												This game is so ridiculously good.  I started playing it in beta before it was on Steam after a friend introduced me to it, and the game has grown so much since then.  It has so many unique things to offer.  For those who want to know more...I will attempt to explain some of the things you will need to know from the start.  It may sound daunting, but it isn't as difficult to pick up as it sounds.A quick sidenote.  Yes, it's free.  No, it's not pay to win.  There isn't a single thing in the store that gives an advantage over other players.  It's filled with a ton of cosmetics, bank tabs, and character slots.  None of which you will actually need, they're just nice to have.For starters, there is the incredibly large passive skill tree with over 1300 passives on it.  All 7 characters are positioned in different spots on this skill tree.  The "pure" characters are positioned on the passive skill tree directly within the three core attributes.  The Marauder with strength, the Ranger with dexterity, and the Witch (my personal favorite) with intelligence.  The "hybrid" characters are the Duelist with strength/dexterity, the Templar with strength/intelligence, the Shadow with dexterity/intelligence, and the Scion (who isn't unlocked until later in the game) with strength/dexterity/intelligence.  There are also jewels which can be socketed into the passive skill tree, that grant various buffs and abilities and sometimes alter other passives within a certain radius.Next is your equipment.  Weapons, armor, accessories, and flasks.  There's a ton of possible stats you can get, and every weapon and armor piece will have a random amount of colored sockets on them, some linked together and some not (I will explain that more later as it ties in with your active skills).  As for the flasks, you can have up to five equipped and those are what you use to replenish your health and mana.  There's also some with a more niche purpose.Your active skills come in the form of skill gems.  These gems come in three colors: red, blue, and green.  And what colors are those sockets on your weapons and armor?  Red, blue, and green.  You get skill gems as drops and quest rewards, and then socket them in the apropriately colored slot on your equipment.  A piece of equipment can have anywhere from one to six sockets on it, depending on a number of factors.  And if multiple sockets are linked together, then the gems in those sockets can work together.  For example, you could have a skill gem that lets you raise a zombie, and then another one linked to that which makes your zombie do more damage.The story is great, the soundtrack is cool, the NPCs are awesome.  The game has full voice acting.  Overall things have a really dark and gritty theme to it, and it's done very well.  The enemies and bosses and even the areas get progressively more and more creepy.  There's currently a total of four acts, each with their own unique things to offer.There is so much more I could talk about, I've barely scratched the surface.  The Forsaken Masters, corrupted areas, Divination cards, hideouts, leagues/events, the barter system (no actual currency in the game), all the items that can be used to alter your equipment, plus the special maps for endgame...but you can learn it for yourself when you play.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												It was the summer of 1997, i was 11 years old; one night, at some friends of friends house, in a dark room, a bright monitor enlighted me the path, a wierd music attracted me to the PC; there i saw Diablo for the first time. I feel in love with it at first sight. When a friend told me they were making a sequel, i actually started useing internet for the first time; i never had a reason to connect before, now i was seeking every piece of information about Diablo II. It was summer, it was hot, and in my hands i had a copy of Diablo II, i was one of the most happy nerdfag ever seen. I don't know why but i started playing on-line as first experience (the phone bill was bad that summer, very bad); after that, i played for other 4-5 years that harsh evil game called Diablo II, both in soft and hard-core. It was around 2008 when i saw the website of Diablo III, a brief video of a Barbarian smashing enemies, with havok, sparkles and all. Couldn't wait so i started playing D2 again, and again until 2012, when Diablo III came out. With all my friends we were there, ready to have it. We were there, on team speak, playing hard, but the feel was kinda different, we couldn't tell what was it; we were playing the new chapter, the last piece of the story, with new mechanics and all; but something wasn't there, i played hundreds of hours but couldn't find it anywhere in it; it was passion. The passion to make every detail matter, every little piece of the puzzle match the greater design. This is Path of Exile, an artistic passionate song to a game genre that was dying; Grinding Gear Games picked their favourite game, which i guess is Diablo II, and from its ashes, they made something truly new and innovative.(I don't play PoE on steam, i play it on their original Launcher, got many chars above 85, some also HC)

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												This is a complete head-scratcher.  It's been around too long to not have a succesful business model, but I'm astonished at how ethical the microtransactions are in this F2P Diablo-alike.No, no hyperbole, I'm truly astonished.  I mean, it's almost hard to find the microtransactions, and they come in three flavors: Extra character slots, extra equipment tabs, and cosmetic appearances.I don't know how many character slots PoE has, because playing one character is dozens of hours of playtime.  Playing two (it's nice to have a "solo" character and a "co-op" character, which you can do without paying anything) is easily over 100 hours of playtime.I still have enough stash tabs to organize my stuff into appropriate tabs.  I might need more tabs some 200 hours into the game.  Maybe?And there's a huge amount of things to upgrade.  Weapons and armor that has slots for skill gems, but also "currency" items to buy items from vendors (no gold?  Yes, no gold) that also affects your items.  This helps the "trash loot" and "RNG gods" problems so much.  If you find an item with great slots, but not enough else,  you can enchant, disenchant, renchant, add more enchantments, craft on more enchantments, etc.  If you find a great item with poor numbers of slots, you can reroll slot, reroll links, etc.  How do you get these items in this Free-To-Play game, you ask? ...from Grinding Gear Games, the answer is "NOT by paying money.  Ever."  You want those items, you find them or you trade for them.  But wait, doesn't that create a third-party economy that might sell stuff out of channel?  Maybe, but GGG resfuses to compromise the quality and feel of a game the depth of Diablo II to try and skim some profits.The skill tree (web, really) is just bananas, too, in a great way.  The selection of passive skills and abilities mixed with the equipment in this game encourages, again, Diablo II leves of creative character building, with a shocking amount of high-end viable oddball creations.  (Just be aware of the vastly larger phase-space of useless characters you can make along the way, and assume you won't get your first character right.  Really, it's okay).The difficulty level make for a fun experience for those looking for a fun ARPG romp, but challenging theorycrafting challenges at the higher levels for hardcore players.Best game I've played all year?  Maybe.  Most?  Hands down.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												★★★☆☆A classic-style ARPG, with deep playstyle customization.  + Potion depth+ Upgrade items+ Fitting graphics+ Leagues and races+ FF7 Materia-esq system+ FF10 Sphere Grid-esq system+- Endless junk loot+- Weird currency system+- Classes only effect your starting position on the Sphere Grid+- Highly customizable loot filter, that requires editing an external script file+- While most microtransactions are vanity-only, there are a few pay2win things, like stash tabs+- Playstyle is super customizable, but can't easily be changed, without creating a new character- Is there a story?- No damage numbers- Meaningless text walls- Ugly loading screen with no animation- Attacks have a stupid high chance to miss- Classes are gender locked and not-customizable- No transmogs, probably because vanity cash shop- Leveling abilities increases their mana cost, often making it pointless- Can't easily join other players, and coop doesn't work very well in general- Balance issues.  Entire screens of enemies die in a single hit.  Abilities vary from worthless to madness.  Bosses that 1shot you, after an entire dungeon of enemies that did 0 damage.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												Daybreak. The first rays of sunlight claw their way through the dawn and glint off my monitor like shards of glass, mocking me. I briefly see my reflection, haggard and inhuman, before I whip the curtains closed. I do not know how long I've been here; the passage of time means little to me now. My friends and family have stopped calling, their pleading voices falling harshly on my ears like a horrible, otherworldly tongue. I haven't spoken in so long that I've forgotten how to form the words. Crit chance and dexterity, skill gems and passive points. These are the only things I value. I have created a new instance in life, destroying the old. This is what I've become. This is my exile.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
Product received for free
												Path of Exile is an Free to Play online action role-playing game.  The player controls a single character from an overhead perspective and explores large outdoor areas and underground caves or dungeons, battling monsters and fulfilling quests from NPCs to gain experience points and equipment. All areas aside from the central encampments are randomly generated for increased re-playability. While all players on a single server can freely mingle in encampments, gameplay outside of encampments is highly instanced, providing every player or party with an isolated map to freely explore.  The game borrows heavily from the Diablo series, particularly Diablo II.   The graphics, sound, gameplay looks pretty good.  For more info:

												The best ARPG on the market today, and it's FREE! No pay-to-win BS, either; all you can buy are cosmetic effects for spells and equipment, more stash space for hoarding items, and character slots. Most people won't even need to buy the latter, though, because you start with 24 slots for free. Endless character builds to try out, regular content updates and free expansions planned, on-going series of race events where you can compete and earn limited edition prizes... If you're a fan of the genre, there's no reason not to be playing this.My only complaint with this game is the de-sync. They had to make the game always-online to prevent cheating, but then to accomodate the fast-paced, highly reactive and tactical combat, they're constantly syncing game state between your client and the server... Which, when their servers are overloaded by the huge influx of players on Steam, can often mean rubber-banding or lag in performing actions. It's most frustrating when playing hardcore, and a half-second delay can be the difference between life and death. They've been working hard to alleviate such problems, so hopefully they can make it better soon.
