number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												So, you loved Diablo 2?  Loved LoD?  Hated how simplified and consoletastic Diablo 3 was?  Path of Exile is your fix.   Let me do you a favor though.  Your first character, learn the game.  Like melee?  Stay towards the south parts of the tree (Mara, Duelist, Ranger) if you like casters like myself, stick north.  Templar, Witch, and Shadow.  The skill tree needs to be seen first, go check it out online.  It's huge and VERY intimidating.  But once you start learning; it's also the single best character customization tool ever seen in an action RPG.  I cannot say this enough, this is what Blizzard failed against with Diablo 3.  Only Diablo 2 could compare, and the limitations of a game from 2000 show.  This is the one and true king of ARPG.  Shoutout to the staff as well for being highly active within the community.  Play this game, it's free and you will NOT regret it if you were a fan of the Diablo series before number 3.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I used to play Diablo 2 in the hay days and my god, I never thought I'd ever have the same enthralling dungeon crawling, loot craving fun like I had back then. But this satiates all that and more so. The claim is correct when people regard this as the true spiritual successor to D2. The monster bashing and the item drops are highly rewarding and it doesn't waste your time by shoving cutscenes down your throat (unlike D3) to continue your advent to better gear. Instead of active skillpoints you gain passive points to put in a massive web of skills. Although less instantly gratifying with earning passives for leveling, this is counteracted by receiving gems that act as active skills once you socket them in your gear. These gems are found either by completing quests or dropped by monsters you'ved killed. Any character can use any gem. Therefore the character you can build will be limitless. I can't say enough about this game and how much I've already enjoyed it. There are currently 3 acts and and a 4th said to be implemented in 2014. I cannot wait what Grinding Gear Games has in store for us. Hopefully act 4 will be in a snowy setting perhaps? That would be rather awesome.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Path of Exile is a F2P game with a great business model and consistent updates.I would say that, if you're going to play for a long time, you'll want to spend €10-20 on additional storage just so you've enough tabs to be able to get a drop, say "might want that later", throw it in and forget about it. That's the only maybe-necessary purchase.Lots of people play PoE for hundreds or thousands of hours, and spending ~ €15 on so many hours of entertainment has to be a good deal. I've only just gotten started in the game, but I can already see why so many of my friends have been speaking highly about it.Grinding Gear Games release an expansion every 6 months and new 'challenge leagues' every 3 months. A challenge league is where they make a change to the game in some way, or add new content which they're not sure should be implemented forever. It won't completely transform the game, but it's better than Diablo III's seasons which change nothing.I genuinely believe that both Path of Exile and Grinding Gear Games deserve your attention.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												This game takes a direction that Diablo 3 would have taken if the original Diablo 2 team worked on it. The skill tree is expansive with 1300+ passive skills to choose from, sadly you can not get all of them. The skill system is another great feature you equip skill gems into your gear to allow you to use your spells(which while equipped gain roughly 10% of the experience you gain and level up), this system in itself is quite extensive with support gems and linking sockets to further improve your spells. Just like any expansive RPG there are fetch quests but these have a refreshing feel to them they aren't too grindy or too much out of your way either. The map system in this game is wonderful allowing you to refresh each area so that you can grind if you wish, on normal difficulty I feel this is not needed at all, I have found myself over leveled a bit(which does impact your skill gems as you upgrade them they gain new requirements for you to meet and I keep finding myself needing to level my character up before being able to upgrade my skills but it doesn't take too long so you won't miss out on too much experience for your gems) for each new area I go to by just completing all the quests that I come too and clearing out all side areas. The game does feature a microtransaction shop but this game is far from pay to win, this shop is for cosmetic and stash items only. The game is truly free and even the updates are. Path of Exile is truly a wonderful game and i personally give it a 9/10 and would recommend this to any old school and new school ARPG players alike and if you are the latter then I suggest not playing it as if it were a modern-day ARPG.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												First thing: Get a friend to play with. A tank- damage or tank-healing group will anhilate everyone.Second Thing: Keep an eye on your health. Don't be afraid to use potions, they are not one timers, but each one has charges. You replenish charges by killing monsters. You stay in battle to kill monsters by drinking potions. Its an infinite loop.Third Thing: Don't get intimidated by the skill tree system. You will never, ever, get all the skills. Focus on the main skills, and the skills from where you are to there. Its best done in portions, rather than all at once.Fourth Thing: Have fun. Its a great game, with good combat, graphics, The developers are saying they are against Pay-2-Win, and so far, they are reinforcing it. Everything from the microtransaction store is all cosmetic. There may be some shady people offering "Legendary Loot X" for money through PayPal, but chances are, they will scam you. Don't focus on chat. IF you have a question, someone probably will help you. Other than that, ignore it. It is spammed by traders, who will post their offer multiple times in a row. It ruints the immersion of the game, which can be pretty immersive if  you play the right way.Above all else, have fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Ive been playing before the Steam release. PoE is truly a game i've never been bored of, whether i'm playing with my bf or playing solo. It might be hard to grasp and get into for someone completely new (what isn't though?), but once you get the hang of it and figure things out you become addicted.I have played Diablo II, and Diablo III. I never purchased Diablo III, I could barely play through the trial. I can't fully compare Path of Exile's likeliness and differences to Diablo III; and while it feels like Diablo II, I can't entirely say that because PoE just feels like, well, PoE. It is truly a free to play game, the only things you can buy are cosmetic effects and pets (weapon effects, alternate skill animations, armour glowy effects, footprint effects, etc). The various supporter packs they offer periodically let you purchase physcal merchandise bundled with other in-game goodies, again entirely cosmetic. A player who is serious about collecting and crafting might find that the 4 default stash tabs won't be of much help to them. PoE offers a premium stash tab bundle for about 20 USD, these go a looooong long way. If you've reached the point where you're thinking about crafting and investing then 20 USD is super affordable, especially for free game as well developed as this.  Someone had once said PoE is P2G; Pay to glow. This pretty much sums it up.Aside from that, PoE keeps me entertained with their 4 month challenge leagues. These leagues have their own set of rules and mods. It's always fun completing challenges and planning old builds around new changes, and even new builds entirely. Unique items designed by players and devs alike can drastically change a build for better or worse. With the skill tree being as huge as it is, you never run out of builds to try. You could be a witch and wield a bow, a ranger and wield a wand, it's satisfying planning out your build and reaching the point where it shines. End Game maps are both challenging and rewarding (to me at least, others will disagree ;) ) Path of Exile's frequent updates, whether they be bug fixes or new content, are always welcomed. I love seeing a game maintained and updated as well as PoE is.The Devs and staff take part in the community; they don't put out messages/updates and forget about their players. My personal experiences have been nothing but postive. Path of Exile is known for its desync problems. I've had my share of issues, especially while on hardcore servers. You can almost always tell when you are desynced. Some builds desync more than others too unfortunately, so if you are one of those people that likes to play hardcore only modes, PoE might not be for you. A simple /oos command fixes any sync issues, and if you can learn to play around the desync then it really is an enjoyable game. That is maybe the only downside to an otherwise outstanding game.As others have said, the game is completely free, so why not check it out? Whatever you decide, happy gaming! :)

Best of all it truly is free to play.  Money purchases are cosmetic or an increase in item storage capacity (which I'd wait for "tab" sales on that).  Download it and have fun!

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												This game is like playing Diablo 2, but with the rules and abilities greatly expanded. The freedom to sculpt characters into differing roles, or hybrid them completely leaves a wonderful amount of re-play value. I had some rubberbanding issues in certain areas of the game, but I have yet to find a game like this that doesn't have the rare moment of rubberbanding. One area that I must applaud is the gem/ability link. It actually forces you to consider some abilities and gear selections not just based on better stats, but more on sockets, and what to socket into a piece of gear. It does become a slight tedious to find that perfect set of gear, but then it makes the hard earned item that much more enjoyable. All in all I would give this game 8/10. Though Diablo-like, this game makes this genre of games refreshing, offering the freedoms the diablo games have quickly done away with.

content:

												The successor that D2 deserved, a dark gritty and unbelievably deep ARPG, incredibly original itemization, crafting, skill, talent and stats systems which blow other similar games out of the water.Made by a small indie team that I can hand on heart say have developed over the past 7 years the best game I have ever played. Crafted without compromise, made by gamers for gamers, and it shows in every detail.Beyond AAA+ quality, the game receives a interesting patch every two weeks and a major content update (mini expansion) every 4 months, it is free to play and without any pay to win elements, you can purchase cosmetic effects if you wish to support the company.Ruthlessly challenging even for a player with 2+ years experience in PoE and a lifetime of PC gaming, merciless for new players but unrivalled in the sense of character development and progression.Weather you have 1 or 100 hours a week to game there is content to be enjoyed. Highest metacrit user score ever, perfection incarnate, crafted with unrivalled love, nothing any large published game devloper can create could ever rival this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Path of Exile is a free to play, action RPG that draws heavy influence from the Diablo franchise while still managing to carve out its own niche. Developed by Grinding Gear Games, the game follows the player as one of six unique characters banished to Wraeclast, a dark and decrepit island where the worst degenerates of society are exiled to. You wake up on a shore during a storm and find that everyone on the ship, aside from you and another passenger, didn’t survive the wreckage. The other lone survivor is weak, but looks like he may live to see another day. That hope dashes quickly when a nearby corpse comes to life and finds him to be an attractive meal. Much to your benefit, there’s a nearby weapon that you can use to whack it over the head. Thus begins the bloody adventure that awaits you on Wraeclast.Path of Exile takes the dark atmosphere of the Diablo games then kicks it up another notch. This game is downright depressing. You start out alone and weak as a plethora of enemies clearly outnumber you. The beach is strewn with corpses, some lying on the ground and others impaled. Everyone you meet in the first town feels hopeless about their predicament. The motif of death and loss that persists throughout the game is a stark reminder of the way life is on Wraeclast: an everyday struggle to survive.Path of Exile is a simple, yet beautiful game. Animations, from character movements down to magic abilities, look perfect and perform seamlessly. The dark tones of the game are emphasized in the grittiness of the environments. There’s a great attention to detail, evident in the astounding variety of enemies. You’ll still find the standard zombies and skeletons, but beyond that the monsters you’ll find are both creative and terrifying. There’s no question that its graphical fidelity stands above other games in the free to play market.In such a polished game, it’s incredibly disappointing to see great inconsistency in the quality of Path of Exile’s sounds. Voice acting varies greatly. Each playable character is fully voice acted, and all six of them sound like real individuals, the emotion apparent in their tone and word choice. Other NPCs also sound great and you can really hear how desperate and helpless they feel, but some are just odd and out of place. There’s a strange mingling of accents among the inhabitants of Wraeclast, and a good chunk of them just sound cheesy. Attack sounds suffer the same fate in that some abilities feel impactful, and others feel like a slap on the wrist. The music is painfully average. It’s ambient and emphasizes the scale of the world, but that’s about it. It feels hollow and is reaching for emotion that it just can’t seem to produce. Overall, the sounds are very underwhelming and end up being one of the weakest parts of the experience. Path of Exile doesn’t stray far from the formula that made games like Diablo and Torchlight wildly successful. Rather, it sticks with the established conventions and executes them flawlessly. There are six classes, each with a specific role and playstyle. Hubs, or central towns, nestle amidst numerous dungeons where most of the action will take place. Gear is a huge focus of the game and you’ll find countless of pieces as you and hack and slash your way through Wraeclast. The game is difficult, unforgivingly so even from the start. Combat is similar to Diablo and Torchlight titles in that the player clicks on an enemy to auto-attack and selects hotkeys to activate abilities, making it simple and fun. It’s a formula that has proved successful and it holds true here. But it can feel like an all too familiar experience. By not branching too far from established norms of the genre, Grinding Gear Games chose to play it safe instead of going for innovation.However, one area in which Path of Exile stands above Diablo and Torchlight is its impressive lore. Each playable character is given a distinct personality and backstory showing why they were exiled to Wraeclast. Quests and conversations draw an image of the island before you arrived. Throughout the game world you’ll find stones laden with carved messages from prior inhabitants, telling the history of the island and the harrowing tales of those who scribed them. Walking away from these stones will end the sequence being read to you, which is very bothersome, especially when there’s a mob of baddies trying to turn you into a pile of bones. Regardless, the tales of furious gods, barbaric races, and more easily surpass any of the lore that the Diablo and Torchlight games were able to muster up.Customization is a huge part of Path of Exile and each player really can create a character to their liking. There’s a varying amount of classes and skill gems. These gems each contain an active ability and can be tacked onto equipment. Upon leveling up characters gain a single skill point that can be added into the—woah… that skill tree is massive. Anyways, the skill tree quickly branches off in a multitude of ways and points can be designated as the player sees fit. Whether the player decides to go for an offensive, defensive, or jack-of-all-trades route, each build is viable and produces a truly unique experience.Path of Exile has a very interesting currency system, both with in-game and real world currencies. To start, in-game currency doesn’t exist. Players must trade items with NPCs and other players for more useful items. This creates an immersive and surreal environment on Wraeclast, a place where something like money would be utterly useless. The game’s cash shop is generally pretty fair. It’s far from pay to win, with the majority of items being purely cosmetic. Charging for character slots is a negligible payment as players could just make another account, but charging for additional guild member slots is a bit ridiculous. Aside from that, the cash shop is very reasonable and one of the better ones in the free to play market.Unfortunately, Path of Exile isn’t all that well optimized. Although the game can run on a range of systems, there are very few available graphical tweaks. I found that even though I ran it quite well, there were slight hiccups where the frame rate would dip for a fraction of a second. Path of Exile is a must-play for anyone who is a fan of the point-and-click action RPG genre. It builds wonderfully on established conventions and executes them masterfully. Combat is just as fun and addictive as in the Diablo and Torchlight games, and collecting awesome loot is half the fun. Its visual presentation is crisp, and although its sound quality shows inconsistent effort, the captivating lore is sure to make up for that. Despite being repetitive in nature, its deep character customization and incredibly depressing atmosphere are sure to keep players hooked for a long time. And it’s free, so you should at least give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												This is a video game simulator in which you click on things and see stuff happen on screen. You get to zone out in front of your computer for hours while giving your mind some basic tasks to keep it distracted. It is kind of like playing Fruit Ninja but with a very complex RPG system under the hood. No, really!Here are some of the more specific things I would like to point out:+Exciting planning and theory-crafting of seemingly flexible (but highly varying in viability) builds.+A more interesting economy which allows you to get something meaningful out of even the most useless of your items.+Satifying visual and audio feedback during combat.+Surprisingly good voice work contributes to the overall vibe and atmosphere.+You can make Youtube videos explaining why your build is the best.+It is infinitely cheaper than Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2.+An incredibly fair, even generous business model.-Unnecessarily padded out and grindey. Complexity and sheer volume are not the same as meaningful depth.-The actual combat lacks any tactical depth, and can get awfully repetitive as most builds rely on 2-3 active abilities.-Occasional lag.-Some elements of the interface are obtuse and fiddly.-No real challenge once you figure out your build and get the right items.-You invest about 5% of your time in researching and planning a build (the good part) and 95% of it in mindless clicking on-screen (the "oh my god, what the ♥♥♥♥ am I doing with my life?!" part).Get this game if you are unemployed or in need of a new outlet for your obsessive-compulsive tendencies.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												A completely free Diablo-style lootfest ARPG, and it's one of quality. Clearly designed by and for a hardcore crowd, but with easy appeal for just about any fan of the genre. It's fun and accessible, yet has plenty of depth if you seek it. And this game is TRULY free-- no BS, no PayToWin aspects at all. And it's still being updated with fresh content. This game is always a blast to play either solo or with friends.In short, PoE is effin' AWESOME and I highly recommend it.If you dig the game as much as I do, you can (and should) show your support for the developers by purchasing any of the cosmetic options in the in-game store to give your character(s) some visual pizzaz. I like the pet selection and the plethora of electricity-themed stuff. My only gripe is that a lot of those shiny items cost way too much, but it's all cosmetic and entirely optional so this is a minor complaint.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												A very good aRPG, it has a few problems, but for a free to play game, nothing to complain about. I have seen some bad reveiws, but to counter thier arguments just read this comment i put to the disapointments they addressed:This is a hardcore game, the steep learning curve is supposed to be there; the XP death penalties are supposed to be there, and as for the trade system well that's one the best things about the game - let me elaborate. In most aRPGs (or any other RPG for that matter) you have a gold based currency system. early game everything you want is way too expensive, but late game you walk around with more money in your pocket than the entire NPC world savings - and that's just chump change to you. With this currency system you acually spend your money in day to day activities. You wanna improve your weapon, that will cost you, you wanna change the seckets for gems, that will cost you and that makes sense!as for the pay to win mechanic, there is PVP in this game, no pay to win means a better, more balanced PVP experience. The way you get items that haven't yet dropped for you is grinding. Either you need lower currency to trade up (wich is easy given a few NPC vender recepies) or you get to a higher level so that you can kill harder enemies that have an increased drop rate and increased rarity of items dropped. Make no mistake this game is hard, but once you get that hang of it and start learning how to make money, its much easier. I have played for over 400 hours and not seen a single exualted gem drop (the main currency) but i have been able to buy them.I will agree that research is essential to this game, but really, i research all the games i buy. I look for where to find better items, good combinations of gear ect. most people do. But when it comes to a perk system like this one, you should expect to need to research - i would suggest if you are starting this game, use a tried and tested build (sumoner is easy and cheap to make), that way you can have a character that will di well, level up and help you find currency to make other characters or even experimentJust remember that failed builds are expected due to the versatility this game offers and don't let it get to you - it's not even a waste of time as this game gets updated a lot and the developers allow full respecs of characters every now and then, allowing to start over with a character that is already leveled, a great oppotunity toi try out new builds, eperiment or repurpose failed builds.You put the time into this game and it will reward you :)

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												a dungeon crawler like diablo yet so very different. the mechanics of this game are very complex and the versatiliy of each class is very vast. there are so many different ways to build each class the possibilities are endless. how it works is you get all of your abilities through socketing skill gems into your gear. there is no penalty for removing gems from your gear though, all you have to do is right click the gem. the passive skill tree is very large and confusing at first and can be very overwhelming but once you understand the basic mechanics of the game it's fairly easy to understand. the idea is to have your skill gems, passive skills, and support gems all working together in synergy to unlock the full potential of your build and your character's abilities. i recommend for your first character play something tanky or maybe a summoner witch. playing a glass cannon as your first character really is not the best idea.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
NOT recommended for RAM below 8GB.It's a very good Diablo II clone, the added Gem mechanic is nice and works well, the balancing is good (so far - first playthrough) and overall I'd recommend it, weren't it for the numerous crashes and the time the game takes to start up again. Granted, my rig isn't very up-to-date, but it definetly exceeds the minimum requirements. But 4GB RAM does not satisfy this game's memory hunger, it crashes at almost every single loading screen after I reached lvl25 or so. Before that, it only crashed at about every third. Now I already searched for fixes and found some (putting -gc 1 in the launch properties for example, low graphics etc.) but that only helps in the first ~half of the game as I played it (I'm currently in act 4, last thing I did was killing Voll), after that I have to restart the game on every loading screen. That means if my inventory is full I can basically just hit Alt-F4 because a TP will cause a crash and a restart gets me to town anyway.The problem seems to be that a lot of things get preloaded into RAM to decrease loading times while ingame, which makes startup take about 2 minutes for me. Gets annoying really fast, although I'd LOVE to spend more time on this game.

												Path of Exile is a superb addition to the Action RPG genre, taking the best of the Diablo and Torchlight series' and adding in its own tweaks to perfect a formula for what any hardcore RPG fan will enjoy.With almost limitless levels of customization for your characters using the simply massive Passive Skills tree as well as the innovative and flexible Ability Stone system, this game offers players the ability to play through it multiple times and experience a different character build every time. Top on the fact that the dungeons are randomly generated and Grinding Gear Games hosts seasonal challenges and there is no end to the amount of content to enjoy.Any fans of Diablo or Torchlight would be doing themselves a great disservice not to try out this game since it costs nothing but your time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Path of Exile is an action RPG, similar to Diablo 2. The game, in the first 30 seconds at least, definitely seems like a Diablo clone. But all that changes once you level up. You open up the skill tree, and you just feel overwhelmed at the size of the skill tree. Classes don't make too much of a difference in the game. Instead, they just change your position on the skill tree, the marauder is closer to heavy weapon skill points, while the witch is closer to spell based skill points. But you can build a 2h weapon wielding witch and a casting marauder!The gameplay itself is simple. Click and kill stuff. The trading is not so simple at first. There is no gold. You can only trade a variety of orbs and items. A bartering system that works incredibly well, since you can use those orbs to improve your weapons and armor as well.Different leagues have different challenges. And beyond the standard and hardcore leagues, there are 4 month leagues that add a new challenge to the game. And beyond that are races that are as short at 1 hour to as long as 2 weeks. The races net you some pretty sweet prizes.But the game is not flawless. The game doesn't run exceptionally well at the highest settings on some systems. The fact that you have to go through 3 difficulties of the game before you reach end game content might be a turn off for some. The fact that the end game content is VERY repetitive might also turn some people off as well. And the biggest flaw, one that the devs are constantly trying to fix, is the desync. The desync issues can kill your character, and if you're on a hardcore league, it could hurt. The game is pretty damn great. I've got nearly 1000 hours played and I don't regret (most) of them. Yes, the desync issues are a major problem, literally the only major problem i have with the game, but I've dealt with it and I still love playing this game.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Before finally giving in and finally installing the game via steam, I have put about little over 300 some hours into playing this game ( about 5 or 6 hour intervals every 3 days a week). What I can tell you is this. Path of Exile is most DEFINITELY the HD remake of Diablo 2 that everyone wanted Diablo 3 to be. Without a doubt the similarity is absolutely 100% there which not even 3 seconds into playing the game, you figure out for yourself. So with that being said I'll get to the pro's and cons of the game IMO.PROS: Pretty much as I said the game is just an hd version of diablo 2.           The dark and chilling atmosphere           The combat system           The greatly unique and in-depth skill tree           The way obtaining spells and abilities work (Skill gems)           The not too shabby microtransaction shop           Completely and utterly free, no buying DLC or expansions no nothing.           Absolutely NO pay to win ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t CAN I GET A HALLELUJAH JESUS!?           Pr   Cons: Not very user friendly for the casual gamer. This can prove to be EXTREMELY frustrating for the casual every day newcomer player. Unlike diablo 3 where it will tell you whats an upgrade for you and whats not, you find new gear which will require having to have a little knowledge about your classes primary stats and what will benefit you. This is time consuming and requires back and forth reading of the stats the gear has and even the slightest hiccup of misinformation can literally make or break your character.  The party loot system: This which is not a big deal for me, can be frustrating for others. The way the party loot system works is well......there isn't one... It's just a rat race to see who can pick up that beneficial piece of armor or weapon first and in some cases, that would really♥♥♥♥♥♥ya off if you don't have good friends who you play with and joined a public party. Pantttttttttss: Quite literally the most ANNOYING thing about this game. New players will find themselves til about level 30 in act 3, every piece of armor they obtain will always lack a leg-cover. So that means for you templars and mauraders out there, we get to see your lovely jock-straps through 55% of the game and its not cool. I know diablo 2 had the same exact aspect but seriously, having the option for equipable pants would be nice guys. Not everyone has $40 to spend on your super awesome fantasy looking armor fit with PANTS. So cut us some slack....The armor: This may not be a big deal to some, but to me its a huge deal. The armor in this game is nothing spectacular whatsoever. So if you come into this game wanting your chacter to look like something from a world of warcraft armor tier, you better go to another game. No matter how much you progress the armor never gets prettier and the lack of style is quite a bummer unless you cater into buying fantasy-esque armor from the microtransaction shop. No armor sets: This is pretty annoying and where I think Diablo 3 really beats the crap out of this game in imo because that's the one thing that I really adored about diablo 2 was its mass ammount of set piece items and bonuses. This is something I think they should add as it brings more playability into the game and gives players something to grind for. I know I'd double my play time if I could get a badass looking and dramatically helpful armor set & set bonus.The story: I may have some disagree which is absolutely fine but I have yet to be sucked into this games story unlike diablo 1, 2 and 3. It's pretty boring imo but the gameplay and overall aspect of the game brings me back into the fight.No offline mode: This annoys me so badly because when it just happens to storm it seems as though my block almost ALWAYS loses internet connection. And everytime I lose my internet connection I flock to nothing but single player video games and this would be great to play offline if only i could play it offline.IMHO the barter system: The barter system is pretty cruddy quite honestly and I know a lot of people will disagree, but obtaining gold and being able to buy and sell with it is much more simpler then what they chose to go with.I just like it more.That's all I got, other than all the cons overall believe this is a great game that with a little fine tuning could VERY WELL be an absolute masterpiece. 9/10 is what I rate it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Pros: - Truly Free to Play- Enormous Skill tree that allows amazing variation in gameplay- Actually great story with several powerful lines.- Developers are active, constantly patching the game and starting new leagues to challenge the more hardcore crowd.- Multiple Weapons Types, and every class can use every weapon if you build it that way, certain classes just allow more optimization- Great endgame- Skills are handled in the form of Ability Gems, which there are enormous variations of, one of my Chest slots is just entirely ability gems.- Easy on the eyes, fairly capable settings menu- Great community- Amusing barter-typ in game economy fits the story and situationCons:- The game is a bit repetitive, especially as you near end game.- The systems in the game aren't always as clear as they could be- Client and Server desynchonise- The initial loading time when launching from steam is enormous for some reason- The story is only told through scrolling textI've been playing Path of Exile since it was in Beta, and it's one of the few games that's managed to effortlessly lure me in, but lets start at the beginning.I haven't played any of the Diablo games, but I knew about the bad launch that Diablo III experienced, and in one of the comment boards or something similar someone mentioned PoE in passing along with the fact that it's entirely free. This of course intrigued me as at the time I was a poor high school student. I value story above all in a game, but PoE drew me in without really putting the story front and center. I was absolutely hooked, but what really elevated this game was the end of Act 1. I had finished farming Merveil for a couple hours and decided to head back to Lionseye Watch, the first hub town and while selling off my stuff I figured might as well see what they're new dialogues were.  Nessa's line "Please, keep one thing in mind for me. What have you become when even nightmares fear you?" made me sit up and pay attention to the story, and then everything really came together for me as the complete package Instead of just the addicting gameplay keeping me glued to the Screen.The game has officially released since then and it's only gotten better.

content:

												It's free, why not? Was the mentality I had when first starting this game. The first time I played, I really couldn't get into it. The gameplay was not as fast and flashy as Diablo 3 and after reaching Sarn, I quit. However, after a year, I returned to the game and my mind was blown at how fun it is. There is so much more depth to the game than I initially thought and then I found that the leveling and end-game was so much better than diablo 3. In addition, thanks to all the community support this game has, trading is so much fun with programs like procurement and poe.xyz. I highly reccommend this game to anyone who enjoys arpg's, even though anyone who is a fan probably tried this game already

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												I love Diablo 2, and Torchlight & Torchlight 2 during my 2010-2012 era. When Diablo 3 was coming out, I wanted it. I NEEDED it. But reading about all the missteps that Diablo 3 took, I felt betrayed. So I never purchased it. That's when Path of Exile crossed my path. And it definitely scratches my Diablo 2 itch. Best of all - it's FREE! The microtransactions are tempting, but kind of pricey. There's nothing I really want to buy, even if I want to throw them $10 bucks. It feels very Diablo 2. Everything clicks, and you'll find yourself looking at loot drops and hoping for a decent weapon. It even has the same inventory! But it also has Final Fantasy X's level-up grid system, and FF7's Materia system where your character can use any skill and any power-up. It also has a very interesting economy. There is no gold! Everything is traded for items. Check it out!It also has events, so if you find yourself bored of power-leveling - create a new character and do a event! Definitely a great way to learn about the insides of the games. Highly recommended.

												Update review #3Atlas of worlds is fantastic!9.5/10------------------------------Old reviews below------------------------------Update review #2They have included an ingame possibility to auction items through the poe.trade website indexer. This has made it so much easier to trade items and has really made the meta game a lot better! They also added a currency tab (premium) which made currency handling easier.The Ascendancy patch was a let down unfortunately. Personally I really don't like the Labyrinth and I find the Ascendancy classes to narrow your choice when playing certain builds. I'm still increasing the rating to:9/10------------------------------Old review below------------------------------Updated review8/10Well they fixed the desync with the awakening patch and you can now roll with a bit slower network response but much more accurate.Highly recommend this awesome game! Some small nitpicks about what I'd like to see in the game is a more suitable way of trading stuff/marketplaces and to make more builds viable for endgame.------------------------------Old review below------------------------------6/10This game is pretty much everything Diablo 3 wasn't... A hardcore game for hardcore gamers better in every way possible except for one thing... The 6/10 boils down to one simple thing... Desync.Playing this game is amazing and frustrating at the same time. Yes the monsters are sometimes quite hard or the endgame bosses might give you a fight but in the end it's pretty much the desyncing of your character that will be your biggest enemy.Getting stuck in corridors and not realizing it until you are pretty much dead, attacking enemies that aren't actually there and waiting 1-3 seconds to pick up an item because your character is not anywhere close to where it's portraid on your clients screen are just some of the things that you experience all the time when playing PoE.It's incredibly frustrating knowing that this game could be so much better if this problem was fixed but unfortunately GGG has talked about this not being a top priority for them.Still worth playing. But could've been so much better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Path of Exile is a classic, completely Free-to-Play Rogue-like Action RPG. It's heavily influenced by Diablo 2 and breathes its legacy in myriad of little details and design decisions.If you know Diablo 2, atmosphere, graphical style and gameplay will remind you of the great classic. While citing Diablo, it's fortunately not a simple clone. It introduces a few fundamental changes, by combining a huge passive skill tree with active skill gems which level independently.Therefore the player as manifold ways to develop the character, being free of most artifical limitations of the initially chosen class. While skills and attributes are chosen via the passive skill tree, the offenisive capabilites are modified via the active skill gems / runes, which have to be equipped via socketed weapons or armor. With varying types of sockets, even a magical character might decide to use his or her favorite melee attack, as long as the character is able to meet the requirements. Support gems buff these active gems, by being placed into "linked" sockets of the same item. This way it is possible to buff i.e. a melee attack with additional frost damage or a life leeching ability.Another remarkable design decision is the currency free economy of Path of Exile. There is no gold to be farmed, so that it is far more rewarding to trade items with your friends. While items like town portals, item quality changing orbs or identifying scrolls serve as a substitution currency, their constant use keeps the whole farming aspect in check.The Free-to-play concept is extremely fair, as there are only cosmetic items or attributes available in the online store. There are no gameplay advantages rewarded for spending money, with the minor exception of a slightly larger item stash.Bottom line:If you are an old fan of Diablo 2 and looking for an Action RPG which brings back old times, go for it. Same applies for casual players who do not wish to spend an awful amount of money just to have a few hours of fun after coming home from work. There are no strings attached, so go forth and try it out!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												If you are a fan of Old School Action RPG ( the kinds of Diablo 1 and 2) then there is probably no better game out there than this one. I'll give you a small list of things to expect from this amazing game:Pros:- Free to play. Need i say more... And the fact that all purchases are 100% cosmetic or quality of life. ABSOLUTELY NO ADVANTAGES CAN BE BOUGHT. Need i say more :).- Enourmous Talent tree, making hundreds of viable builds.- Skill system based on gems, making combos of skills a maze of choices.- Constant updates and great community.- Plenty of leagues and challenges always poping up, including the odd race weekend leagues.- Almost all resolutions supported, easy on the machine.- End game is extensive, not to say endless, and everything is interchangeable between characters.Cons:- Online only.- Could have the option to zoom out a little further.- Still "incomplete", huge patch coming up summer of 2017 which i believe will make things even more awesome.- Some people don't adapt easily to the mouse movement.For those deciding to start the exile path, a few tips out of the box:- Search for Loot filter, find one that suits you, and put it in the game. You don't know the time you will save searching for loot until after you done it.- Vendor recipies are a thing. So for the beggining search for the Chromatic Orb(Three linked sockest of different collors) and Chaos Orb ones, they make a big impact in the long run.- Thouroughly search the UI options and make it up to your liking (Heck, i didn't have a minimap up until i was going at the 30 or more hours).In the end, you will make A LOT of mistakes on your first toon due to the complexity of the learning curve, but if you are an ARPG fan, there is no better game out there.9.5/10 - Could be better still, and maybe the note should be around 8.5, but there are so many constant updates and HUGE patches, it's completely free,  that i feel it deserves to be called The best when it comes to its genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												Path of Exile is one of the most engaging ARPGs I've played lately.  I'd highly recommend this to fans of Diablo or Torchlight who wish that there were a few more ways to customize their character.  The classes are diverse (and customizable) and combat is intense and sufficiently difficult.All skills in the game are contained in gems, which are slotted into equipment similar to how materia was equipped in Final Fantasy VII.  Also, character progression is done through a non-linear system that reminds me of the Sphere Grid from Final Fantasy X.  There is no hard currency (such as gold or gems) in the game.  Instead, there is a wide variety of customization orbs that can be traded as currency to either vendors or other players.I've had a lot of fun playing PoE, and find myself coming back to it whenever I want to play a good action-oriented smash-and-loot game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												I just got this on Steam but played since Closed Beta. 200+ Hours into this game. I started with a level 51 Summoner Witch, then started a Ranger, got to Level 71 Lightning Arrow crit build. Now I've made a Marauder 2 handed Mace build with Ground Slam/ Hatred Aura for cold damage and he is at level 78 going on 79. The game is addictive.The Skill system is unique and fresh. The passive tree is a little offputting to noobs but it makes sense and is great after some getting used to. The battles and bosses are fun and require planning in later difficulties. Maps at the end are fun with friends, I like crafting my own level 70 maps and doing them :P or doing 66-67 maps with some magic find gear on. Trading is a bit rough, I like the currency system with orbs, but they do need an in game auction house (NOT WITH REAL MONEY). People use POE.XYZ online to sell items mostly its an item search engine. Trade chat is abysmal at best. If you like action RPG's this is much more fun than Diablo 3.  This game is free, and worth much more. I put in $20 to support developers and get 6 new stash tabs :P TRY IT

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												This game looks and feels like a spiritual successor to Diablo 2, arguably even surpassing it.     Enormous passive skill tree that replaces flat stat increases on level up and shared between all classes in the game. Nodes vary between flat and percent increases to various stats to some unique modifiers that completely change things around. Picking different classes starts you out in different areas of that tree with complete freedom to develop in any path you desire from that point, creating countless build variants.    Active skill tree is replaced with skill gem system in which gems are your active skills which you can level up separately and socket in your gear as you see fit. Further more, those gems can be combined creating different skill effects and sometimes even changing the way the affected skills work. Amount of available skill gems is just as enormous as the passive skill tree.    The standard gold currency is replaced with various orbs of varying values and rarity, creating a barter trade system between players and NPCs. These orbs can be applied to your gear to modify it. Depending on the orb used it is possible to change item quality or rarity, add or remove bonus properties, change number of gem sockets, socket coloring and links or re-roll bonuses or their numeric values. This means, with enough luck you can essentially craft any item from the common quality gear with no bonus stats. This adds another layer of depth to the game.    If you are feeling competitive, there are different leagues with different rule sets modifying core game experience. Small races are hosted on a 24/7 schedule which bend game rules even further to create some fun challenges. Participating in them earns you points which are used to reward your account with race exclusive gear based on how much points you have at the end of the racing season.    On top of all this its completely FREE to play, without any pay to win shenanigans. The only item in the cash shop that can affect your gameplay experience in any way is extra storage tabs in your shared loot stash, everything else is purely cosmetic stuff ranging from gear skins and skill effect skins to passive pets.     However, this game is difficult to get into. It has a somewhat slow and effortless start followed by almost vertical vertical difficulty wall hitting you in the face once you switch to harder difficulty. This, combined with passive skill tree and gems total freedom of choice and complete randomness of loot means that your first character will most likely end up as a big disappointment and scrapped mid way through the game. It is impossible to beat all three difficulties in this game without careful planning of your build, skills and gear. But as soon as you get comfortable with game mechanics and synergies the game sucks you in and you start trying different builds all the time.Bottom line, If you liked playing Diablo 2 or any other ARPG before, it would be a mistake not to give Path of Exile a try.PS:I also forgot to add an important detail. The game suffers from slight desync from time to time, usually it's tied to some skills that involve jumping teleporting or any kind of fast movement. If you decide to play on hardcore league this can become a major annoyance. The game has a built in chat console command (/oos) to combat this, but sometimes you just don't have time to type that in and not everyone likes or can use keyboard macros or tools like Autohotkey.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												“In my dreams I see a great warrior, his skin scorched black, his fists aflame.” Path of Exile (PoE) is an online action role-playing game (arpg) developed and published by the company Grinding Gear Games. Atmosphere & presentation: + Free-to-play game that can be completed, enjoyed and continued without spending money. + Grim and dark atmosphere is supported by appropriate background music.+ Creative level and monster design. o A permanent internet connection is required, in order to access the PoE servers.o Cosmetic effects can be bought via in-game microtransactions. Combat & gameplay: ++ The passive ability tree is massive. In combination with the creative skill gem system it provides a multitude of options for character development and tuning towards the end game.+ Replayability profits from the league system and randomly generated (end game) maps, with countless variation in form of map modifiers, increasing the difficulty with each added attribute.+ Creative currency system with elaborate item-changing properties. + In-game trade system allows the easy acquirement of high end gear from other players. + ‘Hardcore’ mode satisfies the needs of the masochistic player community.Characters & story: + Interesting side characters provide the player with entertaining information about current and past events of the game world.o Limited identification of the player with the protagonist. - No cutscenes or other means of exposition are used to support the storytelling or foreshadow future events. Summary: Overall, PoE offers offers high-quality hack & slash gameplay with sophisticated arpg mechanics that can be enjoyed from the beginning to the end on a free-to-play basis. It is a challenge to reach the end and you can definitely end up putting a lot of hours into it.Furthermore, the game succeeds in the field of long term motivation by providing an elaborated league system that maintains the in-game economic balance and replayablity.The only shortcoming of this game lies in the presentation and simplicity of the storytelling. While the different non-player characters will fill you in about the historic and current events in Wraeclast, no other means are used to bolster up the storyline. Trivia: While 60 percent of donors were in the $10 range, the ‘diamond tier’, in which someone commits to $1,000 or more, found 183 supporters.Achievements: A little advice for achievement hunters. The level of difficulty is a 10 out of 10 on the freak scale with a badass seal of approval.Estimated time for 100 % completion: +300 hoursOffline achievements: noneOnline achievements: 84Chronology: Path of Exile (PC) Action role-playing game + hack & slash (Dark Fantasy) – 2013

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Got allmost 2k hours in this game, and i can still figure out new ways to play and build the chars i make and that means a lot for a player like me that is allways trying to figure out something nobody else has done. The massiveness of the game and the constant updates from GGG makes this game allways fresh.GGG has created originality in the sense of there desire to keep inflation out of the game economy which they have done by making every item in the game a currency in itself. Skills are items you find and use in sockets which means skills is a tradeable currency to.Every skill can get enhanced by support gems you link to them, as an excample fireball linked with chain making the fireball chain between targets. There are a lot of different gems and a lot of different ways to combine em. and deserves a try from all gamers out there.You can play this as a casual player, or as a hardcore player that desires the competive scene.At the first glanse of the skill tree in this game it might seem that you will never learn it, but in my oppinion it is far from as hard as people make it to be.Events are being created runningly to keep the game exciting besides the new leagues that last for longer periods at a time. With every new league they create new prices for both the hardcore racers and the casual players that just want to get the achivements or challenges to earn a price.Path of exile has gotten some critisisme for the famours "Desyncs" since the release.With the version 2.0 on the door step GGG has made an official statement they are adding a new network model to the game to fix the issue it has caused for some players.On a more personal note on that matter, i have died to em myself but over my hours of path of exile i have learned to avoid the desyncs you can cause in the game, so for me the desyncs is not a problem anymore. But i understand it can be an annoying factor for some players.A quote from GGG themselves:Wraeclast is a dark, brutal continent. Scarred by mysterious catastrophes of the past and inhabited by creatures of nightmare, the very environment challenges exiles who dare explore it.We're sick of the recent trend towards bright, cartoony RPGs. The art style we chose for Path of Exile is dark, gritty and realistic. Wraeclast is terrifying, and we've tried hard to do it justice.In Path of Exile, replayability is key. All world areas including outdoors ones are instanced for your party and randomly generated, right down to the magic properties of the monsters that dwell in them and the treasure they guard.I coulden agree more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												******DIABLO 2/3               VS.           PATH OF EXILE REVIEW******First of all, I have over 3000+ hours played on Diablo 3 and 9~ years of constant play on Diablo 2(00' - 09' RIP best gaming years of my life). I'm currently only at 166 hours on POE and as I play more and as both games are updated I will add/edit information based on *MY OPINION*. If this review helps you make a decision on whether to try it, or is informational please thumbs up!Second and very importantly for some of you: PVP -Diablo 3 has NO PVP. POE has GREAT pvp with often events! For you WOW players POE has twinks. There are a large number of pvpers and great events like capture theflag, arenas, tournaments, free for all's, dueling. There is a league where you can find people in PVE zones and attack/kill/loot them, but rest assured carebears, all the other leagues are safe.PVP in-depth - http://pathofexile.gamepedia.com/Player_versus_playerStyle -POE has more of a diablo 2 feel VS the feel of diablo 3. It is a much more in depth hack and slash then Diablo 3. It has a difficulty playthrough style as did Diablo 2 where you go through normal, nightmare, hell as well as it scaling in difficulty based on your level VS D3's scale as you level select your difficulty. This makes the game challenging where you meet the requirements with your equipment vs being able to blow though the game in D3 on normal with any gear on. Both games have hardcore characters but if you die in hardcore POE your character becomes softcore which i'm a fan of.Endgame - Diablo 3 has greater rifts, POE has maps, maps are dropped items with rarity i.e. normal, magic, rare, unique with EVERY MAP being UNIQUE. The maps have unique traits that make each one different and more/less difficult. an example of traits that can be found on maps are: 2 bosses in the map, a curse of a certain type for the full duration of the map(I.E. reduced movement speed, attack speed), monsters in the map have more damage, hp, or attackspeed, increased items found on map, increased rarity ETC. There are many modifiers!Builds/Gear/Class - Diablo 3 has cookie cutter builds, most of the classes have 1 and 2 builds that are viable for greater rifts 35~+. POE also has cookie cutter builds but a major difference is gear and: *SKILL TREE* which Diablo 3, doesnt have. POE's skill tree consists of, wait for it, ***One Thousand Three hundred and Twenty Five** thats 1325 skill points. The max your character can currently attain is 120 clearing all quests and achieveing level 100, which would take you a good while. The tree makes it so it doesnt completely matter what class you choose, you can get the same skills as any class on any character. The tree with everything combined makes leveling a new character to try out your new unique build really, really fun. There's strength, Dex and Int by default and 7 classes: Marauder, Duelist, Ranger, Shadow, Witch, Templar and Scion.Diablo 3 has legendarys, POE they are uniques, In POE they are actually HARD TO FIND. No legendary every 5 minutes thats most likely going to be a pos. Uniques have much more value then legendarys in diablo. In the last ~30 hours i've found 2 uniques. Rares(Yellows) in POE can be GREAT and you can build an end game character purely off rares. You can actually get excited when a rare of a certain armor/weapon/jewelry type drops.Now, other then the skill tree and its customization options, the other HUGE advantage POE has over D3 are skills, there is a HUGE number of passive, support and active skills that come only in gems, its similar to legendary gems in D3 on crack. The skill gems in POE are complicated but a quick ecplanation is you find/buy them, get armor with say 1-6 sockets, you can link the sockets to link skill gems which is what youll be doing once you get better/higher level. For you D3 players its be like linking cluster arrow to 30% reduced resource cost, 40% fire damage, 30% faster attack speed, multishot which would fire 4 clusters at those modifiers. The skill tree and skill gems OWN Diablo 3. You can think it up, level the char before or after you find/buy the right gear, test it, improve it, tweak it. D3 - use this build roll these items from kadala shards and farm act 1 chests for rorg till you get 6/5/4 piece akkhan's/firebirds/marauders/raekors/sunwukos with these stats and GG, oh but good luck finding a wep especially an ancient BiS. skillsgems POE site - http://www.pathofexile.com/skillsPassive tree builder - https://poebuilder.com/Trading/Economy -D3- lootshare? Real money auction house(pay to win)?  <(  ; _  ;  )>POE- ORBS/ITEMS. Orbs are items that change gear in various ways that double as currency with traders and players. The orbs(currency) add/remove/change stats of items, upgrade rarity of items, change socket number, color, links. There are 25 types of currency in POE with varying values some being EXTREMELY rare(worth thousands of the other valuable currencies). The trading system in POE is great, They shouldve had a similar system in Diablo 3.POE currencies - http://www.pathofexile.com/item-data/currencyConclusion - Path of Exile > Diablo 3 in my opinion.  If you enjoyed Diablo 2 TRY THIS GAME. If you enjoy Diablo 3 TRY THIS GAME. If you enjoy a challenge similar to Diablo 2 try it. The only things purchasable with real money in game are cosmetic. BUT the only downfall of POE is stash tabs are purchasable only with real money, at a reasonable price for it being a FREE game.POE WIKI - http://pathofexile.gamepedia.com/Path_of_Exile_WikiHave i convinced you to try it out? Watch this first itll save you alot of time:25 things you should know before starting Path of Exile:


YouTube™ Video: 25 things you should know starting off in Path of Exile 

			Views: 559,784		

			1. Chromatic orbs and gear 0:13 2. Socket connecting 0:56 3. Class selection 1:33 4. Armor and weapon selection 2:00 5. Overleveling gems 2:17 6. Using other peoples portals 3:19 7.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												I am currently closing in on 200 hours, and feel better positioned to give a full review of this game.The basics: Free to play, and everything people were actually hoping for out of Diablo 3.The visuals: The visuals are what you would consider current gen for PC.  Gone are the murky levels and textures of D3, and in with something clean and more modern.  I've had no issues with slowdown, and GGG are continually tweaking the video options to ensure the game perform well across most PC configurations.The sound: Decent quality, although you might run into some issues with Creative cards.  This won't come as a surprise to you if you're had Creative cards forever, but it might annoy you until you find out what the issue is, and the work-around.  Creative owners know that Creative updates their drivers once every two years or so, and tend to leave huge bugs unpatches.  That aside, the overall game sounds and soundtrack are high quality.What makes this game different:  An insanely deep skill tree, randomized maps, and an unlockable character after you complete your first run.  Oh, and it's F2P, and no Pay 2 Win from the micro-transaction store.Difficulty Scaling: Three grades of difficuly, and end game content is well flushed out.  Once you complete your highest difficutly run, you can loop back for items and things you might have missed, or you can start running the handful of 'Maps' that dropped for you once you got past level 60.  These maps have unique challenges attached, and can have their quality adjusted to increase their rewards.Grinding Gear Games runs new leagues in seasons, one normal and one hardcore, with hardcore death causing your character to be moved to the permanenent 'normal' mode.  These are often referred to by trolls 'scrubcore' and 'hardcore'.  I prefer to think of them as 'drunkcore' and 'coffeecore'.  The microtransaction store they utilize to keep the game alive and in development offers only cosmetic items, along with the usual stash upgrades, and is relatively unobtrusive.  They run special 'races' on a regular basis, which allow you to compete for Unique prizes each season.  These include special dungeon runs, races to top level/area, and coming soon, PVP tourneys.Overall, this is an incredibly solid and addicting game, and if you're a fan of ARPGs overall, you might find yourself logging quite a few hours in this one.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2013
												I immediately fell on love with this game! I'll break it down into pros and cons. But the cons really aren't enough to make it not worth playing.==PROS==- First off, it's FREE! And the things in game you do pay for are all aesthetic. So there is no Pay-to-win here.- LOOT!! Loads of loot that is satisfying to find- It looks fantastic! Lot's of gore too- The passive skill tree is amazing- Heaps of nostalgic feelings. If you loved Diablo 2, then play this!- The new potion system is somewhere between classic potions and health globes. But the ability to find "magic" potions makes it fantastic- Skill gems are weird, but it's grown on me- The corpses of monsters staying piled up is gruesome and satisfying==CONS=- Some of the animations are funky. Running looks odd. And there isn't always a lot of oomph to attacking- Can sometimes be lag, where hit's take a second to register (not often though)- I like the removal of gold, but sometimes the bartering system can be super annoying- I wish there were more acheivements. They seem too few and far between

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												A rather good singleplayer experience in the vein of classic Diablo. Surprisingly polished for a free-to-play title, I especially like the perk web and skill gems compared to static skill trees, and the NPCs actually have sensible things to say - at least for your first go around.No payment necessary to play and advance, as all paid content is cosmetics, which I think is rather fair.The multiplayer is okay, but PvE gets dull fast, as there is not enough variety to pose a challenge and the skills that are fun in singleplayer quickly turn into overpowered steamrollers in multiplayer. Bosses are are a little limited for a modern game, very few different stages and either the fight is over fast or gets protracted. The lenient respawn system alleviates frustration.I would definitely recommend the game for anyone into hack'n'slash, as it is free and of decent quality.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												At first, PoE seemed to me like a worse (graphically and styalistically) version of Diablo 2 or 3, but the charm in the experience comes from Grinding Gear Games knowing that they are not Diablo...they are much more hardcore.What this game lacks in immediate charm it makes up in lasting allure towards leveing, gearing, and the fear of *gasp* permadeath (dependant on the server you play on).  My brother played the game completely non-hardcore and still liked it, so theres something to be said for that, but this game puts the HARD into hardcore.  Spend talent points sub-optimally?  You're going to die.  Don't have enough survivability? Or damage output? Dead.  Think your character is invincible?  I suppose that's obvious but YOU WILL LOSE YOUR FIRST FEW CHARACTERS BECAUSE THEY SUCK.And I liked it anyway.

												From as far as I have played on PoE, its very different from Diablo. But with those differences make it a good game to play. Though in Diablo, you get good equipment straight from the first boss you fight. In PoE, not so much, you get regular equipment. Honestly I like PoE better than Diablo, as it is a tougher game to things in and I do think other people will consider playing PoE too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												While similar to a more DiabloII, this ARPG dungeon crawler is fun in its own right. The grid-sphere system they revamped from FFX makes for a very fun leveling up system, and one that allows a great deal of versatility.  Now, it sometimes is more illusion than reality, but that there are so many different paths one can take, and even be a non traditional playstyle is great for me. I believe player freedom is one of the more important aspects of online games, and in general, choices - even from the basically talents and style, should have an impact on the experience. No one size fits all, and at least on the surface, Path of Exile seems to recognize that. I have spent a great deal of time playing with good friends as well as having solor characters; either way, for a free game, it's absolutely worth a look.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Path of Exile is one of those games that makes you want to punch your screen, face to keyboard or just sit there in silence as you died to a bunch of fire BUT it is also one of those games that makes hardcore actually hardcore, carries a very smart way of dealing with currency. Do I want a new piece of gear? More Currency? MAYBE craft a new item all together? Lets try it all! The game is SO in depth with its vast array of passive nodes that says if I die let me try this build out see if its better... 5 hours later and you are level 40ish and you just died you say NEW BUILD and do it all over again, the replayable content is so amazing that it makes me come back to it all the time just to die to Hailrake because I have 0% Cold Resist. Curse you perma-frozen!!! On top of all this, the developers are always looking for ways to improve the game and have continued to do so. Im talking about races, new leagues, MORE ITEMS even more maps for end game playability. My review so far has been totally from my heart to this game so without further adou I say this game is allowed a 10/10. Tons of content, an insane passive tree and the heart-warming troll De-Syncs of the century :).

												This game is one of my favorite action RPG's. The gameplay is solid with a variety of builds that you can create with the numerous skill gems that you can find throughout the game. There is also a massive skill tree, which lets you fine tune your build. The developers also offer timely patches/updates to the game to make it fresh and exciting each time you play. content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												This game is really a great example of an f2p game done correctly. You NEVER need to buy a single thing at all, you can pay to support the game and get skins for your stuff.The normal difficulty -You are forced to start with it anyway- is easy and not frustrating at all. The only tip to ease your life -and not make you quit this game- is don't fight the final boss of Act I until you have a cold resistance ring (or 2). This really is the only tip you need to beat normal. Get the right resistance rings for bosses instead of one set of rings.Take your time and enjoy the first run you get of this game, even if you explore every single room. Hands down the best time you'll experience this game is the very first run.Edit : It got even better with the addition of the endgame atlas. This is a must try f2p game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Nothing like a good hack 'n slash and this is what Diablo 3 SHOULD have been. Finely polished with amazing visuals, deep character customization and massive deep skill trees. So rare for a F2P game to be this well done and even the cash shop offers nothing to give you an advantage, though the extra tabs and bank slots come in handy!This game is sure to give countless hours of good times, both solo and with friend(s). I tend to gravitate towards dungeon crawl, hack n slash, loot fest titles and this one is a sure crowd pleaser. It's barely a year old and has been gaining traction since. This game is totally free to play and never asks for a dime, nor will you ever need to spend any. There is no Auction House (at least none that I found in the Normal modes) so relying on loot, boss drops and player to player trading will keep you on your toes, though the NPC vendors offer really nice goods and you can always use orbs and gems to upgrade or re-roll items stats and rarities. Another thing that stands out with this one over say Diablo 1/2 and Fate is the fact you can have and use multiple skills at one time. You are not stuck with a left click and right click skill. Like Torchlight II, you can have up to 8 active skills. This is where having an MMO mouse comes in handy so much!All in all if you are like me and love games like Torchlight/Torchlight II, Diablo, Fate and any other good dungeon crawl, loot fest, hack n slash games this one is a MUST try!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Don't let the Steam hours decieve you, I have played over 4k+ hours of this game.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I started playing PoE on the 9th of February, 2012. At that time, the game was in Closed Beta, It was hard to get a key to get in. I've been playing the game on and off ever since.First I'd like to start with some Pros and Cons.+ Unlimited replayability.+ Insanely fun.+ Difficult to master.+ Very good economy system.+ It pays off to play with friends.+ Well made microtransaction-system.- Desync.- Starts off slow if youre a beginner.The game is very big. It consists of 3 acts, featuring 3 difficulties plus an End-game "Map" system, with a level cap of 100. It even comes with races and "recently" they've included special leagues with special formats and gimmicks that the normal "Standard" and "Hardcore" versions don't have. The game features one of (if not) the biggest passive-tree in all of video-gaming. It is a very big thing, it's what makes Path of Exile what it is. All of the different combinations of skills and passives you can do is endless, you will never do every single combination. Skills aren't granted through the tree, Skills are given to you using different gems, which are given to you through completing the games story-line and finding them by killing things.The economy system of PoE is very interesting, it consists of "orbs" that you will find while killing things, these orbs are the currency. For a list of all the currency click here.[www.pathofexile.com] Using these orbs you can trade for different items with other players aswell as with NPCs inside of the towns or your own Hideout."Well, how does GGG make money of this game?"GGG makes money by their fantastic Microtransaction model. It is -all- cosmetics with some convinence items (stash expansions, these are a great way of supporting the game if you dislike the cosmetics).The game is hard, it's not easy to play and it's definetly not easy to adapt to the desyncs and such. You WILL ♥♥♥♥ your first character up. I recommend visiting the PoE Forums at first and finding a build labeled "cheap" and then following that for your first character. Playing with friends definetly pays off as it makes the grinding a bit less tedious and it generally makes the leveling phase alot more enjoyable. The game even gives you a +50% Increased Drops per person in your party.Overall, the game is alot of fun with very few flaws, biggest one being the desync, but if you enjoy playing ARPGs, or if you disliked D3, this game is definetly worth trying out. And if you never have played before, don't play on Standard, it's practicly the dumpster of all leagues.

												It's a good fun game in the vein of the original Diablo's before the "re-imagining" of Diablo III. Very different in style than Torchlight II, this game is dark, and foreboding and it really feels like you vs everone else.I play it mostly as single player and the occaisonaly net glitches don't tract from a brilliant single-player experience. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												If you can accept occational rubberbanding and want a true Diablo experience, then this is the game. The rubberbanding, though not excessive, has cost me my life on a few occations.There are a few other things I don't like besides the rubberbanding. I have a hard time getting used to how the economy works and would have preferred gold as main currency. With the extremely big passive skill tree, it's absolutely possible to mess up your character pretty bad, and you can't just respec if you for example made a glass cannon that gets 1-shot on "malicious" level. To respec you have to buy these "orbs of regret" which will allow you to change 1 passive skill. I find this system is a bit tiresome and I strongly recommend that you use a tried and tested build from pathofexilebuilds.com, because you WILL have to respec several points if you just pick what you like as you go.I played until I hit level 56(?), but kinda lost interest after falling victim to the death penality a few times too many (you lose 10% of an entire level which will take a long time to get back). To me the game lacks "flow" for lack of a better word. I still recommend it however, and as it is 100% free to play, you have nothing to lose by trying it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												| WARNING | If you do not have a good computer and internet connection, you're gonna have a bad time. You might not feel the effects until 20+ hrs into the game as that's the amount of time it takes for you/allies/enemies to get decyncing, fps-dropping, lag inducing skills. On to the actual review.As someone who has played Fate, Torchlight 2, and Diablo 3, I can say with certainty that PoE is... not bad. The game has an interesting crafting/trading system (though it's extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ when you're poor and/or ignorant), much darker graphics than it's competitors (a surprise given one is named 'devil'), and a good amount of content including a smidgen of endgame. The environments are diverse, you'll find a large asortment of interesting enemies, and randomly generated killamajigs (strongboxes, rogue exiles, whatever buffs they add during leagues) will keep you on your toes. But I feel the game falls short in its most differentiable area - the passive tree and skill gems. Although these mechanics allow for much more potential build diversity than in other ARPG's, they also force your character into spamming 1 and only 1 damaging skill which eventually leads to dull, repetitive gameplay.I really wish there was a way to make a neutral review, but since there isn't I will recommend this game to anyone looking for a new ARPG, and doesn't mind Maplestoryesque skill/pot spamming.
